APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION

To the
Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

October 1st, 1938

Sir,—
I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the Sechelt Residential Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child:
English name: Riona Joseph
Age: 6
Name of Band: Alert Bay
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid:
Father's full name and No.: John Joseph
Mother's full name and No.: Emily August
Parents living or dead: Living
State of child's health: Good
Religion: R.C.
Does applicant speak English?: Yes
Previously attended: No school for years

[Signature of father]

Note—If mother or guardian signs, agent must forward full explanatory note.

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

[Signature of Missionary or other Witness]

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

Note.—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

I beg to forward you herewith, application for admission to the Sechelt Indian Residential School, in respect to Rose Marie Joseph, 7 years of age, of the Skway Band, Chilliwack.

This girl is the illegitimate child of Bernadette Joseph, who has abandoned her with her old father and mother, who are unable to look after her, and I would, therefore, recommend her admission to the School.

I am also enclosing application in respect to Charles Joseph Mussell, 9 years of age, the son of Bernard Mussell of the Skwah Band, Chilliwack. This man and his wife have separated, the wife has been in the State of Washington somewhere for several years, and Mussell himself, is rarely at the Reserve, and lives all over British Columbia with various women. The child was abandoned with his mother's parents, who are old and destitute, and I accordingly recommend his admission to the School.

In view of the circumstances outlined above, I have signed both the applications as Indian Agent.

Enclos.

SECHELT, B.C.

Jan 3, 1947

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have just completed the quarterly report. I wish to report that there are still two or three children whose names appear on the report and whose application forms have not been sent in.

It is most difficult in some cases to get the application form signed by the father. When the Missionary visits the Reserves the parents are often away fishing or working in some inaccessible logging camp. I have tried mailing the forms to the parents in the past, but this has not worked out well in most cases.

I expected all the parents would visit their children at the school this Christmas. They did not, and the result is there are still three application forms to be sent in.

In such cases would it suffice to have the mother sign? The way things look now it will be Easter before all the application forms are duly signed.

Yours very truly,

H. F. Dunlop, Q.M.I.
Ottawa, January 14, 1947.

Rev. H.F. Dunlop, O.M.I., Principal, Sechelt Indian Residential School, Sechelt, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, it will be quite in order to have the mother sign the application form for admission in the absence of the father.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

We are enclosing herewith application for admission to Sechelt Residential School for Gordon McMillan and Mary, or Marjory, McMillan, children of Daniel McMillan, Indian of the Kitamaat Band, Bella Coola Agency.

We have a letter from Indian Superintendent H. D. Taylor of Vancouver Agency advising that these two children had been sent to Sechelt Residential School by the day school teacher at Churchhouse, as the children were being neglected by the parents.

The teacher, being new, did not first consult Mr. Taylor but took it on himself to send the children to the school.

The principal informed Mr. Taylor that they would have room for the children, at least for some time, as evidently a number of the Indians at Sechelt were across the line picking hops and fruit and had not returned. We have now received, through Mr. Taylor's office, the enclosed applications for admission so evidently room has been found for these two children.

Dan McMillan, although a member of the Kitamaat Band, has been living in and around Churchhouse for the past 13 years or so and is married to a woman of the Churchhouse Band, Vancouver Agency.

The day school teacher advised Mr. Taylor that the parents were neglecting the children, going away from the village a great deal and leaving the children evidently with friends or relatives.

It will be appreciated if the Department will approve of the admission of these two children.

T. A. Levelton
for Supt., Indian Agency

Sechelt School——Reverend Father McCaffrey's reply was not as satisfactory as I would have wished, as he was of the opinion that it would be a mistake to give Coast Indians any technical education as it might induce them to migrate to the more populous centres where they would have to compete with white labour. He is of the opinion, however, that a properly equipped plant for the repair and making of shoes for the pupils would serve a useful purpose. Father McCaffrey, however, is a new man in the Indian work and what I have seen of him leads me to conclude that he is more studious than practical. In view of the attitude of this School, I am of the opinion that no manual training equipment should be purchased as the phase of technical education at present being dealt with has reference to manual training only. Possibly next year the Principal may become possessed with a broader vision.

EXTRACT from Report of G. H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools, regarding his inspection of the SECHELT Indian Residential School on May 19 & 20, 1931.

Original on File 167-18-6.

Vocational Training:

The Principal informs me that he could not afford to pay the salary of a Manual Training Instructor. There is a Shoe Shop, containing one Singer machine. In this shop, the repairs to all the shoes are made. Half soles and heels are put on by the boys under instruction. This work seems to me to be satisfactory. The boys do some garden work.

In the Sewing Room, there are six machines in good condition. The girls make their own dresses, knit, sew, mend, darn, and do fancy work. They also, of course, learn to clean, cook, bake, and wash. This work shows when the girls leave school in cleaner homes, better food, and homemade clothes. The crochet, fancy work, tatting and knitting that I saw were excellent.
Ottawa, July 16, 1931.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Sechelt Indian Residential School is one of the few of our institutions in British Columbia where manual training is not given proper prominence. In 1928, when the Department equipped most of the residential schools and arranged a grant towards the cost of a manual training instructor, the Rev. Principal was so doubtful about the advisability of special training, that the Department did not take any action in the case of this school. Mr. Inspector Barry's most recent report states the Rev. Principal at Sechelt informed him that he could not afford to pay the salary of a manual training instructor. It appears that only garden work and shoe repairing are undertaken by the boys.

The Department wishes you to discuss this question with the Rev. Principal at the first opportunity. Inform him that we will pay $50 a month towards the cost of a qualified manual training instructor and will supply, not only the equipment required for the purpose, but lumber for woodworking and other materials from time to time. You will please report the result of your efforts.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

P. J. C. Ball, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
819 Metropolitan Bldg.,
Vancouver, B. C.
Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th with reference to manual training at Sechelt Residential School. I consulted with the present principal, Father Maillard, who is agreeable to this special training being given, and we were both in complete accord in suggesting that Mr. A.R. Tebbs, of Selma Park, Sechelt, be engaged as instructor. He is fully qualified to teach the usual manual training work and what is more important in a fishing community, can also teach boat-building and Father Maillard and I respectfully recommend that this man be given favourable consideration when an instructor is appointed. I am glad this work is being undertaken, and suggested it to the former Principal who was not in favour for some reason or other. The ex-pupils are far more likely to make use of such instruction than any academic learning they may acquire.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]

Ottawa, August 10, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to manual training instruction at the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say it is noted that the Principal and yourself recommend that Mr. A. R. Tebbs be engaged as instructor, as he is fully qualified. The Department will approve of the appointment of Mr. Tebbs and, as stated in official letter of the 16th ultimo, will pay the sum of $50 a month towards the cost of his salary. The Reverend Principal could arrange to pay Mr. Tebbs each month, and at the end of each quarter you could forward a voucher, in duplicate, properly certified, in favour of the Principal, for the amount of salary allowed by this Department.

If any equipment or tools are required, I have to request that you will, after consulting Mr. Tebbs, prepare a list of the supplies absolutely necessary, together with an estimate of the cost, and forward same for the consideration of the Department. Should any lumber for woodworking, etc., be required, you should also prepare a list of same and forward it to the Department, stating the cost, when consideration will be given to authorizing the purchase.

You might also advise the Department as to the date upon which Mr. Tebbs begins duties. It is hoped that he will meet with success in his instruction of the pupils in manual training work.

F. J. C. Ball, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
619 Metropolitan Bldg.,
Vancouver, B.C.

Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 10th ultimo regarding manual training for Sechelt School, the Principal advises me that it will be necessary to make alterations in the school to accommodate the workshop and if the material is supplied, the School workman will do the work free. I have obtained figures for this, which with windows and doors will amount to $102.35. It is proposed to have the benches and cupboards made by the boys under the manual training instructor's supervision, the cost of this lumber, etc., being $26.50. There will be a small additional cost for the bench screws so that the total for the room, benches and cupboards will be approximately $150.00. Stock benches complete with screws cost $40.00 each so a considerable saving will be effected in having them made.

I asked Mr. Tebb to give me a list of articles considered necessary for the pupils, and the enclosed was submitted by him. Part of the list shows what each pupil will need, part shows what each pair of pupils can use together and the balance shows the tools for general use. I have had no previous experience with manual training in Indian schools, but Mr. Tebb appeared to understand what is required so I submit the list as sent in by him. I obtained prices from three local firms on the patronage list and the total for these articles, figuring on a class of twelve, will amount to approximately $250.00 according to the lowest tender. In compliance with your instructions, I also obtained prices on wood to be used in the manual training class and this amounted to $40.00.

In summary of the total expenditure, I beg to submit the following and respectfully request your advice as to purchasing same:

- Lumber for school---------------------$102.35,
- Lumber and other material for benches, etc.------------------50.00,
- Tools and other supplies for pupils---250.00,
- Wood for working---------------------40.00,

Total----------$442.35,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Freight will be in addition to these figures and with various unforeseen items may raise this figure to nearly $500.00, but the school will then be well equipped.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C. Hall]
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, September 29, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, relative to the alterations necessary to provide workshop facilities for the carrying on of manual training instruction at the Sechelt Indian Residential School, and enclosing a list of tools, etc., required in conducting the classes.

In reply I have to say the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding approximately $150 in carrying out the alterations required in the school and in providing the lumber required in making benches and cupboards for the work to be performed by the boys under the supervision of the manual training instructor. The Department will also approve of you purchasing the various woodworking tools as mentioned in the list, to an expenditure of approximately $250, as well as the wood required for working purposes by the class. You should arrange for the purchase of the above materials, tools, etc., from indicated sources, after obtaining their best prices, and the purchase should be made from the firm quoting the lowest price. The total expenditure for all purposes, including freight, should not exceed your estimate of $500.

After the purchase of the lumber, tools and other equipment has been made, you should forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred. You should state on the face of the vouchers that payment is to be made from B.C. Special Appropriation.

I shall be pleased if you will give the matter of the purchase of the materials and tools required early attention, in order that manual training instructions for the pupils can begin as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

EXTRACT from Inspector Barry's Report on his inspection of the SECHELT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL on April 19th, 20th and 21st, 1932.

Original on File 167-18-6.

Vocational Training:

A Manual Training shop 45 ft. by 25 ft. has been partly fitted up. There are six double benches, and 12 small sets of tools. There does not appear to be a set of tools for the teacher. There are 12 boys taking the course, and they work on two afternoons per week from 2 P.M. to 4 P.M. The teacher is Mr. Tebb, who is a local boat builder and a carpenter contractor. He was foreman of works when the Residential School was built. The boys are making models, tables, etc. They appear to be much interested in the work. I saw these boys at work.

This class under its instructor have lined the walls of an old building and put up part of a shiplap ceiling. They did not have a sufficient supply of shiplap to finish the job. In addition the roof of the building requires to be reshingled.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a request from the Reverend Principal of Sechelt Residential School for manual training supplies. The total amount of the requisition will be under $25.00.

This manual training class is making excellent progress and Mr. Tebb, the instructor, is a distinct success in instruction. The pupils are keenly interested and as Mr. Tebb is a practical man, the Indians will learn something which should prove very useful to them later on.

I respectfully recommend that this requisition be favourably considered.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 167-18-11, I beg to answer—

The work accomplished by the manual training classes from Nov. 1st 1931 to March 1st 1934.

The work accomplished was as follows, in the building allotted for a workshop, four new windows and frames have been made and installed, thereby giving the classroom sufficient light. The walls and part of the ceiling has been lined with shiplap, thereby adding warmth to the shop. Six work benches (double) have been built with bench screws and tool racks; these supply accommodation for a class of twelve students.

Lockers with twelve compartments, for accommodation of the students' tools and drawings, have been built.

On the first of January we commenced work on the different methods of joining wood together in model form, to give the students both practice and insight into the modes of joining before taking up construction.
Sechelt Residential School

SECHELT, B.C.

The mode of procedure adopted is for the instructor to draw the model either full size or to scale from this student makes a working drawing, afterwards constructing the model from the drawing prepared by himself.

Each student is being instructed in the care of and art of sharpening his tools.

I am pleased to say that a great improvement in the quality of the work done has been effected this year; carelessness is being reduced and more personal pride taken in the work. My belief is that interest and attention of the entire class are very good.

Now all these Boys after school will have to earn their living mostly by fishing. My wish is that these Boys should be trained in boat building and for this kind of work we have in the actual Instructor the boatman to be had, as by trade he is Boat builder. To attain this Object, the school should be equipped with proper tools, material for boat building.

So I am convinced that money spent by the Dept is well spent.
Sechelt Residential School

While the heavy pieces are passed through the washing machine—pieces such as sheets, blankets, overalls, towels, etc.—there is a great deal of handwashing done by the girls. On this I insisted and still insist on this particular point.

Handwashing—ironing of the clothes, pressing, cleaning is all done entirely by hand.

Sewing room—The work accomplished there is quite satisfactory. The girls have made their dresses and are making sweaters, night shirts for boys and girls, overshirts for boys.

Blouses—Mending—patching work—more actual knitting such things as sweaters, stockings, socks. Has been neglected and brought this point to the attention of the Sister in charge.

Kitchen—The work here has not been as I had wished it—not enough training in the actual demonstration of the art of cooking—no bread made. So, girls on their leaving the school could scrub floors and pots, prepare vegetables but not cook.

Rev. Ed. Maillard
Principal
Sechelt Residential School
Sechelt, B.C.

M. R. A. Tebb, Manual instructor

Dear Sir,

I wish to say that I am greatly pleased with the progress which has been made. Such practical evidence of the services being given in pursuit of our educational program should surely convince the Dept. that these efforts along manual training lines are worth while, especially when the work is conducted under the direction of men who are not only qualified to instruct but also able to give such evidence of their sympathetic consideration for the advancement of the Indian children as you are doing. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo with reference to the letter of the Principal of the Sechelt Residential School regarding the instruction of the boys in boat building. This matter was the subject of a discussion recently between the manual training instructor, Mr. Tebb, the Reverend Principal and myself and after looking into it thoroughly I was preparing to report to you.

I believe I have already mentioned that before Mr. Tebb's retirement from active business he was in the boat building line, his yard employing as many as three hundred men, and is well qualified to instruct in that work. When he was first engaged as manual training instructor I asked him if he would be able to teach the boys boat-building and he said that as they had had no previous training, it would be a year or two before he considered them proficient enough in the use of tools. However, they have shown remarkable ability generally and Mr. Tebb considers they could now be given boat-building instruction in the advanced classes. This would mean possibly eight or ten boys at Sechelt School.

I had in mind that possibly we could take advantage of Mr. Tebb's services by sending pupils from other schools to take this instruction, or better still have a special boat-building school at some central point where the senior boys of other schools could all receive instruction. There is no question that this is work for which the Indians are peculiarly suitable, and the trade now going to Japanese boat-builders might well become the main Indian employment at the Coast as quite a number of Indians have taken up marine engineering.

Manual training instruction is the most valuable teaching they receive but so far it has apparently been confined mostly to making furniture or small articles which are also factory made, and therefore the Indians can not compete in the market for that class of goods.

In this report I am only suggesting for the Department's consideration the establishment of a separate boat-building school as I realize the many angles which would need careful thought, but as regards Sechelt School we should first need a boat-house near the beach, proper tools and suitable material. Mr. Tebb suggested that the boys make a 45-foot hull, fishboat type, of fir and cedar.

to commence with. This would take possibly four school terms at the present hours and small number of boys available. A few tools will be needed in addition to those on hand at present. The lumber in a boat of this size would cost about $400.00 but of course would not all be needed at once. You are correct in your premise that this lumber is in addition to that needed in the usual way as recommended by School Inspector Barry and I am enclosing herewith Mr.Tebb's list of present lumber requirements.

With regard to the boat building, we are now midway in the last term before the school holidays and I respectfully suggest that this work be commenced when school re-opens in August. That will give me time to submit to you a detailed plan rather than send immature suggestions now.

In 1925 the Department paid $680.00 for a launch supplied to this School and a boat-house was built which is still in a fair state of repair and could be easily fixed up for the purpose. I understand the boat was never taken care of and they allowed it to be pounded to pieces on the beach shortly after it was supplied and they therefore have no further use for the boat-house. Your file 157-18-5, August 18, 1925, refers to this building.

I hope the Department will not think I am delaying this work, but by looking ahead now, we may save trouble and disappointment later.

A point I wish to bring to your notice and which is often overlooked when comparing the manual training work of different schools is that we have no machinery in the schools of this Agency, all work being done by hand which I believe is more valuable training because while the Indian is going to work in a town he will not have machinery available. That is the reason I mentioned that it would take probably four terms to build a small boat. It is the instruction that is valuable rather than the article produced.

With your approval therefore, I will again confer with Mr.Tebb and then forward you a complete list of boat-building requirements which he has already assured me will not be large.

Rev. Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a telegram from Rev. Father Scannell with reference to Mr. A. R. Tebb, Manual Training Instructor at the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

Mr. Tebb was appointed by the Department and is paid by the Department. Consequently, he is in a different position from the other members of the staff. It was for this reason, no doubt, that Mr. Ball advised you that Mr. Tebb's services should be retained.

If the Manual Training Instructor's services are unsatisfactory, you should have so reported to the Department, giving your reasons for desiring a change, and, at the same time, giving the name and qualifications of the person whom you wish employed.

If you communicate with the Department along the lines suggested in the preceding paragraph, the matter will receive careful consideration. A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Mr. Agent Ball.

When Mr. Phelan was in British Columbia recently, I mentioned to him that the Rev. Father Fahlman, the new Principal at Sechelt Residential School, had written the manual training instructor asking for his resignation. This was in line with Father Fahlman's action with all the staff. I understood Mr. Phelan to say he would advise Father Fahlman that Mr. Tebb's appointment was made by Order-in-council, but apparently Mr. Phelan did not do so.

I asked Father Fahlman whether he had any complaint against Mr. Tebb and apparently there is none. Mr. Tebb's work at both Sechelt and Squamish Schools has been most satisfactory, and I do not think he should be dismissed merely because Father Fahlman is discharging all his own staff, including the Sister who has been there since the School opened many years ago.

Sechelt School in my opinion was very efficiently run, and the standard of work done by the pupils was high so this wholesale dismissal of the staff is not understandable.

Dear Sir:

The thought and consideration due the matter of your letter of the 15th inst., required much time and resulted in this regretted delay. In reply may I state that a copy of the telegram sent the Department by very Rev. Father Scannell has come to me, and I heartily endorse the opening sentence. I feel that the principle of the Principal's authority is at stake.

When, for reasons which I shall hereinafter mention, I discharged Mr. Tebb, not knowing that he had been appointed in any other manner than any other member of the School Staff, I was acting just as I had acted formerly in discharging members of the Staff of this School and of St. Mary's Mission School when I was Principal there, and among those thus discharged there were some whose salary was paid by the Department in just the same way as Mr. Tebb's has been paid. That the position of Mr. Tebb should be different from the other members of the Staff is what I most heartily disagree with. It necessitates my giving way to what I cannot regard as being in the best interests of the School of which I am Principal. Now to be obliged to retain the services of one who is known by the other members of the Staff to have been discharged by me is bound to affect my authority very adversely. Furthermore, for me to reinstate Mr. Tebb now in view of his letter to me which was anything but respectful, nay, redolent of open defiance, would render my position quite untenable.

My reasons for discharging Mr. Tebb are briefly these:
1; He lacks authority over the children who make up his class; he has admitted that they do not work well for him.
2; He has overstepped his authority in some instances.
3; He has failed without apparent good reason or any explanation to comply with requests I have made in connection with the Manual Training Department of the School.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 31st ultimo regarding the Manual Training Instructor at Sechelt School, the last sentence in the same is not understood.

It will be difficult to replace Mr. Tebb under the arrangements now in existence. He instructs one day a week at Squamish School which involves three days' travel at his expense. His work at both places is most satisfactory. He is an expert boat-builder which is the principal work to be done in my estimation. There has never been any question as to his competence to instruct and undoubtedly the Reverend Principal merely desires to bring in some one from outside the district as has been done in the boiler room where his young nephew replaced the former man. The position is inside the School and no objection was made although I believe the new man has no papers as an engineer, but the manual training is separate from the school and classes are held in another building.

The whole trouble I have no doubt is because Mr. Tebb refused to allow the young man referred to, and other employees of the School, to use manual training tools whenever they wished, and it was upon my instructions they were forbidden to remove these tools. If we are to have no control in such matters, I can not be held responsible if in a short time we have to replace the manual training tools at large expense.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir,

re: Your File No.167-18-11

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st ultimo, and note that you have decided to get rid of Mr. Tebb as Manual Training Instructor at Sechelt Residential School.

I think the Department is making a mistake in this matter, and it is very disheartening that an Agent is not supported. Father Fahlman is new to the work and has yet to show that he is going to make a success of the School - so far the reverse is indicated. Already I am receiving complaints that the children are not being fed nearly so well as formerly; the Agent soon notice it and report it to their parents. Apart from that, Mr. Tebb was recommended because of his peculiar fitness for instruction, especially in boat-building, which is the main thing in training up. He formerly had as many as 50 men working under him in ship and boat building so he knows considerably more than the Principal about his work. Sechelt is a small community, and it will be interesting to see who Father Fahlman has in mind as instructor. He dismissed the Sisters and the boiler-room fireman (an old and faithful Frenchman, with a family, who had been there a long time) and put his young nephew in his place.

These changes are not being made for efficiency reasons, but to satisfy personal inclinations. If Mr. Tebb's services were not satisfactory, I should quickly report it to you, but no man's work should be dependent upon personalities of this kind. I do not think there are any strained relations at all; Father Fahlman simply ceased sending any pupils to the Manual Training Building, without giving any reasons except that he was "making changes in the staff". Tebb is scarcely a member of the staff, he goes to the school one day a week, and never enters the main school building.

If the Department wishes any more information, I may add that this trouble started because Tebb refused to allow the young nephew referred to, to use the Manual Training tools for odd jobs.

If this young fellow is appointed instructor, so that the amount paid quarterly to Tebb is paid to him, I hope the Department will ask for his qualifications, if the Department still has any control in these matters of personnel.

It is becoming rather obscure as to what an Indian Agent's duties are regarding Residential Schools. Sechelt School was worked up to a high state of efficiency, cleanli-

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the action taken by the Principal of the Sechelt Indian Residential School in dispensing with the services of Mr. Tebb as manual training instructor.

The Department has given careful consideration to this matter, and, as you were informed in official letter of the 31st ultimo, it is considered that the present relations between the Principal and Mr. Tebb are strained. It would be in the best interests of the work to make a change. While Mr. Tebb's services have been entirely satisfactory, our experience shows that, when there is dissatisfaction between the Principal and any member of the staff, it is necessary, in the interests of the work, to make a change. The Department is, therefore, of opinion that, in order to have the work continue without friction between the Principal and Mr. Tebb, the services of a new manual training instructor should be obtained. You will therefore be good enough to inform Mr. Tebb that his services as manual training instructor at the Sechelt School will not be required after December 31st, next. It is presumed he will be willing to continue the work until that date.

You should request the Principal to forward the name and full particulars regarding the qualifications and experience of the man he nominates for the position, to succeed Mr. Tebb. You should inform him that the Department will be unable to approve of the appointment of any person who has not the necessary qualifications. The Principal should make a nomination, through your office, at an early date.

It is understood that Mr. Tebb's services are to be continued as manual training instructor at the Squamish Indian Residential School.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th instant regarding the manual training instructions at Sechelt Residential School, and to enclose here-with a voucher for $75.00 in Mr. Tebb's favour. He reported every day on which classes should have been held, this meant a three-mile walk and loss of at least half a day, and this amount represents one-half the amount he should have earned. After losing this time, the Reverend Principal commenced sending classes to him again, and asked him to give extra instruction so as to catch up on lost time.

With regard to your enquiry as to nomination of a successor, I have repeatedly asked for this, so far without success. I shall make further enquiry and report later. My opinion is, as mentioned in a previous letter, that the Reverend Principal proposed having his nephew, the boiler-room man, do this work, but since a qualified man is required, he, of course, cannot be nominated.

Personally I think it will be difficult to find another man in such a small community as Sechelt; in fact, I know there is no one who can teach boat-building which I expected to become the chief aim of the instruction so that these pupils could learn to build their own fish boats instead of buying them from the Japanese.

This whole scheme has been wrecked by petty interference. I asked the Reverend Principal recently what friction there had been between himself and Mr. Tebb, and he said there was no friction, but he thought Mr. Tebb could not control the boys. This has never been mentioned before, and I do not see how such a complaint could be made from my observation of the manual training class-rooms both at Sechelt and Squamish.

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Mr. Agent Ball, in which he states that you have requested him to forward vouchers covering the manual training grant for the December quarter for Mr. Morley, whom you have employed as manual training instructor.

In official letter of November 15th, Mr. Ball was directed to request you to forward the name and full particulars regarding the qualifications and the experience of the man you nominated for the position of manual training instructor. No doubt, Mr. Ball conveyed the Department's instructions to you; but, as yet, no such information has been received. I also quote, for your information, the last paragraph of official letter of November 15th, addressed to Very Rev. J. Scannell, O.M.I.:

"The Agent is being requested to have the Principal nominate the services of a fully qualified instructor, to replace Mr. Tebb after December 31st. The Department will expect that the person nominated by the Principal will have the necessary qualifications and experience."

In his recent letter, Mr. Ball writes regarding Mr. Morley:

"He is a commercial artist by trade, not a carpenter or boat builder, and his only experience has been in helping his father build a few summer cottages."

In view of Mr. Ball's report, the Department does not consider that Mr. Morley has sufficient qualifications to act as manual training instructor of the Sechelt Indian Residential School, and, consequently, we are not prepared to allow a grant to the school for his services.

As stated in previous correspondence, the Department is quite prepared to allow you to nominate the manual training instructor, but we must insist that the man nominated by you holds the requisite qualifications and has had the necessary experience. Otherwise, the expenditure of public funds for the purpose will be wasted. I regret that Mr. Agent Ball is under the impression that you do not wish to cooperate with him in fulfilling the Department's principle of Indian residential schools to do. The best results can only be obtained by all our officers working in harmony.

Yours truly,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a requisition for material for the manual training department of the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

This material, it will be noticed, is for making articles which are rather under the classification of cabinet making. It is regretted that the more useful and important training, viz, boat-building, has been dropped since the change was made in instructors.

Our Indians up coast are primarily fishermen, and while cabinet-making gives a good impression in the class-room, and, of course, teaches the pupils the use of tools, their instruction should be along the lines of boat-building, and repairing, which will be useful after they leave school. I have been over-ruled in this, but still consider I am right.

The requisition is submitted for your approval.

I have the honour to be Sir,

Sir:

I am in receipt of the attached account from Marshall-Wells B. C. Limited.

A similar account was forwarded from your office under cover of your voucher #9597 of May 1938. The item of $12.75 covering the cost of 50 lbs. ¼" galvanized chain had been deleted when it reached here. This reduced the account to an amount of $11.56. You also attached an account of $1.71, dated May 4, 1938, for some supplies for the Sechelt School. This account showed that it was subject to a discount of 2½% and we deducted 3¢, making the net amount $1.68.

Adding the amount of $11.56 and $1.68, gave an amount of $13.24. Cheque #43034 for this amount was issued and sent to the Company on June 25, 1938.

We are also in receipt of your voucher #9595 for $102.66. This amount includes an account of $12.75 for galvanized chain fence. Apparently it is the item that you previously deleted from the old account. A cheque for the latter account has not yet been forwarded to the Company, but will go forward in the near future.

Under the circumstances, I am enclosing the account Marshall-Wells B. C. Limited recently forwarded to us, and you should interview the Company and straighten out the matter.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division

Sir:

I beg to advise that the Reverend Principal of Sechelt Residential School has applied for the manual training instructor, Mr. Morley, to be placed on full time at the school so that he can do carpentry and other work around the school premises. At present he is paid $8.00 per day for classes held, averaging $60.00 per month. There are approximately forty boys at the school, the primary classes not receiving manual training instruction.

While Mr. Morley's services as manual training instructor are satisfactory to the school, it will be recalled that I objected to his employment because he was not qualified to instruct in boat-building, which in my opinion is important for coast Indians. Mr. Morley is no doubt useful in repair work around the school, staff houses, barns and other buildings. Whether this can be included in his work as manual training instructor is for the Department to decide.

The Reverend Principal, Father Cornell, has done excellent work in bringing this school to its present high standard in so short a time.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C. Ball]

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 10th instant with reference to the manual training instructor at the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

As you are no doubt aware this man's salary is paid from the B.C. Special Appropriation which is intended for special expenditures. It would not be possible to consider paying Mr. Morley a salary from this Appropriation for doing minor repair work at the school as services of this nature should be supplied by the school staff. Under these circumstances it is not possible for the Department to favourably consider the request of the Reverend Principal of the Sechelt Residential School.

I have carefully noted the contents of the second paragraph of your letter but in view of the fact that Mr. Morley's services have been satisfactory along certain lines at least, and as the new school year is rapidly approaching, I do not consider it advisable to make any change at the present time.

However, the Reverend Principal and yourself should, during the coming school year, make inquiries with a view to recommending for the Department's consideration for the school year 1939-40 a manual training instructor who would be competent to do boat building and boat repairing.

Yours truly,

F.J.C. Ball, Esq.,

Sir,

File 167-18-11

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd ultimo advising me that Mr. Morley, manual training instructor at Sechelt Indian Residential School cannot be given full time employment. I have discussed this further with the school, and I am advised that Mr. Morley is working only 5 hours per week or $2½ each term for $150. This is $2.40 per hour. I do not know what hours the Department requires, but $2.40 appears to be too high for the work he is doing.

As previous correspondence at the time of his appointment contains full particulars, I do not feel that I should again raise the issue. Under Mr. Morley the pupils are doing good work of the type in which they are instructed, such as making desks, tables, cedar-chests etc., but I think he should work three times as many hours for the same money, or at the rate of 80¢ per hour, the rate most carpenters receive. Possibly this extra time would cover the Reverend Principal's request for a full time instructor.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F. J. C. Ball]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,

Dear Sir:

Your File 167-18-11.

I have to refer to Mr. Hosey's letter of the 6th ultimo in the matter of the appointment of Mr. E. J. Henderson as Manual Training Instructor at Sechelt Indian Residential School.

The question of procedure in such appointments was discussed with Inspector Barry, and I quote hereunder excerpts from his report to me regarding same:

"Manual Training is part of the curriculum in almost all of our Indian Residential Schools in B.C. Manual Training Instructors are appointed, as are all other members of the school staff, by the Principal of the school, without any particular reference of the matter either direct to Ottawa or indirectly through your own office.

"Ever since my own appointment as Inspector of Schools and probably for years before that it has been understood that while the appointment of the Principal of an Indian Residential School, on the nomination of the Church concerned, is subject to the final approval of the Department in Ottawa, the appointment of members of the school staff in these schools is a matter for the Principal alone. It is true that when a member of the school staff is reported on adversely the Department has as a general rule upheld my own findings and requested the Principal to make a change to remedy the adverse conditions reported on by me. This in no way invalidates the general rule that the Principal is alone responsible for appointments to and dismissals from his staff."

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

In .....
"In conclusion I may say for the information of the Department that I was not informed of the vacancy for a Manual Training Instructor at Sechelt. I know nothing of the qualifications of Mr. R.J. Henderson of Vancouver though I have on file particulars of a Mr. R. Henderson, Manual Training Instructor, of Vancouver, and for some time at St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, who would be quite unsuitable for the Sechelt appointment.

"Under the circumstances I would recommend that the Reverend Principal of the Sechelt Indian Residential School be permitted to exercise his undoubted privilege in appointing a Manual Training Instructor of his own choice. I do not consider that the Department should go on record at this stage and in any way restrict the actions of the Reverend Principal.

"When the Sechelt Indian Residential School is next inspected, and this will be before Christmas if I can manage it, a full report will of course be made on the Manual Training.

"Should my report on the above training be adverse the Department would no doubt take steps to have the school authorities make a change in the staff."

The Reverend Principal of Sechelt School in engaging Mr. Henderson was simply exercising a right which has been recognized and approved by the Department for many years and which applies in all our Indian Residential Schools in British Columbia.

Inspector Barry will report on Mr. Henderson's work as Manual Training Instructor, following the forthcoming inspection of Sechelt Residential School.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C."

Dear Sir:

I beg to refer to your letter of October 19th authorizing the purchase of lumber and equipment for the Manual Training Division of the Sechelt Indian Residential School. The application for these materials was made by the Reverend Principal of the School and was endorsed and forwarded direct to the Department by Mr. Indian Agent Bell.

The requisition calls for a large quantity of hardwoods and I doubt if the Department took into consideration the costs involved when the application was approved. Quotations have been received for all the soft woods and about one-quarter of some of the hard woods applied for, and the lowest estimate received was $345.64. The tools and hardware will cost approximately $113.00 so that the total cost with a considerable reduction in the amount of the hard woods would be approximately $460.00.

I think it is a mistake to purchase expensive hard woods for the Manual Training Division of our Schools. The Indians will not have these woods available to them on their Reserves, and I am satisfied that if they are trained to work with the native woods of the Province that the aim of such training will be met equally as well as if expensive hard woods were used. Before placing the order I should appreciate your further instructions in this matter.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I beg to request advice upon a matter which has been brought up by the Principal of Sechelt Residential School. He is a manual-training instructor working part-time at the school, on a salary of $50.00 per month, eligible for compensation under the Dominion Government Workmen's Compensation Act as administered by the Provincial Government Board. Chapter 30 of the 1920 statutes and amendment of 1931 appears to cover it, but I have not heard of any claims having been made.

I think the question was raised because a manual-training instructor, appointed by the school authorities without reference to us, and who was discharged by the Reverend Principal in threatening suit under the Minimum Wage Act because the school offered, and he accepted odd-job work at the same salary for two months when the school was closed. The Reverend Principal is now perplexed because he thought such statutes as the Minimum Wage and Workmen's Compensation Acts did not apply to the school, and in case of injury to the manual trainer, he is afraid the school would have to pay him compensation.

Personally I consider he would be covered by the Dominion Government Workmen's Compensation Act, but I would be glad of your advice so that the Reverend Principal may rest assured on that point.

With regard to the Minimum Wage Act, we are not concerned in this case as the man was not employed by the Department whilst school was closed.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C. Ball]

September 26, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to your communication of August 23, in which you ask to be advised whether a manual training instructor working part time at the Sechelt Residential School on a salary of $50.00 a month would be eligible for compensation under the Dominion Government Workmen's Compensation Act as administered by the Provincial Government Board.

I note you state that the manual training instructor was appointed by the School authorities without reference to the Department and was later discharged by the Principal, and is now threatening suit under the Minimum Wage Act, because the School offered, and he accepted, odd job work at the same salary for two months when the school was closed.

Will you kindly advise me who paid the salary of $50.00 a month for the casual labour performed by the instructor. Also please advise me the name of the instructor and the dates he was employed.

Would you kindly forward me, if possible, a copy of the Workmen's Compensation Act for the Province of British Columbia, and a copy of the Minimum Wage Act.

Yours very truly,

F. J. C. Ball, Esq.,

CHAPTER 65.

An Act to amend the "Workmen's Compensation Act."

[Assented to 30th November, 1939.]

HIS MAJESTY, by and with the advice and consent of the Legislative Assembly of the Province of British Columbia, enacts as follows:

1. This Act may be cited as the "Workmen's Compensation Amendment Act, 1939."

2. Section 8 of the "Workmen's Compensation Act," being chapter 312 of the "Revised Statutes of British Columbia, 1936," is amended by striking out subsection (6), and substituting therefor the following:

"(6.) A workman who becomes disabled from uncomplicated silicosis or from silicosis complicated with tuberculosis on or after the first day of January, 1936, shall be entitled to compensation for total or partial disability as provided by this Part; and where death results from such disability the dependents of such workman shall be entitled to compensation as provided by this Part; but neither a workman nor his dependents shall be entitled to compensation for such disability or death unless the workman:

"(a.) Has been a resident of this Province for a period of at least three years last preceding his disablement; and

"(b.) Was free from silicosis and tuberculosis before being first exposed to dust containing silica in the metalliferous-mining industry in this Province; and

"(c.) Has been a workman exposed to dust containing silica in the metalliferous-mining industry in this Province."
for a period or periods aggregating three years preceding his disablement; and

'(d.) Has been a workman in the metalliferous-mining industry in this Province for at least three months in the five years last preceding his disablement; and

'(e.) Has filed a claim for compensation while employed in the metalliferous-mining industry in this Province, or within five years after the date of leaving such employment in this Province, and in any case within one year after the date on which he became disabled:

Sir:

re: File No.167-18-11

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo and to enclose herewith copy of the Workmen's Compensation Act as requested.

The new Principal at Sechelt Indian Residential School advised me that he made a settlement with the Manual Training Instructor, whose name is Stanton, rather than have any publicity about it, but did not tell me what he settled for, and he has been replaced by a Mr. O'Grady, brother of Rev. Father O'Grady, so there will be no similar difficulties with him.

Originally the Manual Training Instructor was an outside man who went to the School for the requisite number of hours per month. This was a clear-cut arrangement leaving no doubt or ambiguity as to his duties. When Rev. Fr. Fahlman was made Principal he changed the system, dismissing the instructor and employing another man who did other work around the school, for which they paid him extra wages, in addition to board and room, from the school grant. I do not think this system is altogether satisfactory, but it has apparently been approved by the Department.

There are two ways of viewing the matter. The School authorities say the boys get practical instruction when repairing buildings or erecting chickenhouses, tool sheds, stables, etc., and this is more valuable than purely instructional work in the class room. On the other hand, the pupils do not receive the individual instruction in fine workmanship and use of tools while working on practical jobs. In the class room they usually make tables, writing desks, ornamental boxes, chairs, etc., where joints, etc., have to be exact, whereas in the practical work the idea is to get the job done as quickly as possible. The ideal instruction, of course, would be a combination of the two.

My personal view, which counts for nothing nowadays, is that the most valuable instruction our Coast pupils can receive in manual training is in boat-building, but they receive none. There are boat at Sechelt School built by the pupils under a former instructor, but the past few instructors could not build boats. In some Agencies, the Indians compete with the Japanese in boat-building, and the School is the proper place to start instruction in this craft. I know of nothing more valuable to Indians from fishing communities than building their own boats. However, this is beside the point in question, which has apparently been settled, and the Reverend Principal does not want it discussed further.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa,
February 20, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant with reference to our manual training programme.

The manual training programme which we are trying this year is only being used in the residential schools in the Province of Alberta. We are obtaining monthly reports on these schools and are checking them very closely so that we can ascertain if any adjustments in the programme are necessary in order to make it as effective as possible. It is not our intention to extend the programme this year to the schools in any other parts of the Dominion. Under these circumstances we do not consider it advisable to request you to follow our programme at present. Manual training work has been carried out at the Sechelt School for several years and I feel certain that reasonable progress is being made. At the end of the current academic year we intend to give the whole matter very careful consideration and decide at that time to what other provinces we will extend the programme for the academic year 1942-43.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 11th instant, the Department approves purchase of manual training tools to a value of $460 for the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

As mentioned in my letter of February 7, regarding manual training equipment for the Kamloops School, the Department does not favour, at the present time, supplying power tools and consequently the tools in this class should not be secured for the Sechelt School.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B. C.

re: File No. 215-14-1534

Replying to your letter of the 24th instant advising me that the Department refuses to supply certain power tools to Sechelt Indian Residential School for manual training, I had the same opinion until recently - viz. that the boys would not have power tools on their Reserves; however, on several occasions lately, employers at mills and small boat-building places have told me that Indian employees do not know how to use such tools and have to be taught before they can expect to earn wages. That is an angle which I had overlooked and possibly it has not occurred to the Department.

Perhaps if this was mentioned to them, they might reconsider their decision, although they will probably not entertain any such suggestion from a mere field man.

B/DH.

Indian Agent
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I would refer to your letter of the 17th instant, file 167-18-11, advising that the Department does not favour, at the present time, supplying power tools for Sechelt Indian Residential School.

In this connection, I enclose herewith for your information Mr. Indian Agent Ball's letter of the 25th instant advising that the lack of knowledge of handling such tools by Indians at the coast is necessitating their being trained to do so by industries in which they are being employed.

In the absence of Commissioner MacKay, the writer would advise that there may be some misunderstanding of the type of Indians who are being trained in our Residential Schools at the coast and it is thought that the enclosed photographs taken in connection with my inspection of the Cowichan Agency in 1942 may be of interest in this connection. One of these will show the Chief of the Esquimalt Reserve outside his boathouse standing beside a bandsaw which he has improvised from Ford truck wheels and using an old car engine for power. At the time of my visit the Chief was repairing a very large boat of the tug type for a white concern, this involving the use of heavy sawn timbers, mostly curved. It will be noticed from the photograph that the Chief is quite an old man and not the young ex-pupil type that would be expected to require such power tools. Indians up and down the coast are beginning to find the advantage of such machinery.

(over)
I also enclose photographs of some typical homes in the Cowichan Agency, which is not by any means outstanding on the coast in this respect, which would indicate that these Indians are rapidly passing the whipsaw stage.

The foregoing is not in any way intended to minimize the necessity of young Indians being thoroughly instructed in the use of hand tools.

For D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF F. S. Calvert, Provincial School Inspector, following his inspection of the SECHELT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL - Feb. 21-22, 1945.

Original on 167-18-6

Vocational Training

Provision has been made for boys to receive instruction in woodwork. Some good pieces of machinery, such as a turning lathe, band-saw, etc., have been installed recently. There is a good supply of saws, planes, and other tools. The equipment in this respect is quite good. The work benches are rather crude.

This work is carried on in an upstairs room which is far from satisfactory. A modern industrial arts room on the ground floor should be provided. These boys should be given instruction in boat-building, boat-repairing, forging, and metal work. Such training would be of great value to these boys after they leave school.

The young man who was in charge of this department and who appears to have done a good job was called to military service a few days ago.

A shoe-repairing department seems to be carrying on a good piece of practical work.

MEMORANDUM.

August 11, 1947

To: The Indian Commissioner for B.C.
From: Inspector of Indian Day Schools.

I refer to the requisition for manual training supplies for the Sechelt Residential School.

It is recommended that this requisition be approved with the exception of the following items:

1 only pipe wrench 14"
1 only set pipe dies ½"
1 only power grinder
1 only electric drill

It is felt that the tools for pipe fitting should come under "School Maintenance" rather than "Manual Training".

It is also felt that the expense of supplying a power grinder and electric drill for the few pupils who will be taking woodwork is not justified.

R.F. Davey
District Inspector of Indian Schools.

I am in receipt of a request from
the Reverend Principal of the Sechelt Indian Residential
School for a $10.00 per month increase in the grant allowed
by the Department towards the salary of a manual training
instructor.

Present grant is $50.00 per month.
I understand that similar grants to other Residential Schools
are up to $75.00 per month.

At the above School there is no one on
the permanent school staff to give instruction in manual train-
ing.

The only carpenter available resides
at some distance from the School. His transportation costs
$12.00 monthly, which he is unwilling to pay from his salary
of $50.00 monthly.

The instruction given is satisfactory
and it is very difficult to obtain the services of a competent
instructor at the salary paid.

I would recommend that every considera-
tion be given to the request for an increase.

To quote an example from among many, this year we were granted $250. for equipment. I requested among other things that out of this sum one electric motor be provided for the manual training shop. The motor was to cost $45. As my duties as principal require my presence in the school twenty four hours daily, I feel, that at least geographically, I am in a better position to state what things are most useful in the school than one, let us say, who lives 3000 miles away and has never even seen the inside of the school! Yet, this request was flatly refused although this motor was to be used for the operation of equipment already supplied by the Department. What utter nonsense is this!!
Mr. H.E. Taylor, Supt. Indian Agency, Vancouver, wrote on 18 September, 1943, as follows:

Requesting equipment -

One 1/3 H.P. electric motor at $36.00 for operating power equipment used in manual training instruction.

Department of Indian Affairs.

To whom it may concern,

Dear Sir,

I, Mr. A.C. Pate, am Manual Training Instructor for Skeetch Indian Residential School, under Rev. Zachariah Dunlop, O.M.I., Principal.

I am informing you, Sir, on my failure to receive the monthly checks, you pay me for this work.

When I took over this job, I was informed that the salary was $60.00 per month, payable on the 15th of each following month. I.E. September salary paid on October 15th and so on. As per these agreements I took over the job.
I have done this work for three and one half (3½) months now Sir. I received payment for the month of September on the twelfth (12th) of November, and since then have not received payment at all. You owe me for October and November.

I surely don't have to point out the impossibility of living on sixty dollars ($60.00) for three or four months! Can you do it? I'm sure that neither you nor any of your staff, if they had to wait three months for their salary, would like it.

I don't wish to write you a nasty letter Sir, but surely your department can do better than you've done. If you expect me to keep my agreements surely you can keep yours.

This is the first time I have "squawked," don't you think mine is reasonable. I wish to be paid according to my agreements, not 3 or 4 months later.

If you were in my position wouldn't you be annoyed and quite a little angry at
such a state of affairs.

I hope you will soon inform me that this situation has been adjusted.

Thank you. "Sir"

October 6th, 1949.

Mr. H. E. Taylor,
Indian Superintendent,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Mr. Taylor:

It has been necessary for me to engage a new manual Training Instructor and to greatly increase his salary. The Department at present allows a grant of $60.00 per month towards this salary. Could this possibly be increased to $85.00. I am doing everything possible to hold this present instructor because he is eminently satisfactory but the wage consideration is quite a hardship. Mr. Rositch is a married man, a very good carpenter, an all round handy man and is able to assist considerably in teaching the boys the guitar, accordion etc. More than any other consideration, the boys have taken or shown an attitude of respect and cooperation towards him. The Department can be assured of very capable handling of the boys by further assisting us to pay the necessary adequate wage.

Yours very truly,

L. Viney, O.M.I.
Principal.
W. S. Arneil, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Vancouver, B.C.

October 11, 1949.

I enclose copies of a letter from the Principal of the Sechelt Indian Residential School requesting an increase in the grant for the Manual Training Instructor.

It is difficult to obtain suitable craftsmen as instructors and wages have risen considerably, so that it is necessary to make the position attractive.

I would recommend consideration of the requested grant increase.

(H. E. Taylor)
Indian Superintendent.

EXTRACT from Report of G. H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools, regarding his inspection of the SECHELT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL on May 19 & 20, 1931.

Original on File 167-18-6.

Stock:

1 Horse (16 years old).
2 Cows (Old) These give very little milk, at present about one gallon per day.
About 90 chickens, Wyandotte, Barred Rocks, and Leghorns. Many of these are dying. The chicken houses on Indian Reserve lands are old and I consider full of disease, lice, etc. Many of the chickens are, I believe, suffering from white diarrhea. The only thing that could be done in this case is to build new houses for the small chickens and to burn the old houses. Many of the old birds should be killed.

Milk is bought in the form of fresh cream. Water is added. Twenty-five pounds of this cream are bought per week. I am informed that the children get over one cup of this milk per day. Eggs are also bought to the extent of a case (30 dozen) per week.

All the feed has to be bought for the cows. They use one ton of hay per month, with straw and oats in addition. The hay costs $26 per ton, with an extra $4.50 for freight.
Sir:

I beg to advise that the Sechelt Residential School is having difficulty in obtaining an adequate supply of milk for the pupils. The boat leaves Vancouver three times a week but there is a break from Friday to Tuesday and in the soft climate at Sechelt, milk does not keep. The Principal, Rev. F. Maillard, says they have two cows, one a fairly good milker but the other is fifteen years old and is poor. He has requested me to write you and inquire whether two Jersey cows could be supplied to the school. He would be able to feed them and there is a good barn on the premises. There are many Jersey herds in the Fraser Valley from which a selection could be made at a reasonable price.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the milk supply at the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to state that the Department will provide one milch cow if the school authorities will provide the other. Our funds are so limited that I cannot authorize accounts for both cows being forwarded to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

There are only two cows at this school. Neither of them is of much use. They do not give more than a total of two gallons per day between them. They are very old Jersey-Holstein grades. One of them is hopeless. It is useless to send cows here as there is no place to find food for them. They would have to be stall fed.

The old horse mentioned in my report under the heading "Stock" last year, died and was replaced by the purchase of a horse and the necessary harness at a cost of $147.50. I have the honour to request that the Department will consider the question of refunding this sum to the school.

Stock:- 1 Horse, 2 Cows (Old) These give very little milk and are not worth keeping. It is very doubtful if any cows could be kept at this school with profit, as hay costs $26.00 per ton, with $4.50 freight, and 50¢ wharfage at Sechelt. Milk is bought in the form of fresh cream, as mentioned above. The children get at least a cup of fresh milk daily. Eggs are bought to the extent of 30 dozen per week. There are now about 50 chickens at the school. As reported last year, these are dying off. They are kept in old chicken houses which are placed on the Indian Reserve lands close to the school. These houses are full of disease germs, and vermin. The only possible course to take would be to have these houses burned down, when all the chickens now housed here have either died or been killed off.

Dear Mr. Ball:

For some time we have felt the necessity for giving our boys training in gardening and general farming. The chief obstacle to the implementing of this plan is lack of workable land. When the School was first erected the Department set aside 4.4 acres for the school buildings. This is completely utilized now by the main building, playgrounds for boys and girls, Father's residence, barn capable of holding 10 cows, wood yard holding 200 cords, and one acre fenced off as a pasture for 5 cows.

Some 15 years ago the Department arranged with the Indians to cede to the School 10.6 acres of heavily wooded land. This property directly adjoins the original grant. An attempt was made at clearing this land about ½ acre being prepared and gardening attempted. Since then nothing has been done until this fall when we cleared, ploughed and harrowed 2 acres which will be ready for seeding this spring. An analysis of the soil has been made and recommendations given as how best to obtain a crop. A pipe line has been laid for irrigating.

At present we have engaged 6 Indians to cut the trees in line with the part cleared. During the coming summer we can stump this and so have approximately 5 acres ready for cultivation. The expense to do this work is reasonable, but to pay all of it out of the School grant places a heavy burden upon us. We know that the Department has always been favourable to the policy of teaching the children general farming so we are appealing to you to place our case before them as stated above.

Yours sincerely,

"E.J. Cornell" O.M.I.
Principal.
Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a copy of a letter received from the Reverend Principal of Sechelt Residential School.

Reverend Baxter has recently gone to Sechelt from Kamloops as vice-Principal, and is doing some general agricultural work there. He expects to clear this 10 acres and raise vegetables, and feed for his chickens.

The soil in the Sechelt district has never been considered good enough for agriculture, and will need heavily fertilizing to be productive. However, I should like to see Father Baxter encouraged in what he is trying to do.

Recently he has employed four or five adult Indians from the village, besides the pupils, and they have cleared about 1/2 acre as he states in his letter, and they have cut down the brush on another 5 acres. He has requested a grant of about $200.00 to be used for wages, and claims to have spent $300.00 in wages from their own grant.

If any money is available for this purpose, it will be beneficial to the School if they can grow at least part of their vegetable requirements. Rev. Father Cornell is quite successful in his operation of this School which has been rather a difficult school to manage in the past.

The Indian Commissioner, Major MacKay, visited the School recently and they applied to him for this assistance, but he told them to write me, so that I could forward it to you. He considers the School should be encouraged in this work.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Ball:

Our dairy cows here at the school are of mixed breed. As you know, our grain and hay must be shipped entirely from Vancouver. In our case, where our herd is of poor breed and consequently low in milk production it is very questionable whether it pays to keep a herd at all. On the other hand we must have fresh milk for the children. New four thoroughbred Jerseys would supply us with an abundance of good rich milk. But the price of thoroughbred cattle is quite high and it would be impossible to purchase them out of school funds. Would you, therefore, place before the department a request for assistance in establishing a thoroughbred herd for the school. A jersey herd would benefit the health of the children by the richness of its milk and also it would help to lower the operational costs of the school.

Yours truly,

H. F. Dunlop, O.M.I.
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I have received the enclosed letter from the Reverend Principal of Sechelt Residential School.

They usually have either 3 or 4 cows but they are poor grade stock. I suggested to the Reverend Principal that he should try to get better grade cows as it costs no more to feed good ones, but he considers they cannot be purchased from the school grant.

There has been a remarkable improvement at this school in the food supplied to the children. They have a flock of pure bred hens which enables the pupils to have a regular supply of eggs and each child receives fresh milk daily. They kill most of their own beef and pork, and there has been an entire absence of complaints, whereas formerly the Indians claimed their children had to be given additional food by their parents.

While it is too late to assist the school during the present fiscal year, I hope this request will be borne in mind during the coming year, as it would be money well spent.

Indian Agent

SECHELT B.C.

June 20th 1939.

F.J.C.Ball Esq.
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Mr. Ball:

In connection with the conversation we had with you concerning the procuring of Band Instruments for the School, I would like to make this written application for same. I believe that if we could receive a grant of $100.00 we could procure just about enough instruments to complete our Band. We already have two drums, two cornets, a baritone and a tenor which we got for about $80.00. We need two clarinets, a saxophone and a bass or trombone and I think we could get all these for $100.00 at the same place we got the others.

In one of our previous conversations you mentioned that you might be able to get us two outdoor drinking fountains like you provided at the North Vancouver School. If you can still get these for us, we would find them very useful.

Withing you the best of health and hoping to see you soon, I remain

Yours sincerely,

E.J.Cornell "O.M.I."
Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith copy of a letter received this morning from the Reverend Principal of Sechelt Residential School. The school has the nucleus of a band which gives the children much pleasure, and should be encouraged, as the confinement of Indian children in any institution, no matter how good, is foreign to their nature, and anything which will raise their spirits and keep them happy warrants favourable consideration. I hope the Department will be able to comply with the Reverend Principal's request.

With regard to the drinking fountains, these are a health measure. The two I recommended and placed in Squamish Residential School last year have been worth a great deal to them, and the Reverend Principal there is most grateful for them. The cost was $51.96 for the material, and the School supplied the labour. There would be a slight extra cost for freight and packing if they are supplied to Sechelt School, and if funds are available, I would recommend it as a health measure.

I have the honour to be,

[F.J.C.Bell]
Indian Agent.

July 16, 1945.

Mr. F. J. C. Ball,
Federal Bldg.,
Vancouver.

Dear Mr. Ball:

Last year, as you know, we organized a troop of BOY SCOUTS here at the school. The results of this project were extremely gratifying. The uniform - the emphasis on outdoor life appealed very strongly to our boys. As an aid in training children I could imagine no organization more suitable. The scout code of cleanliness of mind and body; its insistence on respect and courtesy; on honor and honesty; on providing for future contingencies are all qualities usually conspicuously absent in the Indian. I intend, therefore, to carry on with scouting in a more intensified manner during the coming term.

On the girl's side we have no organization of this kind. I should like very much to form a troop of GIRL GUIDES. However I am faced with an obstacle ever present in the smaller school, namely, a financial one. The scouts up to date have cost the school $100.00. Considering that there will be more than double the number of girls eligible for membership in the Guides this project would become a severe strain on the slender resources of this school. Would you, therefore, place before the department (B.C. Special Grant) a request for $250.00 to aid in the organizing of the GIRL GUIDES in this school. I assure you the valuable training the children will receive from this organization cannot be valued in dollars and cents.

As you understand the money will be spent in the purchase of uniforms and equipment. Perhaps it might seem that uniforms are not essential, but I am sure you will agree with me that they are, for they give the children a sense of unity and pride in their club and an ideal to live up to. Lord Baden Powell whose writing show that he possessed an insight into a child's nature far beyond the average man realized fully and acted upon it.

Yours very truly,

H. F. Dunlop,
Principal.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

I enclose herewith a request from Rev. H. F. Dunlop, O.M. I., for assistance in obtaining uniforms for a proposed Girl Guide Company at the School.

The Boy Scout Troup has made a very fine showing and were highly commended when they visited Vancouver recently. I would like to see this Girl Guide Troup formed if the amount can be made available. There is no question but what the Boy Scouts and Girl Guides of this School would enhance the esprit de corps.

Father Dunlop has done a splendid job among these children, and they have made real progress under his care.

Indian Agent
