DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of
(George) Freddie George, Pupil No. 182,
of the Sechelt Indian Residential School at Sechelt B.C.,
who died at Sechelt School (place) on 29 March 1936.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a report on the death of Pupil No.182, Freddie George - registered as George Freddie George - who died in Sechelt Residential School on Sunday, March 29th 1936. By a sad coincidence, his father, Councillor Fred George, Sr., died in Vancouver General Hospital at almost exactly the same time.

The history of this case is as follows: On March 19th, the Reverend Principal phoned me that he was bringing Freddie George to Vancouver for hospitalization, and asked me to advise Dr. McQuarrie, which I did. Dr. McQuarrie thought the school infirmary was the best place for him under the circumstances; we could not send him to his home as his father was also seriously ill. Sir:-

I have the honour to enclose herewith the result of an inquiry into the death of Simon Francis Jefferies, late pupil of the Sechelt Residential School, who died following an operation in St. Paul's Hospital, Vancouver, B.C.

The boy's death was no doubt hastened as a result of eating green apples but his condition was serious before that although he had not reported sick, and the School did all they could for the boy. The only criticism of the school authorities is that sickness is not reported to the medical officer, Dr. Inglis, quickly enough. At the inquiry Dr. Inglis referred to an appendicitis case which is still in hospital, where he was not called until the boy was in serious condition.

I have reported to the Department in connection with this School and have received routine replies which are unsatisfactory, regarding wholesale dismissals of the staff by the new Principal. I strongly objected to the action of the Principal in calling for the resignation of the manual training teacher who was appointed and paid by the Department and has done excellent work, and this matter is still being argued back and forth. He reports for duty on the appointed days but so far this term no instruction has been given as the Principal will not send the boys to his class-room. Meanwhile the pupils are without instruction in the most important part of their curriculum. I mention this as one incident of the actual harm being done by this irresponsible and unwarranted dismissing of employees. Possibly we have no say where the inside staff is concerned, but I think you should be acquainted with the facts. Dr. Inglis advises me that the Sister who has been nurse in the School for many years has been replaced in the general shake-up. The former nurse knew all the Sechelt Indians and their family histories and Dr. Inglis said he could absolutely trust her diagnosis of patients and she knew exactly when to call him. In Mr. Jefferies' case it would have made little or no difference but the appendicitis case might easily have had serious consequences and the boy is still in hospital. Dr. Inglis says that the former nurse would have recognized the symptoms immediately but by the time he was called, inflammation had become acute.

I have never yet been able to obtain any clear understanding of an agent's duties with regard to residential schools. Some principals work with the agent

Harold W. McGill, Esq., M.D.,
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
and encourage him to inspect the school and see for himself what is going on, other principals appear to resent the agent going into the school, or taking the slightest interest in it.

I know that the satisfactory standard at Seeholt School for the care of the pupils has not been maintained under the present regime and that not only is cooperation lacking but there is a veiled hostility becoming more and more apparent which I can not yet understand.

The school receives a generous grant from the Department more than sufficient to take care of these pupils and I would say that the Department's representative has a right to be consulted rather than ignored in matters affecting the education, welfare, safety and general well-being of the pupils.

I am advised by some of the travelling salesmen that the amount of their orders for provisions has been greatly reduced since Reverend Father Fahlman succeeded Reverend Father Maillard last fall which would indicate that the feeding of the children is not up to the former standard, although I have no definite knowledge of this as yet. In the clinical report the pupil is shown as "rather ill nourished" but I presume the disease would cause that condition.

I feel that it is my duty to report these matters to you even if I exceed my authority in doing so, but personally I can not see why these schools should be held sacrosanct and above all criticism.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]

REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF JANUARY 1937, ON VANCOUVER AGENCY.

On the 20th the death of a pupil took place at Sechelt Residential School, and the usual investigation was held. This school was operated for several years without a death, but there have been five since an entirely new staff was placed there two years ago. The former Sister Matron had had many years of nursing service among two generations of Sechelt Indians and knew their family medical histories. This was valuable information when pupils reported sick, and the medical officer has said that he trusted her diagnosis as much as his own. There are still many bitter complaints from the Indian parents, as to the treatment of the pupils at the school, and I am afraid it may end with some untoward incident. On my last visit to the reserve, the Indians stated they were going to hire "the best lawyer in Vancouver" to investigate the school, as soon as they earned enough money from logging and fishing.

Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I have before me letter No. 229080-1 of Dec 13/21 handed to me by Indian Agent Mr. Graham regarding the necessity of a kindergarten class at St. George's School Lytton. I might say that the matter was brought before Inspector Cairns & he perfectly agreed with the proposition & saw the necessity for such in the school.

In conjunction with Mr. Graham & Mr Carins I also since coming here can see that those children coming in at the age of five & six years who are unable to take part in the outside work of the farm, should undoubtedly have an extra room for themselves. At this early age receiving proper attention a proper foundation could be laid which would be of great advantage to them when in due time they will be required to do their work on the farm. These children are attending school from nine thirty AM un_6 til four thirty PM but have no special attention at any time which they so sorely need.

I have already taken steps to standardize the school to comply with the B.C. standard of public schools. This of course means a necessary rearranging of the working programme as well. My ideal is to have the teacher carry out each school day curriculum which will allow the making of one curriculum in the beginning of the year & followed throughout. Again by reorganizing the working hours of the pupils they will cover in two days the one day curriculum. In this way the child will in time be ready for high school entrance & able himself or herself to carry on with their education without starting from the beginning.

Compulsory education gives us the opportunity of holding the child until eighteen years of age & surely he should receive as far as possible a standard as well as liberal education.

I might say that I have just received Inspector Cairns report & have already, if it is at all possible, begun to equip the school with properly qualified teachers.

I trust that you will carefully consider the kindergarten proposition & will favor us with your permission & wherewithall with which to establish this very needed acquisition. With the present construction scheme on hand I would not find it an extra burden, doing it now would mean that it would all be finished at once.

Yours very obediently

Principal.

I have your letters of March 2nd, and February 24th, numbers 229080-3 and 10, in connection with the financial standing of St. George's Industrial School.

As you are aware this institution was left so badly in debt by the late principal, that Constable MacLeod and myself did our best to try to get it out of debt during the short time that we were in charge, with the result that we had to get advances up to the end of the fiscal year. This has naturally left the new principal, Mr. Lett, up against a hard proposition, as he has a full school of over one hundred children and staff, which have to be fed, and which cannot be done on nothing, as well as pay wages.

During the winter months there is absolutely no chance of earning money from the farm. We have several thousand dollars worth of hay on hand, if there was only some market for this.

In my letter of the 18th ult., I asked if it were not possible to have the number increased for which there is capita grant allowed, and your letter of the 24th ult., stated that we would only be paid for an average attendance of one hundred. Now this is very hard on a school like this, that is struggling for its existence at the present time, and especially when we can accommodate more pupils who are voluntarily coming in. It is the only Church of England school in the district and we certainly do not wish to have to turn children away when we can accommodate them at all. We can accommodate them by using up the residential portion for the staff, but the school is not equipped with any isolation ward, which is a very essential thing for an institution like this and it is a matter that will have to be provided for in the very near future.

During the late principal's regime supplies and equipment were let run so very low that we are finding it now impossible to get along without spending considerably on this, all of which goes to use up what small amount of money we have available, with the result that the wages are not paid.

Dear Sir:

I am taking this privilege personally to write you concerning conditions at St. George's School. I am aware of the fact that all correspondence should go through the hands of Indian Agent Mr. Graham, but hope you will pardon my intrusion, and with patience peruse my appeal.

As you stated to me in your office before I came out I found the situation by no means in an ideal shape, and naturally, with enthusiasm, began to reconstruct and rearrange.

I made an application to you, through Mr. Graham, for an additional schoolroom, the kindergarten, which you granted, and which I have now opened and have in full working order, excepting for some additional kindergarten material for teaching, requisition for these to be sent in shortly.

In order to properly carry on this needed work in the school and meet the additional expense, we hoped the Department would allow us to overstep our limit in numbers, which is one hundred children. We are running over that number now, and it is most essential that the Department recognize this fact by continuing our per capita grant to allow over the limitation. As you know the school is in a very low financial condition, and the taking in of children is a source of finance to us, so to be deprived of the grant would prove very serious indeed at the present time.

I may say that since I have taken over the work we have had a number of voluntary applications, which perhaps has a meaning in itself, the Indians evidently already realizing the fact that it is not a period of slavery their children are being sent to, but a period of training for future usefulness. These voluntary applications, we feel cannot be turned down, even though we had to do without our grant, yet I feel sure that the Department will deal favorably in this matter. We would like the limit to be one hundred and twenty, instead of one hundred as it stands at present.

Because of the installation of the kindergarten, I am boosting the fact that parents should send in their children at the age of five and six. The financial situation, of course, is a secondary thing in my opinion, for I feel that if we are going to do the best for these young lives in helping them to pave a way for their future as capable citizens in the Dominion, and to help them rise to that standard of civilization in which the modern world lives, we must make provision for the conditions outside, which we have no hand in curbing; that is, increase of population and naturally increase of numbers here. To do this we must have finances, which although I have placed as secondary, yet they must run hand in hand. They are
interdependent.

As our accommodations for this greater number, we are crowded. The residence is now filled up with staff. Mrs. Lett and myself are confined to one bedroom, livingroom and diningroom. This we have no hesitation in making the sacrifice as we feel we are here to give our lives' work for the good of the cause, and inconvenience and griefs and cheerfully endured. In the course of time the Institution will have to be enlarged either by turning the residence into staff quarters and building a residence, or by building a new dormitory. This latter, my feeling is at present, more inclined to, as provision could be made for better conveniences for the children from health and sanitary points of view.

We are now passing through an epidemic of "Flu". It is of a very slight nature, yet it carries with it everything calling for isolation and precaution. We find isolation requirements nil. I am sure that if you were to drop in on us at the present moment you would not hesitate, at first glance, in seeing the difficulties we are contending with, and the great necessity for isolation accommodations. This department of school work is not secondary by any means. It is most important for convenience and prevention of disease. This being one of the chief factors in dealing with the Indians outside, their health conditions calling for such isolation. Also to teach them this important fact should be our aim. Later you will hear from me in detail on this matter.

I have already placed my finger on many leakages about the farm, and feel certain that with a proper irrigator and plenty of water, the farm will be a source of great revenue to the school. I have already begun credit and debit the farm in order to ascertain what the farm is really doing for us. I believe I can, in time, make the situation at St.-George's much brighter and of less expense to the Department by directing my energy upon the farm as a source of financial help, and in due course we will be able to help ourselves very substantially.

In closing I beg again to be allowed to take in, at least the voluntary applicants, and that the Department will supplement our per capita in extending the limit now placed.

This appeal is wholly from the standpoint of helping the people directly implicated and in working this out to help ourselves to carry out our aims.

Yours obediently,

Dear Mr. Lett:

I have yours of the 6th instant, referring to conditions at the Lytton Industrial School. I have been aware of the difficult situation which you were called upon to face and am pleased to note the enthusiasm with which you have commenced your duties. I trust that the epidemic of grippe has now run its course and that the staff and pupils are in good health.

In reply to your request for an increased pupilage, after a review of the facts which you have presented I am of the opinion that you would do well to accept the voluntary applicants that present themselves for admission. Active recruiting, however, should not be practised and further action will have to be taken by the Department when we find the average attendance running over the hundred.

Make every effort to secure the perfect attendance of those enrolled, and this will keep your per capita earnings high. With an enrolment of about 110, you should aim at an average attendance of 105, and I will instruct Mr. Ferrier to allow grant for a few supernumerary pupils for the time being.

The practice of the Department is to frown on applications for the admission of children under 7 years of age. However, in view of the provisions for kindergarten work that you have been able to make, it will be in order for you to accept those a year younger. This can be considered a special privilege at this time and will be revoked when you are at full strength.

I have learned, with satisfaction, that in the near future you will derive substantial assistance from the proceeds of the farm. It is extremely desirable that the special per capita grant be discontinued and the regular $150 and $20 bonus be paid to the Lytton Industrial School. I see no reason why the finances of the institution should not be in good condition when you are assured of a fair crop this coming summer. I wish you every success in your work and assure you of my continued interest.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Sir,

Ottawa, September 22nd, 1923.

Dear Mr. Saunders,

Under date of the 8th February last I made a report recommending the payment of the removal expenses of Rev. A. R. Lett from Navan, Ont., to Lytton, B.C., amounting to $932.19. The Treasury Board replied stating that they were unable to submit the matter for favourable consideration as it is not the practice to pay transportation expenses in the case of a first appointment. On account of the unusual circumstances in this instance I would ask the Treasury Board to reconsider the matter.

The Government recently took over from the New England Company the schools which they had conducted for many years at Brantford and Lytton. The Company's funds would no longer bear the expenditure of keeping up these institutions, both of which, however, were doing splendid work and fill an important place in our scheme of Indian education. It was then decided that the Government should become responsible for the maintenance of these two schools.

In the case of the Lytton Institute the management during the time of the last incumbent appointed by the Company had been most unfortunate, and the school was decidedly unpopular with the Indians.

J. C. Saunders, Esq.,
Secretary of the Treasury Board,
Ottawa.
It was necessary to take radical steps to restore the institution to its former standard.

The Department appealed to the Missionary Society of the Church of England to nominate a principal who should be a capable administrator. After extended negotiations the name of Rev. Mr. Lett, of Napan, was submitted to the Department, and he appeared to have the necessary qualifications. The salary, however, was none too attractive and the cost of moving his family such a distance prohibitive. He, therefore, made it a condition of his appointment that his removal expenses to British Columbia should be paid. Under the circumstances the Department agreed and I am, therefore, of the opinion that these expenses are a legitimate charge against the fund provided by Parliament for the education of Indian children.

In view of this explanation I trust that the Treasury Board will see fit to pass favourably upon my memorandum.

Yours sincerely,

Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

I note your appreciation of the help and cooperation of the Department and the Indian Agent at Lytton in connection with your work at the school. You may count on this in the future as we wish your administration to be in every way successful.

Yours truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Reverend A.H. Lett,
Principal,
Lytton Indian Industrial School,
Lytton, B.C.
At the time of my visit this summer, I noticed that barns will soon be needed and, eventually, a building programme (less chapel) will have to be considered. A site near the centre of the farm should be considered. The school owns 100 acres of land in the hills 7 miles away.

In the near future, the Principal should be given an opportunity to build, by day labour, a dormitory building and other out-houses such as residences for staff. The Department would be put to little expense, as they have facilities for their own lumber. More pupils - and there are many voluntary ones - could then be taken. The present needs are as follows: an electric light plant, a start on a good dairy herd, a bake oven, dormitory flooring, threshing outfit, lavatories for boys' dormitories, and perhaps two more bath tubs.

Water - not land - is the great care here for successful farming. A reservoir is needed for domestic purposes and for the lawns, also for hydrants which should be installed for fire protection. Later on, if the Botanic dam was raised, the 100 acres in the hills could be irrigated. Inspector Ditchburn promised to send an engineer, at no expense to the Department, to look over the Botanic dam project. The Inspector was a little doubtful about the advisability of preparing more land for cultivation, because he felt Mr. Lett, the Principal, might work the boys too hard.

I should write to Mr. Lett, instructing him to get in touch with the Rev. Father Murphy, Principal of the Kuper Island Industrial School, to arrange for a game of basketball in Vancouver. Mr. Lett's connections in Vancouver could arrange for the sale of tickets to cover expenses.
November 16, 1922.

Sir,

I have been having a long discussion with the Rev. A. Lett, principal of St. George's Indian Industrial School, here, in connection with the general welfare of this school.

As you no doubt are aware, this school had progressed under Mr. Lett, until we have now worked it up to its fullest capacity, as far as pupils are concerned, in fact we have a waiting list of a great number of children, if we only had more room.

We have already filed what we consider is necessary for the coming year for the improvements on this school, which if granted will give us more accommodation.

As you know the school had been allowed to run down to such an extent that Mr. Lett started in with a very large deficit, which he has been gradually working off, but it is very disheartening having this hanging over one's head, especially when it has been taken over by the Department. I am taking this opportunity of applying to see whether or not it would be possible for the Department to wipe this debt off, so that the school could start the new year with a clean slate, and I feel sure we can keep it that way, as well as improve generally.

The farm is paying for itself when we take into consideration what the school gets out of it, but owing to the fact of the low market on everything this year we have not been able to sell anything that we could make a profit out of. We have lost it and say that we could have sold but as the market is now it meant holding these over for another year which means that all profits have been eaten up.

The ranch had been let run so low that we have a great deal of fencing to do to get it into anything like good shape. Then again all the school clothing, bedding, etc., had got so low that it means putting all these in new gradually.

If you can possibly see your way clear to granting this request, I feel sure that we can show you some returns in the very near future.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Mathews:

I have to inform you that the Lytton Industrial school under the principalship of the Rev. A. R. Lett, concerning whom I have already written, has been administered for the past year by this Department. It was found advisable to keep a direct oversight from this office, and the services of Department representatives in the field have been utilized in this connection.

We have lately increased the pupilage to allow a greater per capita earning power which will result in regular grants of approximately $15,400 for the fiscal year ending March 31st. In addition, the quarterly payments from the New England Company have been forwarded to the school, to be applied towards current expenses. The deficit incurred during the principalship of the Rev. Mr. Leronde has not yet been completely wiped out, and I am seriously considering making a special grant at this time, to enable the Rev. Principal to start the new fiscal year without this extra burden.

It has been rather difficult to finance the institution this year. The surplus stock and hay have not been sold as yet, because they would have been marketed at a loss. Next year, I trust that they will prove a source of revenue.

The money forwarded by the New England Company, from the Guarantee Society Limited, has been given to the Rev. Principal for the purpose of erecting a dairyman's cottage, a small outdoor infirmary and for some fencing that was necessary.

The Department has made, in addition to the payments mentioned above, certain grants for needed equipment and alterations: a threshing outfit, complete with tractor ($2500), 4 milk cows ($500), bake oven ($800), plumbing fixtures ($1100), flooring ($600), a kitchen range ($200), 36 tons of coal ($900), and smaller items aggregating roughly $500.

It is my intention to ask Parliament to appropriate, in the near future, $2,000 for an electric lighting plant, $8,000 for a temporary outside dormitory building, which will permit of larger pupilage, and $1,000 for the raising of the Bottanie dam - which action will ensure a more adequate water supply.

Ernest Mathews, Esq.,
Governor, New England Co.,
26 Bloomsbury Sq.,
London, W. C.,

Memorandum.

Mr. Scott:

At the time the Rev. Mr. Laronde left the Lytton Industrial School, there were outstanding accounts amounting roughly to $7730. Under the supervision of Mr. Indian Agent Graham and Mr. McLeod, this deficit was reduced to approximately $2500. During this time, practically no equipment was renewed, and the institution was somewhat run down when the Rev. Mr. Lett took over the principalship.

We are paying a per capita grant of $175 instead of the regular grant of $150, and, in addition, are forwarding the quarterly grants from the New England Company to assist with the current expenses.

At the beginning of this fiscal year advances totalling $7000 were made against the per capita earnings. It was the intention to deduct $3500 from the grants at the end of the September and December quarters. The Rev. Mr. Lett and Mr. Indian Agent Graham were unable to sell to advantage the surplus stock and hay, and we were forced to make an advance of $2000 in October, last. Such an advance to be deducted from the quarter ending March 31, 1923. The Rev. Principal has, on several occasions, requested that this Department wipe out the deficit at the school, and he has again made a strong plea, through Mr. Agent Graham, that the Department place him in the position of starting the new fiscal year with a clean sheet. I am not hopeful that the institution will remain in a solvent condition if we deduct $3500 from the per capita earnings for the past quarter and $2000 from the earnings of the present quarter.

The Rev. Mr. Lett has been requested to prepare a financial statement, and, upon receipt of this, we can estimate more definitely the exact deficit at the present time. I am of the opinion that he is about 6 weeks behind with his accounts, or roughly $3,000.

If this estimate is approximately correct, I would strongly recommend that the Minister's authority be secured and a special grant made to the St. George's Industrial School. I believe funds can be found from the Appropriation for Indian Education. I will write a hopeful letter, for your signature, to the Rev. Mr. Lett, if you concur in this connection.

Supt. of Indian Education.

3. Report for quarter ended March 31st. from the Rev. A.R. Lett, Principal of St. George's School, Lytton, dated 10th. April.

Lytton, B.C.

April 10th., 1923.

New England Company.

Sirs,

By request I take pleasure in reporting the welfare of this school. I hope you will pardon some detail. I have now been somewhat over one year in the position of Principal and feel I have grasped an intimate knowledge of the situation both as regards the past and the present conditions (the former only as I found them when taking over) of the school separate from the community or those upon whom we draw for pupils and also knowledge of the community.

A. The Children.

The Children were when I first arrived generally unhappy with a feeling of slavery existing in their minds, no aims, no feeling other than "I have a certain period of my life which perforce I must put in at St. George's school and the easiest way possible out of it is my thought". I saw at a glance that this feeling righteously existed as the children were ill fed and ill clothed and turned out into the cold to work and that without leadership.

Stealing was chronic and from all, this was done without hesitancy. One would think they felt they had a right to everything belonging to the school and if it is not given me I shall get it anyway. This feeling I have no hesitancy in saying was inculcated by example, and conditions existing prior to my coming.

Morale of the children are low at any time and were exceedingly so at my beginning. Mrs. Lett, who is House Supervisor, and myself were in constant dread lest we should find the worst among the girls, yet thus far we have gone along and still have the bright side to look at.

The first of these I combated by using a firm loving hand, gaining the confidence of the individual child. They at once realized that they were going to receive a square deal and I began to see smiles here and there. After I had been going for some three months I had occasion to be away on business at the coast for three or four days, and on my return one of the smaller girls wandered into the office and said "My Mr. Lett, we are glad you are back for we were all lonesome for you", this naturally did me as much good as if some good Samaritan had endowed the place.

The Children were lean, anaemic and T.B. Glands were running in many cases. Energy was at its lowest ebb. Five
minutes leap-frog was the most I could get out of the boys at first. In examining the Hill of Fare I found that here lay the source of a great deal of trouble in the health and welfare of the children. They were not getting enough to eat and I immediately increased the fare and served it as much as possible. This had its desired effect and hearts gladdened, thieving stopped to a large degree, clean skin and rosy cheeks appeared and more energy in work and play resulted. Enough to eat without wasting and warm clothing was my slogan and it worked miracles.

In the schoolroom I found a great lack of necessary training. Mathematics, reading and writing were the only subjects taught. This was insufficient and I immediately set out to establish the B.C. curriculum for the High School. This took time and thought and selection of staff. This curriculum is now established and working smoothly with certified teachers installed. The head master has begun Cadet training for the boys the girls receiving the physical drill with them.

The half day system is in use in the school. Children are divided into A. and B. divisions. When I first took over the smaller children of each division, who were not able to receive industrial instruction, were allowed to run loose while the larger pupils fulfilled their obligations. This has been changed. Those not able to work go to the schoolroom all day and when old enough their work will take their place in the several industrial departments. At present there are forty receiving trade instruction out of one hundred and fifty enrolled. The remainder I feel are too young to work and special attention is being given them in the school-room, by so doing they should get a fair foundation and perhaps be able to prepare for High School entrance. The Indian Dept. at Okaaw are shortly beginning to build a High School for Indian Children and it is my aim to at least prepare for entrance to this school some of these children. I feel this can be accomplished with the present system arranged. The standard of entrance to the High School is qualification certificate per B.C. Public School curriculum.

B. Conditions existing in building and Depts. of same when taking over and at present.

Dormitories in bad repair, no cleaning had been done for years evidently floors worn out in places. Ventilation poor; beds in poor condition; these have all been rectified. In the boys dept., there was only one bath tub and one toilet to accommodate fifty boys. The Dept. has now installed an extra tub and two more toilets so that has overcome an unsanitary difficulty.

The girls dept. needed an extra tub and washbowls, these have also been installed.

Kitchen cooking apparatus was in very poor condition in fact I had to agitate for a new Range which has been installed and is giving good satisfaction. The Dept. has also furnished a Bake Oven which is an endless boon to the kitchen as the children themselves go through an average of one thousand loaves per month. The boys do the baking under supervision of the Farm Manager who learned the trade when he first started out in life.

The corridors and kitchen floors have been covered with linoleum supplied by the Dept.

New lockers have been installed. The Children were obliged to use their suitcases for their belongings. These were kept under their beds and are now stored away.

C. Conditions existing outside the school.

The Parents had to be forced to place their children in the school. There were in the school when I began eighty children.
This number has increased to one hundred and five which over-
spacitates our dormitory space. I have on file about fifty
voluntary applications which shows that I have already gained
the confidence of the parents. In some cases parents have
travelled miles to place their children in the school only to
be turned away because there is no room for them. When I
think of the possibilities of these children I feel that the
above state should not exist and certainly so when H.C.
Institutions are waiting to be hold of every little soul and
we may lose them all eventually. I feel sure that we could increase
our numbers to one hundred and seventy-five in less than one
month's time if we only were able to accommodate men and this
accommodation should be given us without delay. Only a very
short time ago I had to turn away six children, one of them
a boy of fourteen.

D. The Farm.

Having had some experience in farming in Ontario and know-
ing something of the occupation I naturally have taken a keen
interest in this Dept. As in the schools I found the farm in a
sad state of equipment, repair and fertility. This will take
years to overcome especially recuperation of fertility. In some
cases fourteen crops have been taken off without rotation.

There is only one barn on the place of any size or capacity
and this has been condemned by the Vet. Dept. as full of T.B.
germs which owing to it being built of logs with plank floors,
no amount of cleaning and disinfecting would stop infection.
During the past three years some eighteen head of cattle have
been condemned and destroyed. Only last autumn we lost four
through test, two of them being twoгодling an average of
sixty pounds per day each. They were also the beginning of a
dairy herd. I believe the Dept. are going to build a new barn
this summer.

Hogs are inbred and naturally scours. I have taken steps to
overcome this by breeding with pure bred stock.

Machinery old and in bad repair. The Dept. has given us
a new Mowing Machine, also a 10-20 Tractor and Thresher. The
Engine is very handy as we have power to be used for threshing,
haying, sawing, ensilage cutting, etc.

E. Orchard.

The old orchard has been so neglected that it will take at
least another year to bring it back into shape. A new orchard
of about three acres was planted but hogs and cattle were allowed
to run at large in it and consequently about 70% of the trees
were destroyed. This spring the Dept. has given us two hundred
trees which have just been planted.

The farm and climate are very adaptable for alfalfa hay. We
hope to increase our acreage in this line of fodder as three crops
can be cut in one season.

There are as you are aware 700 acres in the property. Of
this about 175 acres is being cultivated and only about one
third of this acreage is in shape from a fertile standpoint.

F. Financial condition.

By dint of close economy the debt of £7000 has been reduced
to £3000 during the past year. This debt has been considerably
encumbered. Because of it I have not been able to go along
as rapidly as I would like to. £4000 would have enabled me to
get more land in shape and make other necessary improvements.
Forced economy after all is the most uneconomic and is in every
disheartening to one who is at all aggressive and wishes to make
a success of the business. I have been living as it were from
hand to mouth or from month to month hardly knowing where I was
going to get money to pay salaries and meet accounts. The Dept.
meeting our requirements with advance grants which is not
the most satisfactory yet it gives us a firm standing and
enables us to go along.

While this report may seem tinged with pessimism throughout
yet there are great possibilities for the school if we can get at
them. This will take time. Patience, perseverance and prayer
solve great difficulties and I can see a bright future for us.
There is always a business side to any occupation one may take
up which must not be neglected. As you will see by financial
report herewith enclosed strict tab is being kept on everything.
I am doing this in order to ascertain wherein we are losing so
that I may make a success of the business end.

The work is strenuous and calls for constant care and
vigilance but reward comes in the thought that one is building
on Christian character and with it enlarging the Kingdom of
God on earth.

In conclusion I might say that in the near future I would
like to see provision made for our waiting list in the way of a
new school or a new dormitory for the boys. The dormitory now
occupied by the boys could be turned into sleeping quarters for
girls and thus solve a problem now existing.

Yours very obediently,

(Sgd.) A.R. LETT,
Principal.

Herewith is a Recommendation to Council for payment of the expenses incurred in the transport of Rev. A. R. Lett from Navan, Ontario, to take over the Principalship of St. George's Industrial School for Indian boys and girls at Lytton, British Columbia.

Mr. Lett was assured that upon taking this appointment his expenses would be defrayed by the Department. This case is similar to that of Dr. A. W. Powers of Baie des Cedres, Que., who was recently appointed Indian Agent and Medical attendant of Betsiamites, Que. Dr. Powers was assured that upon taking office his transportation expenses would be paid, and on the matter coming before the Auditor General's Department, that Department held that under Order in Council of 8th September, 1871, with regard to travelling expenses, the payment covered the cost of actual removal expenses and as such required the authority of the Treasury Board. (The said O. C. of the 8th September, 1871, provides as follows:

"REMOVAL ALLOWANCES.— No removal allowances can be granted except on report of the Treasury Board. No removal allowance is to be granted if the salary is increased, except in special cases, and on a report from the head of the Department. A removal allowance is not to exceed the actual cost of account rendered.")

Dept. Indian Affairs.

Ottawa, February 8th, 1922.
In submitting the case of Mr. Lett for consideration of the Audit Office attention was called to the following:

(1) That the case of Mr. Lett does not come under the provisions of the Order in Council of the 8th September, 1871 re removal expenses as he was not in the service prior to his appointment as Principal of the Industrial School and although there are a few precedents, yet it is not the custom to pay removal expenses of new appointees.

(2) As to payment of freight on an automobile being allowed as "removal expenses."

The Auditor General in his letter of the 22nd February, 1922, returning the case to the Board agrees with No. 1 above, stating as follows:- It is not the practice to pay transportation expenses in the case of first appointments, but I presume it is within the competence of the Governor in Council to do so.

In regard to No. 2 above, the Auditor General states "The claim for freight on an automobile is an unusual charge in transportation expenses."

Dear Mr. Saunders,

Under date of the 8th. February last I made a report recommending the payment of the removal expenses of Rev. A. R. Lett from Navan, Ont., to Lytton, B.C., amounting to $932.19. The Treasury Board replied stating that they were unable to submit the matter for favourable consideration as it is not the practice to pay transportation expenses in the case of a first appointment. On account of the unusual circumstances in this instance I would ask the Treasury Board to reconsider the matter.

The Government recently took over from the New England Company the schools which they had conducted for many years at Brantford and Lytton. The Company's funds would no longer bear the expenditure of keeping up these institutions, both of which, however, were doing splendid work and fill an important place in our scheme of Indian education. It was then decided that the Government should become responsible for the maintenance of these two schools.

In the case of the Lytton Institute the management during the time of the last incumbent appointed by the Company had been most unfortunate, and the school was decidedly unpopular with the Indians.

J. C. Saunders, Esq.,
Secretary of the Treasury Board,
Ottawa.
It was necessary to take radical steps to restore the institution to its former standard.

The Department appealed to the Missionary Society of the Church of England to nominate a principal who should be a capable administrator. After extended negotiations the name of Rev. Mr. Lett, of Navan, was submitted to the Department, and he appeared to have the necessary qualifications. The salary, however, was none too attractive and the cost of moving his family such a distance prohibitive. He, therefore, made it a condition of his appointment that his removal expenses to British Columbia should be paid. Under the circumstances the Department agreed and I am, therefore, of the opinion that these expenses are a legitimate charge against the fund provided by Parliament for the education of Indian children.

In view of this explanation I trust that the Treasury Board will see fit to pass favourably upon my memorandum.

Yours sincerely,

Chas Stewart

Sir,

I have your letter of August 23rd, in which you state that a report has reached the Department to the effect that I have invited Roman Catholic parents to send their children to the Lytton Industrial School.

In reply I beg to state that this is absolutely untrue. I might say, though, that hardly any goes by that I do not get applications from Romans to send their children to the Lytton or Coghlanetza Schools. In every instance I advise them that there is the Roman Catholic School at Mission for them to send their children to, but they emphatically say that they will not send them there. Only on Friday last, I had an application from an Indian at Lillooet to send three children here. When I asked why he did not send them to Mission he stated that he would send them there, if they never went to school, as they could not afford to always be paying for them as the priests insisted on them doing.

I beg to draw your attention to a letter I wrote to the Department, 1-02-12, March 10th, in which I enclosed copies of letters from Dennis S. Peters, which will speak for themselves.

The Indians are all quite well aware of the order in council, as I was informed by one of the chiefs that this matter came up at a meeting of the Allied Tribes.

The education of Indian children is a matter that I am deeply interested in, and I never lose an opportunity when on the reserves of bringing this very matter up, and very often they say to me, "Where can we send them?" and I inform them according to their religion, which school they are to be sent to.

I am quite aware that any officer should refrain from any activity that might cause criticism on the part of church representatives, but Indians invariably will blame the Agent when the priest threatens them.

Trusting that this explains the whole matter,

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Sir:

I thought a general outline of the situation here would not be out of place, and hope by submitting same I shall not be intruding. My monthly report will I am afraid, show very poorly, and my quarterly earnings, when the advance grant of $1500.00 is taken out, will just be sufficient to carry me over one month. It is true, I shall be able, later on, I hope, to dispose of farm produce will net us some cash, but it will have to be used to offset the standing debt, when same could be used profitably in necessary improvements.

We have in the new barn a source wherein we might make good, and will when we have it filled with cows. The process of building up a herd is so slow, that it will take at least two years of heartrending waiting before we can say it would be of any material benefit financially. Five or six cows would strengthen us here, one at least, if not two of them registered animals, as Mr. Timms, the dairyman, is rather anxious to experiment, and this would be a possible feeder to dairy farms about to be established in the community.

With every dairy farm, naturally, follow hogs. We should have a good pigsty in connection with the farm. Mr. Timms has been successful in raising bacon hogs, and is very anxious here also to get to work.

Feed for stock is now no question. We have both silos filled with about 120 tons corn silage, and the remainder, 20 tons of alfalfa. This amount of silage is sufficient to feed 33 head of cattle, 40 lbs. per cow a day for six months. We harvested in the neighborhood of 275 tons alfalfa hay, and threshed 800 bags of grain. We shall have about 40 tons beet root. This means in silos and root cellars, 160 tons. The farm end, I can safely say, is advancing rapidly, and I would venture to say that the Department should not hold us up any longer than can be helped, as it is tiresome, and is not conducive to continued aggressiveness, having a great tendency to make one feel as though it is no use continuing with hands tied. To be candid, I might say that lately I have felt as though I would not be able to continue, being so handicapped in so many different quarters. The men are all so willing, but have no opening for their energies, and are continually approaching me from a get ahead point of view.

The blacksmith and one of the men on the farm also have something done in the way of better housing accommodation, and all four houses should have bathtubs, toilets and so on.
tanks. Comforts are conducive to contentment, and I have a good bunch of men around me at the present time. It would, I feel, be disastrous to lose anyone of them.

Hen coops are another needed acquisition, which could be made payable, even to the extent of feeding the children. I have managed to erect two coops, but have no accommodation for scientific production, which is so necessary in a place of this type, in the training of boys. We have now on hand seventy laying hens, and have been able to give the children eggs twice a week.

So much for the farm. Now I would like to say something of the school building itself. I find it rather hard to keep a staff steadily, as there is no accommodation. Supervision is so hard, that the staff find that they cannot measure up to the standard asked, for insufficient equipment, and no proper division of both sexes, keeps everyone in constant strain, myself and Mrs. Lett, included, as the whole falls upon the head. I am beginning to wonder just how I have continued thus far. Mrs. Lett, at the end of the last period, was on the verge of a breakdown, due to nothing else than being in constant contact with the staff, and work of the school. I am thankful to say, she has regained some strength, and is again more or less feeling herself.

If we had much longer to continue in the building, (old part) new roof will have to be put on, as since the rains, I have been constantly patching and tarring. The sinks and wash troughs, bathrooms, etc., will have to be rebuilt, and new flooring will have to go in, in the bathrooms and dormitories. I have already patched the dormitories' floors.

In the dormitory we have a moral problem, which owing to the arrangement of that part of the building, we are unable to combat. We had one of the boys run away two weeks ago, and questioning him on his return, found out that the bigger boys were using him to commit sodomy, hence, his getaway, afraid to come to me. I suspected this for sometime, but myself and the supervisors had not been able to check up on it. It at least will be an impossibility to eradicate it, until we have proper accommodations where-in we can separate the older boys from mediums and youngsters.

The situation of the toilets, is such, that the boys, of necessity, are continually running to the dormitories, thus making no end of confusion, and necessary supervision.
We are forced to use the children's dining room to afford the boys some room for recreation in the way of small games. This does not lend itself to a tidy and clean dining room. The boys have no play room, in which they could occupy themselves on autumn and winter evenings. It is much easier to direct in a proper manner young energies, then it is to curb. The lack of proper playing quarters is a very hard proposition to cope with, and endless supervision is therefore called for. I have no hesitancy in saying that a great deal of moral trouble in dormitories is due to the fact that the boys are perforce held in too much.

The girls on the other hand are not too badly provided for, but could do with a great deal of improvement.

The water situation is critical. In the course of a short while new tanks will have to be built, but on second thought, the springs that have heretofore given us ample supply for domestic purposes, are gradually failing. We have had to use the irrigation ditch this summer, and I am hoping the fall rains will so increase the springs that they will supply us for the winter. The water situation gives us no fire protection.

As above mentioned, or touched upon, our own situation is by no means ideal. We have at the present time, nor have we had since coming, any home life. Mrs. Lett, baby and myself, occupy one bedroom, not even having a spare room for visitors. The livingroom and the dining room are so public that we dare to talk over business affairs, and repair to our bedroom, but then must confine ourselves to whispers. The main corridor running through our part, and the staff (three members) living upstairs, sharing our toilet and bath, gives no privacy, which is so much needed under such strenuous conditions of work. We long for some place where we could be separate, for at least a time, and could enjoy home by ourselves. With the children's diningroom on one side, dormitories overhead, playroom below, we cannot have much peace.

Our little girl is now growing up, and the constant contact with tubercular and syphilitic children, and immorality, does not make our feelings any brighter. To the above I attribute Mrs. Lett's condition. We cannot afford to allow ourselves to go on in this way indefinitely, and finally emerge broken. No use in Indian work, or anywhere else. We love the work for the work's sake, and hope at least in the near future to receive some encouragement in the way of a home of our own.
I also would make a general plea for the outside, (farm situation), which would give me a chance to do something, and a new school, as soon as it is possible, as we are badly in need of new quarters from so many points of view.

Re the extension of the dam at Bootahnie Lake. This work is setting me back $5.00 per day, and will run me into a bill of about $300.00. Owing to so much fall work here, I could not in any way allow the school teams to go there, hence $4.00 a day for team and teamster, two teams being my division of the work. This work if finished will give us added tonnage at Lot 47, as it will provide for an added crop, and with it, a permanent man, and a span of horses will have to be provided.

In conclusion, I might say that I am at the present time, feeling rather upset, in mind, because of the fact, that I am unable to pick up owing to financial strain, the financial end of the school work. As I go on with my hands tied, the work becomes more and more burdensome, and I feel that it is time the Department was placing the institution on a permanent, businesslike basis, so that I will be enabled to relieve the burden and strain carried.

Trusting to hear favorably from you at your earliest convenience,

Yours obediently,

(Rev. A.R.Lett)
Principal.

Dear Dr. Scott:

Some time ago I visited St. George's School at Lytton, and found the Principal, Rev. Mr. Lett almost in despair, and sadly in need of some encouragement, particularly as to the future prospects of the school.

As you doubtless know from reports you have received, he has certainly worked hard, under most adverse conditions. He has kept the school well filled, and has put the agricultural side, anyhow as regards crops, on its feet, which I believe no other Principal has been able to do before. With, however, the load of debt on his shoulders he has now reached the limit of business capability, unless the Department comes to the rescue. He has, I am pleased to say, received every possible support from Mr. Agent Graham, but I do think that more support should be forthcoming from his own brother churchmen.

Having, however, proved the need of this school by raising the attendance despite adverse conditions, I think that still further support should be forthcoming. As I have already pointed out, he has been able to raise large forage crops, but they, of course, do not pay unless you have, as in this case, the dairy stock to feed it to, which stock will then bring in the much needed income. He has not the money to purchase same, and under present conditions, it will take a number of years before the capacity of this new dairy barn, which should be the paying side of their agricultural activities, can be filled. Pigs are also a good paying side line to dairy farming.

I should therefore advise that the barn be utilized, otherwise the erection of same was waste, and six grade cows be purchased, and some pig pens erected, so much for the immediate necessity of help on the agricultural side, which should materially help put the school upon a self-supporting basis.

From the school side the matter is even more pressing. I have already reported fully upon the deficiencies, and unsatisfactory state of the building, and you have doubtless heard of the difficulties of running the school efficiently, owing to these drawbacks. One of the most pressing and immediate troubles is the shortness of water, which apparently cannot be rectified at the present site of the school. This is dangerous, both from the health point of

Sir,

Within the last few weeks, I have gone into the St. George's School situation very thoroughly with both Mr. Inspector Pragnell, and School Inspector Gairns, at the request of the principal, the Rev. Mr. Lett.

As far as the farm is concerned, this I am glad to say is about on a paying basis, but in order to make it a little better, there is great need for some more milk cows, and a piggery. With these the school should be put on a good paying basis. As far as the farm is concerned, cream could be shipped and surplus milk used for pigs, which are always a paying line. At the present time there is no piggery near the new barn. The old one, which was absolutely useless, is situated up by the old barn.

In regard to the school building, this, as you know, is very old, and the plan is so antiquated that it makes supervision very difficult, especially in the wintertime when the dining-room, for instance, has to be used as a playroom for the boys. All this necessitates the keeping of a larger staff than I would consider necessary, and consequently increases the expenses and difficulties of the Rev. Mr. Lett has in financing this institution.

The greatest trouble that we have is the shortage of water. Owing to the springs from which the domestic water supply was obtained having dried up last winter, every atom of water for the building had to be hauled in barrels, and up to the present time when then the school has relied upon irrigation water, which is none too good for household needs. This is now turned off and it is doubtful whether we are going to get sufficient water from these springs again this winter to supply the school. This naturally makes it very dangerous, both from a sanitary point of view, and also in case of fire.

It has been intimated to us on several occasions, that we are next in line for a new building this coming year, and I sincerely trust that the Department will do all it can to get this started.

I might add that even the Indians are beginning to notice the defects in the building, and fire risks that we are running owing to shortage of water.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Dear Sir,

Yours of the 4th inst. to hand, and I wish to sincerely thank you for the whole-hearted hearing you have given me. Needleless to say, I have conscientiously worked and feel I have not yet arrived anywhere, yet yours together with a letter of encouragement from Bishop Popper, has, I feel, for the present opened a way out of the difficulty.

Owing to the fact of so many weeds on the farm I have not been able to get a proper catch of alfalfa. In one case of some eight acres of land which has been seeded twice in succession, I have not had a catch. I have spent some $400 on alfalfa seed without results and this summer after fertilizing for three years with barnyard manure, tried a potato crop in order to get cultivation, with the result that I hope in the early spring to get a catch, but the potato were not a crop and I lost out in my estimation of having one or two cars of potatoes for sale. Next spring I expect to seed all land available as alfalfa is the only paying crop here outside of roots, potatoes and corn. Grain is a failure because of the fact that there is so much waste through irrigation and results are not very high in comparison with three crops of alfalfa.

Since submitting my report, Inspector Cairns has visited the school, and we had a long talk on ways and means of relieving the situation. Mr. Cairns suggested doing away with the blacksmith-shop as this particular department has not been paying. I believe this would be a good step, as I have found a deficiency here ever since taking over the work. I have not reported this simply because I was of the firm opinion that this being the only department where a boy could really receive a trade training, the department would insist on its being carried on, but since Mr. Cairns has stated otherwise, I would advise closing up the shop with your permission.

Mr. Cairns also advocated giving away the greater part of the farm, but with this I do not agree as the ranch at the present time is paying its salaries and expenses. I shall submit a financial report on the farm herewith. I feel that the next two years will show a fair dividend from this department.

My present financial strain is due to one outstanding factor and that is that I am of necessity carrying a staff that would care for 135 or even 140 children. On the day of Mr. Cairns inspection, we had 93 on the roll, with 92 in the school, one being sick in the hospital. We could handle eight more children. Mr. Indian Agent Graham is shortly sending in a number, and Indian Agent Helmeingof Kamloops is
now taking a census of his agency, and I hope to have a report from him saying that there are a number available in the Nicola valley. I arranged a trip through the Nicola with Mr. Helmsing, but unfortunately, Mr. Cairn's visit here and his trip through the Nicola collide and I consequently had to cancel my visit. I hope later on to make this trip and to do some volunteer recruiting. While, with one hundred children, we are overcrowded, yet I am obliged to carry them in order to make ends meet. This is not at all conducive to good health among the children.

Since we cannot increase our number, I must needs turn to immediate means of remedy, hence the report to you with its suggestions.

We can do with the cows right away. The dairy at present is supplying the needs of the school with butter and milk, but with some additional cows we would be able to ship cream, thereby making a cash surplus which would help the financial difficulty. The additional skim milk used in feeding hogs could be made a payable factor, hence my asking for a hog pen.

The chicken coop would be an asset from the point of view of school-scrap feeding and run on a scientific basis would no doubt develop into quite an income, even from feeding children and tending to the local market. This should be built to accommodate about 300 laying hens. We have about 80 hens now on hand and with the purchase of a few roosters, an incubator with 500 egg capacity, by next autumn we could fill up our hen-house. The new employee's residence to be built should be provided with a basement which could for incubators, as the man occupying this house on completion is to have charge of the chickens.

The three houses in which the farm hands are living need sanitary appliances in the way of bath-tubs, toilets and septic tanks. An ice-house with two refrigerators, one each for butter and meat, has been included in the estimates. At the present time there are no refrigerators on the place.

These are needed improvements and would make us feel that we can take a greater pride and interest in our property.

Regarding the new residence, both Mrs. Lett and myself really feel the necessity of a place separate from the school. Mrs. Lett especially feels this as her condition of health, owing to so much steady contact with routine coupled with the care of our child, is gradually telling, and a nervous breakdown will eventually be the result. The doctor has already told her that she must get away, at least for a time, in order to regain her former self.

The situation of this building will have to be considered in conjunction with the new school, and I presume built in uniformity.

I have no hesitation in repeating what I have already stated, that there would be no common sense in building on the present site. From the following points of view a new school on the present site would be an absolute absurdity:

1. Water, which is vital.
2. By moving down on the farm we would be in the centre of operations.
3. A room for necessary playgrounds, and easier supervision on the playgrounds.

4. An opportunity for beautifying the place.

By subheading the above, I could go into detail in showing the great advantages each would present.

Proper living quarters for the boys. I trust you will hear with me in dealing with this question from a common sense point of view taking into consideration the temporary and the permanent building. Temporary additions to this building would not be feasible, nor practicable from many angles. In erecting a temporary building it would have to have in it a playroom and classroom, as an increase in numbers would mean extension, first of dining room, and secondly more classroom. The only way this could be done would be to open up the senior class-room and extend the dining-room into it. This would mean a large expense, even though it were of a very temporary nature. Water supply is just barely carrying us at the present time and to spread it out would be cutting our supply considerably. The heating plant is not large enough to carry any more radiation. With increased numbers, more laundry room and equipment would have to be installed.

A Dormitory as a unit of the new building. This would have its advantages and disadvantages, yet I feel that a permanent dormitory on the new site would be much better than adding expense to this building. We have plenty of water on the farm, thereby relieving the present situation; the boys would be in the centre of farm activities, but, this situation would mean, added staff which we cannot afford; the children would have to come up here for meals and classroom work; laundry etc would have to be brought up here, etc.

In conclusion I would say that if the Department cannot see fit to commence construction on a new building of permanent type, which indeed would be the solution of the entire problem, that it would be wisest, even with its manifold drawbacks, and certainty of expense, no matter how temporary, to construct a temporary building at the school here, to house a dormitory, class-room, and playroom, with necessary accommodation for supervision, but I feel that it must be clearly borne in mind that this building would have to have a separate heating plant, and where water for it would come from, in view of our present serious shortage, I do not know.

Trusting that this has stated our position to you, and that some remedial measures may be undertaken to ease a situation that to me is a continual source of worry.

Believe me,

Yours very obediently,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Mathews:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the Lytton Indian Residential School. There is no doubt in my mind as to the extreme difficulty of managing and financing this institution with its present buildings and equipment. The school itself is badly laid out, unsanitary and is in a dilapidated condition. Further, if a fire secured any headway the entire structure would be doomed, because of its inflammable nature and the small water supply. Residential facilities for the principal and family and for other married members of the staff are inadequate. More stock is needed, so that the barn, which has been erected on the new site, and the farm produce can be utilized as financial assets.

We have been fortunate in securing the services of the Rev. Mr. Lett, who is not easily discouraged and who has done exceptionally well, considering the difficulties with which he has to contend. Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just returned from visiting St. George's School, Lytton, where I held a Confirmation and had the pleasure of going over the whole farm and buildings.

I write to emphasize the great need that exists for new buildings and more ample accommodation.

The floors are almost all worn out and patched, the dormitories are too crowded, and the building altogether has served its usefulness, and a new building in the centre of the farm near the new barn is an essential so that the school may have a larger capacity and then the same staff could carry on efficiently. I know from observing the schools at Sardis and at Fraser Lake, what a difference is made by having modern equipment, and I trust that the excellent results now being obtained under Mr. Lett's management, that he will be given such help from the Department as will enable him to make still more satisfactory progress.

Dear Sir:

I have yours of Dec. 10th No 165-0-1 relating to Inspectors report advising the reduction of staff in this School. I have to make the following remarks after careful consideration.

I had a long chat with Inspector Cairns on this matter & I must say that he did not give a sympathetic hearing in every sense of the word. I called his attention to the fact that with proper equipment & a properly building in which to work a reduction in Staff would be quite feasible & justified. While he readily agreed that I was working under very great difficulties yet he utterly failed to be guided by the following facts.

1st that the majority of his schools are new & furnished with modern equipment with which to do the work.

2ndly that I am of necessity carrying a Staff which could easily look after the needs of one hundred & thirty or forty children provided we had the proper building & equipment.

The question of fewer lady officers is a question that I have gone into at several occasions. The present situation is this. Their must be at least five Matrons to look after our present number of children. At the present time we have six. The dining room matron who attends to the setting of the children's tables & division of food, also assists the boys matron in the mending & darning of the boys clothing. If the present sewing room were large enough to accommodate the required number of girls the boys repair work could be done by the girls but as the room is small measuring 19x12 with table, three sewing machines, & cupboards there is not much room left for matron & girls. The laundry with its ancient Armstrong equipment, has to be kept in operation six days in the week 8 o'clock A.M. until 4 P.M. so that there is not much opportunity for relief here. Dear Doctor Scott,

At the Court of the Company held on February 11th last, the following letters and reports were considered:

1. Your letter to me of November 27th 1924.
2. Your letter to the Company of January 25th 1925.
3. A letter from Mr Lett to the Company dated December 17th 1924.
4. A copy of the report from Mr Lett to you.

I am sure you will understand that the Company are much surprised and disappointed at the disturbing nature of Mr Lett's letters, considering the previous reports we have from time to time had of the School, the buildings and the farm.

The Company's decision to build a School at Lytton was taken after thorough consideration of the questions raised by the site and its proximity to Lytton and the Indian Reserve.

When the School was visited by the late Governor, Mr Ford, and myself in 1916, the buildings were well constructed and there was a good supply of water; the crops, stock and general management of the place seemed most satisfactory. Successive reports or which a synopsis is appended for reference supported the favourable opinion formed by us on our visit.

Nothing was said about the inadequacy of the buildings when in or about 1916 the Company were encouraged to lay out a considerable sum of money in bringing water by a "flume" from Botanie Lake; it is only surprising to learn now that the water supply is inadequate.

Nor again was any doubt suggested when in 1918 the Company were asked to add to the buildings a large block of rooms containing accommodation for 40 girls.
It has been impossible for any members of the Company to visit Canada since 1914, but they have heard from time to time that St. George's School is one of the best of the Indian schools, while the Chapel has always been described as one of the best in Canada.

Now suddenly without any previous warning the Company are faced with a report that "the School itself is badly laid out, insanitary, and in a dilapidated condition."

Whether this state of things is in any way due to Mr. Laronde who succeeded Mr. Dawson as Principal it is unnecessary for me to speculate, but if so it is unfortunate that the deterioration of all the buildings and the bad state in which everything was left were not reported to us at once.

Looking to the obligations of the Company as covered by their Charter, I feel that to spend large sums on pulling down and re-erecting buildings not more than 20 years old would hardly be justified, because under our present agreement with the Indian Department if all that Mr. Lett requires were done at once and paid for by the Department the lien on the Company's property at Lytton would be very heavy, and objected to on the ground that we are spending money on the secular education of Indians, a work now so well carried out by the Indian Department.

The Court discussed the matter at length and eventually came to the unanimous conclusion that if you are satisfied that removal and reconstruction are essential the best course open to them would be for me to enquire from you definitely whether the Indian Department would be prepared to buy the property at Lytton, in which case I am authorised to say that the Company might be willing to continue the grants which they now give, and also probably give the bulk of the interest derived from the purchase money to the Indian Department.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Governor,
The New England Company.

The Rev. E. Green, Inspector of Schools, visited the School in June and October 1912 and reported that "the School owns over 366 acres of very fine land. 200 acres are under cultivation. Stemp, an employee of the Lytton Residential School, to be reimbursed to the extent of $100, the amount of a loan he made to the Rev. L. Laronde, a former Principal of the School. The facts in the case as appear from our files are as follows:

On the 31st of March, 1921, Mr. Laronde, who was at that time about to give up duties, borrowed $100 from Mr. Stemp for the purpose of paying off the farm instructor, stating that he had no money in the bank at that time, but would reimburse Mr. Stemp as soon as he received further funds from the Department.

Laronde proved to be a defaulter and left the school in a hurry, and Mr. Stemp has never been reimbursed. He claims that as this money was given for the purpose of paying a member of the staff it is a bona fide claim against the Department. This matter was brought to the attention of Mr. Agent Ball when he audited the accounts of the school after Laronde left. The cheque which Mr. Stemp gave Laronde was cashed by him at the bank and, in proof of this loan, the cheque was shown to both Mr. Ball and Mr. Agent Graham. Mr. Stemp is still a member of the staff and again requests repayment by the Department.

From time to time there are funds available from the New England Company grant which are sent the Principal for current expenses, and for which he has to make no accounting to the Auditor General. I would recommend that from the next payment made the Principal, he be instructed to pay Mr. Stemp the sum of $100, as there is no doubt his claim is a reasonable one.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, December 9th, 1925.

Sir:
