THE CRUSADER

A quarterly review of the doings and happenings at St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C., Canada.

Volume 1. Number 1.

In presenting this, our first effort in magazine publication, to you, we do so in the hope that it will, should you not have been to Lytton, a means to an end, that of interesting you in our school; and should you be one of the many who know Lytton, and St. George's, that it will revive memories of past days, and give you an insight into any progress that has been made since last you visited with us.

Much of the material used in this short magazine has been prepared by the children themselves, thus providing them with some very essential practice in elementary composition. They have taken a great interest in this first edition, and we would be grateful for a word to tell them that their efforts were worth while.

To those of our readers to whom St. George's is but a name, we would endeavour to pass on a little information regarding our school. The early history of the school and its founders will be dealt with by our Principal, Rev. A.R.Lett, but much else can be said of the school to-day. We are endeavouring, under rather trying conditions, to impress upon some hundred odd Indian children, enough knowledge and training to equip them for life's battle when they leave here; whilst to those who show the mental aptitude, and the necessary physical equipment to handle it, we strive to put them through the Entrance Examination of the Province, and so on into High Schools. In the classrooms the children are taught many practical subjects outside of the classrooms; the girls, baking, sewing, laundry, cooking and housework; whilst the boys undertake to assist in working a very large farm; have a chance to learn blacksmithing, and rather elementary shoe-repairing, to learn gardening, and some of the older ones help in the management of a very fine herd of Holstein Dairy-cattle, which supplies the school with much needed milk.

The school is situated some two miles from the village of Lytton, on both transcontinental railroads. To one side of the school, the Fraser River flows, whilst from the east into Lytton come the Thompson River; but both rivers being very rapid and dangerous, we cannot boast of having an "Old Swimmin Hole" for our children. The buildings are old at St. George's, very old, some of them, and we hope and pray that the day is not far distant when we will get our long-lacked-for new school. Many new outbuildings have gone up in the past few years, the school being a large dairy-barn, hog-pens, chicken-houses, silos, besides the new staff cottages, so we have much to be thankful for. But although we cannot get a new school-building just yet, we will carry on and do our best by these entrusted to our care and teaching, and hope that they will grow up to be useful and energetic citizens.

In closing, we will take this opportunity of wishing you one and all, kind readers, the Compliments of the Season, and to all,

"A Very, Very Happy Christmas, and Happiness in the New Year."
I do not think I could do better than to say a few words about the unique foundation of St. George's Indian Residential School. The school was built by a missionary society known as the "New England Company", founded in 1649, under charter from Charles the Second, who wished to take care of the subjects in what was then known as the New England States. In drawing up the Charter by which the Company should be governed, the King was careful to include within its scope the aboriginal peoples of the newly settled States; hence the interest taken in our Indians by this Company received its birth.

After the U.S.A. gained their Independence, the Company transferred their interests to Canada and worked wholly with our Indian peoples. They built and supported a school for Indian children at Brantford, Ontario. This school served the Mohawk Indians. Finding that they had sufficient funds to bring it out, they built the present school at Lytton in 1902, and since materially added to the building.

We now have a school handling over one hundred children belonging to the tribes of the Thompson Indians. The school, situated as it is on the banks of the Fraser River, and in the midst of the Cascade Range of the Canadian Rockies, has a particularly picturesque appearance. Nature in all its beauty presents itself to the eye, in the greatness of the mountains, reaching high into the clouds, and extending their snow-capped tops far above the timber line; whilst at their feet or as it were, in between flows the turbulent water of the Fraser, with an altitude at Lytton of six hundred feet.

This comparison of altitude gives the reader an understanding, to a degree, of the vastness of God's book of Nature. And with this wonder, comes a message at this Christmas tide. In the glory, beauty, and vastness, is enveloped the thought of the Christ Child, who although born of humble parentage, wrapped in swathing clothes, and laid in a manger, is above all, and through all that we see. Truly we can say, "Who hath at the end of these days spoken to us in His Son, whom He appointed Heir of all things, through Whom also He made the Universe." This thought ought to come home to us very strongly when we realize in a greater grandeur and lovelier way that He who was born a babe in Bethlehem is Master of all, and we as His servants unite, yet let us who working in co-operation with one another and with Him as guide, sustainer, and Master, we can carry out the Angelic proclamation, "Peace on Earth, Good-will to Men."

May we approach this Christmas tide with a message from our surroundings surmounted by the infinitely beautiful message of the Angels, so that the New Year will begin with a stronger incentive to be true and faithful servants to Him who is our Pattern, Priest, and King.
We welcome but three new members to our staff this year, the school maintaining most of its old staff, which to those versed in work among Indians, is a good sign. We will deal with the new-comers in order.

Miss Aileen McCarthy, our Girls' Matron certainly cannot be classed as an amateur in Indian work. Coming from Alert Bay or somewhere along that treacherous coast, we understand that Miss McCarthy has been many, many moons engaged in teaching, patronizing, and the various other jobs that fall to the lot of the Indian worker. We hope that she likes her new surroundings, in which already she has done good work, particularly in connection with the Girls' Concert recently held in Lytton.

Miss Robson, also, can hardly be classed even as a new comer, for we find out that she was here in days gone by. With many years experience in Indian work, however, we welcome Miss Robson back again, where we know she will stay long with us in her new position that of House Supervisor.

Mr. W. Hargriff, the new Junior Room Teacher, is a new-comer to this type of work, but he seems to have already found a firm footing, and the children in his room are getting along well.

There are several changes in positions on our staff, which we feel might be of interest to our readers:- Mr. W. Rowe, who for three years has presided over the destinies of the Junior Schoolroom, has now taken over the coveted position of Housemaster.

Miss Muir has taken over the duties of the Boys' Matron, where she rules the Kellys, Terry's, and Bakers with kindness, but as becomes such imps of mischief, strictness is also very essential. Miss Robson took over Miss Muir's work in the Dining-room, in addition to her new work.

Mr. and Mrs. Lett, and Marjorie have now moved into their new quarters, and the Staff have accordingly moved into the Residence Dining-Room, which gives them more congenial surroundings. (For the house-warming at Mr. and Mrs. Lett's, you are requested to come in parties of four, as accommodation is limited.)

Congratulations are in order to both the Steen's and Demer's families, on the arrival, in each case, of a baby boy. Mr. Demer's newest little boy was baptised the other Sunday, and christened Edwin Carson, Miss Mitchell and Mr Anfield acting as god-parents.

We wish to announce that after long and patient waiting, the Stamps, with their little girl, have moved into their new house, where we are sure they will be very happy. Practically all the staff cottages have recently been fitted with full plumbing, which will prove a boon to all concerned.

We are gratified to learn that Mr. Tim has benefited greatly by his short holiday, and trust that he is now fully recovered from his slight indisposition.

The Members in Occupancy of the "STACK", have forwarded to the editor of this magazine, a most moving letter, detailing the fact that while the other cottages are getting full plumbing, they have been left with a four-gallon coal-oil tin. Their letter has been referred to Mr. Stevens for report of the possibilities of installation.

All members of St. George's kept Armistice Day with the customary two minutes silence, and in both schoolrooms, special lessons were taught to show the children, many of them hardly understanding what war really is, the true lessons of the Great Struggle for Freedom. In the senior Room, it was decided to hold a competition in the form of a prize essay, the two winners for the Senior Grades being; Peter Antoine, age 18, Spence's Bridge, Grade VII. Eva Tooney, age 14, Grade VI, Ashcroft.

The two compositions are re-printed herewith.

"Why we keep Armistice Day"....Peter Antoine.

Armistice Day is kept throughout the whole Empire and every Canadian should faithfully observe the request of our beloved King to observe the "Two minutes silence" in honor of those who went and fought to defend our country, King and Empire.

This war was the bitterest and most terrific ever known in the whole history of the world, the whole of Europe being at war, namely, Germany, Turkey, Belgium, France, Balkans, Russia, Palestine, Egypt, Italy, East Africa, and a battle was even fought on the southern coast of South America, near the Falkland Islands.

The human cost of this horrible war was estimated at twenty million soldiers wounded, nine million were killed, three million were taken prisoners, nine million helpless orphans whose parents sacrificed their lives for others, and also five million war widows whose husbands were killed in their effort to save our freedom and Empire. After the war, an epidemic of influenza broke out, caused by the filth of the battlefields, and thirty million civilians died of the dread disease. The calculation of dead during the war was sixteen thousand per day, whilst the material cost of the struggle was $358,000,000,000 or nine million dollars for every hour of the war.

Our Canadian Indians played a great part in that war, in which some five thousand of them went willingly and they proved to be brave and obedient soldiers.

In the fourth year of the war, the whole world was disgusted with fighting and were now rising for peace, especially Germany who needed it most, for Germany was in utter despair.

The end of the war came when the Armistice was signed on the morning of November eleventh, 1918, when all signs of fighting ceases and sadness turned into joy.

The result of the war was that many factories and mills closed down, unemployment was rife, and many were homeless.

In June, 1919, a Treaty was signed at Versailles, France, and the League of Nations was formed to enforce just dealings and to protect the smaller countries, and to try and prevent wars.

Quite recently, the Locarno Treaty has been signed in which all the nations have promised never to start wars anymore.

On each Armistice Day, we usually go to Church and there observe the two minutes silence and we should pray for those who are still in agony, for many are still suffering from wounds they received in the war.

Our duty is that we should keep the example of loyalty they set for us, and to be loyal to our King and country, and to keep faith with those who died for us.

The other composition, under the same title, written by Eva Tooney, is given overpage.
Schoolroom notice.

We keep Armistice Day all over the British Empire to remember the first day of peace when the World War ended in 1918.

There were a lot of countries at war, many of them hardly understanding the reasons for fighting. Among them we find Russia, German, Belgium, Egypt, Austria, France, Turkey, Italy, Africa, Palestine, The British Empire, and the Falklands. In fact, they seemed to be at war all over the Old World.

The loss of the war was terrible, nine million soldiers being killed, thirteen million dying with a disease called influenza, which was caused by filth and dirt; twenty million soldiers came from the war wounded; nine million orphans who have lost their parents during the war, two million who lost their homes, and five million women who lost their husbands in the terrible war. The money cost of the war was three hundred thirty-eight billions of dollars, which means nine millions of dollars an hour.

Every country that was at war was desiring peace, and when they got peace, they were so glad that they thought that was the greatest blessing God could bestow upon them.

The end of the war was a great improvement to the world, and now they are signing a Treaty of Peace in Europe showing that all countries desire to have peace.

From the Great War we get Armistice Day, when the first day of peace the World had had since the war began, was celebrated, and on this day we keep the two minutes silence to remember the war. In those two minutes, we keep silent and think of the soldiers that went at the war, and pray for the people that had relations killed, and we hope that God will give protection to the children whose parents were killed in the war.

It is our duty to those who died for us to consider their brave deeds, and to try and sympathize with and help the ones they left behind them, and we must try and be worthy to carry on where they left off, and if we do try, God will bless us for our efforts.

We have had two visits from our Inspector this school-year, and we are pleased to say that Mr. Cairns was very satisfied with our work, but that we must keep on trying all the time. To use his own words, "Education can never stand still."

We wish to thank the Dept. Of Indian Affairs at Ottawa for their kindness in granting us a mimeograph, and to tell them that it certainly fills a long felt want. But for this little machine, we would still be thinking about a school magazine, instead of reading from its pages, for no matter how much we would like a magazine, costs of printing are out of the question.

Pictures, or to use the more popular expression, the movies, are running again this year in our school, and with a program every two weeks, the children no sooner get through one show, than they begin counting the days to the next one. The film serving costs but little as we show in the village of Lytton, charging just a nominal sum to make our expenses of giving a free show to the children.

Two visits from the Dominion Veterinary Inspector gave us the happy assurance that our dairy and range horses are in fine condition, free from all disease to which cattle are heir.
"Echoes from the girls' side."

We graduated four girls from St. George's School last term, in the persons of Mamie Mike, Matilda Boston, Ada Angus and Christine Spike, all of whom we were sorry to lose. Matilda Boston has found that life at St. George's was not so bad after all, as since her graduation she has been unfortunate enough to have to stay in hospital, suffering from glandular troubles.

Mamie Mike has taken amicably to the dishpan to ease her heart, which we understand was broken at having to leave S.S.S.

Christine Spike has multiplied her troubles since leaving us, by taking unto herself a "better half." We wish her all happiness.

Ada Angus, another of our graduates, is helping her sister-in-law with housework.

Several new arrivals now grace the girls' side, in the presence of Lavinia Terry, Mary Jane and Minnie McIntyre, Helen Kanaka, Sarah Blatchford, Emily Bob and Emily Spye.

A Freshman's life is one of turmoil and trouble, as can be seen by the following:- On her second morning here, Minnie McIntyre was busy upstairs, when her little sister, Mary Jane, a little cupid, came racing up, loudly crying, "Where's Minnie? Where's my Minnie?" She seemingly thought that for a few days, the new comers were carefully deposited in some dark corner.

"Babe Terry", her twin cupid, but sometimes known as "Vinegar", had a splinter in her finger and whilst it was being removed, suddenly drew her hand away, saying, "Not you, not you, me go to Mr. Anfield", and off she fled to the Senior Room.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

In 1902, the New England Company, of London, England, erected an Indian residential school at Lytton, B.C. It has been maintained by the Department's regular per capita grant, supplemented by New England Company funds. In 1920, the New England Company pointed out that their income was fixed, and, with increased costs of living, their purchasing power had decreased. The Department was asked to assume the financial responsibility. Rather than have the school closed - it is a very important unit in our establishment for Indian education in British Columbia - the Department made a special increase in the per capita grant and leased the institution for a period of 21 years commencing January, 1922. I even suggested to the New England Company that it might be advisable to transfer title to the Dominion Crown as I wanted to secure the institution as a permanent factor in our programme.

The increased per capita grant and a better management has placed the school's finances in good condition and I am hopeful that in future it can be maintained on the regular per capita grant plus the £1,200 per annum grant, which the New England Company continues to make. By the terms of the lease, the Department allows the New England Company an annual rental of £400. This amount is not directed to London, but is used for repairs and replacements at the school.

Prior to the leasing of the institution, the Department had made no special grants for capital expenditure; but, during the last few years, approximately $41,000 has been used for mechanical plant, irrigation, farm machinery, live stock and outbuildings. In 1923, a modern barn was erected, and, during the past year, two cottages for the staff have been completed.

The main building at the school, although but 24 years old, is most unsatisfactory. Its layout is bad; it is of frame construction and is a veritable fire trap. The school is now a popular one and more accommodation should be provided without delay. I consider it false economy to add to the present main building and am of the opinion that our work will suffer if a new, modern institution is not commenced this coming summer.
I acquainted the New England Company with the situation and asked them if they could assist in the construction of a new school. Their reply was that the terms of their Charter would hardly allow them to spend capital funds for this work and the Company Court formally inquired if the Indian Department would be prepared to buy the property at Lytton so that nothing would interfere with the reconstruction of the School. I asked what consideration would be accepted and the company replied that, although their capital expenditure at the school amounted to approximately £12,900 and the institution stood as an asset at that value in their books, they were prepared to sell all their interest for the sum of £8,000.

They offered, further, that if the sale is effected, they would continue their grant of £1,200 per annum for current expenses and would add thereto the bulk of the interest derived from the purchase money. The conditions of the lease would, of course, automatically determine. I still consider that the Lytton Indian Residential School fills an important place in our work; and, as the value of the lands alone is roughly estimated at £40,000, I feel the offer of the New England Company should be seriously considered.

It will be necessary to secure a valuation of the property, and, as it may be possible to find funds in the current Appropriation for Indian Education - the vote for the Cecil Jeffrey School being unexpended - I should be pleased if you would give me the name of a gentleman in the Fraser Valley to whom the commission of appraisal could be given.

There is an item in the Estimates for the coming fiscal year to provide for a wing of the new main building and I hope that sufficient funds to complete the establishment will be available for the building season of 1927.

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C.

One of the principal educational institutions for Indians in British Columbia is situated just north of Lytton, on the Fraser River. It was established by the New England Company, of London, England, which Company operates under a charter granted by Charles II for the education and evangelization of aborigines. The history of the Company's work in this country is interesting, and it has centred of late years at Lytton and at the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont., established for the Six Nations Indians. The Company found that, owing to the increased cost of living and the increase in taxation, their fixed income failed to meet the charges against it, and the Department took over their two institutions in this country. I need not now refer to the terms upon which we took over the Mohawk Institute. We leased the property at Lytton for twenty-one years at £400 a year, which amount is annually turned in for improvements at the school.

When the Department took over the management, the Lytton school was in an embarrassing financial position. Canon Gould, of the Church of England, was associated with me at that time in the appointment of a highly competent principal, who has been able to restore the financial standing of the institution. The buildings were in a very bad state of repair and, in many respects, wholly unsuitable. The situation has been gradually improved—a barn and other outbuildings having been erected. The main building of the school, however, is most unsatisfactory. It is of frame construction and is so planned and added to that it is not an exaggeration to say that the lives of the staff and children are in constant danger from fire. On the other hand, the farm, comprising 691 acres, is admirably situated and well irrigated and, under proper management, has proven most productive.

Lytton is central to Church of England work among British Columbia Indians and I am very desirous of constructing a new main school building. There is provided in the current Estimates an item of $35,000.00, which is sufficient to begin the work.

- The Lytton school
The Lytton school is not conducted by the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, but this Society considers it one of the most important Anglican institutions for Indian work and was pleased to learn that we proposed its early reconstruction.

I acquainted the New England Company with the situation and asked them if they could assist in the construction of a new school. Their reply was discouraging and the Company Court formally inquired if the Indian Department would be prepared to buy the property so that nothing would interfere with the reconstruction of the school. I asked what consideration would be accepted and the Company replied that, although their capital expenditure at the school amounted to approximately £12,500 and the institution stood as an asset at that value in their books, they were prepared to sell all their interest for the sum of £8,000.

They offered, further, that if the sale is effected, they would continue their grant of £1,200 per annum for current expenses and would add thereto the bulk of the interest derived from the purchase money. I consider that the Lytton Indian Residential School fills an important place in our work; and, as the value of the lands alone is roughly estimated at $40,000, I feel the offer of the New England Company should be accepted.

I wish to recommend that the Company be asked to give us an option on the property for ten years. If we fund their annual grant of nearly $6,000 for seven years, the purchase price would be available without asking Parliament for an appropriation. In the meantime, the Department could proceed with any building activity allowed.

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

November 23rd., 1925.

Dear Mr. Bush,

As I promised, I have been to the Lytton School and find there that the buildings are in a truly sorry condition. I have also seen the Inspector (Col. Fragnell) who tells me that he condemned the buildings a year or two back and has been constantly pressing on the Department at Ottawa for action.

He feels that Mr. Lett is doing splendidly and is worthy of all encouragement.

The particular points on which the school buildings are unsatisfactory are:

(1) Wholly inadequate water supply - for the last two winters water for domestic purposes has had to be hauled in barrels to the School and there is no pressure, except in the spring, to cope with any outbreak of fire.

(2) The sanitary and lavatory conditions are very poor not to say unhealthy.

(3) The lower part of the boys' part of the building is in very bad repair - and their playroom is gloomy and the floor rotten.

(4) The wooden part of the boys' building is very much perished by exposure; doors and windows are now badly fitting, so much so that in the winter when the usual cold snap comes even the school classrooms are intensely cold and work has to be abandoned.

All this I saw with my own eyes and was amazed at the wholly unsatisfactory condition, taken as a whole, of the School. Especially the boys part. Those who have seen the place feel that it is little short of a scandal that such a number of children should be so housed.

I understand that the Indian Department want to remedy things at once, but are held back somewhat by the Treasury and expense.

A vote was passed in 1925 for the purchase of the property from yourselves. Now, possibly owing to difficulties arising from the recent elections, the Department asked Mr. Lett if he would wait another year. Col. Fragnell feels, however, that this ought to be resisted, and pressure brought to bear with the government to make them go straight ahead with the rebuilding.

Editorial.

To one and all, to the children of St. George's School, to their parents and many friends, to new friends formed through the medium of our first volume, and to all interested in the work being carried on in this place, we extend our greetings, and beg to submit this second volume for your consideration and interest.

Perhaps, first of all, we should apologise for not appearing before, for although we set out to be a quarterly, we fell down at Easter, but seeing that we were quarantined with small-pox and scarlet fever for some eight weeks, we are sure that those who looked for our arrival, and felt disappointed, will forgive us fully. Thanks.

And so we come to the end of another school year, for by the time many of our readers receive their copy of the Crusader, the school will be silent for the "Long Vacation", looked forward to by one and all. The children will all have gone to their homes, which are more or less scattered from Vancouver to Kamloops, all anxious to make every minute of that precious six weeks last a year. They are our only advertisement, for what the children are, so is the School, and it is indeed our wish and prayer that they will one and all reflect credit on St. George's School; that their parents will see with pride some progress over the last arrival home, both physical and mental and moral, that other parents with children not yet in school, will look on them that who wish to send their children to school as well, will be the aftermath of association with any or each of our own scholars.

This year has gone, and although we have, during its passing, been visited with much to try us, in the form of epidemic sickness, we hope that the very trial has been as a spur, to urge one and all to greater endeavours, to realise, that although much time was lost, yet a mightier effort could make much of it up. In spite of the sickness, we have much to be thankful for, and we are indeed grateful for the many pleasant times that have been ours in this past twelve months, and especially so to those who helped to make them possible.

To those, who with the end of the school year pass on to new endeavours, whether they be children of the school, new graduates, or members of the staff, we can only say one thing. May all that is well and good go with you into your new life, whatever it be, and may the lessons learned at St. George's long remain with you. We wish you all success, and in the case of the graduates, hope and pray that the memory of the days spent at this school may remain with you as a very bright beam of light among many such that we hope will shine on your life in the days that lie before.

For a more detailed account of some of the outstanding events of the year, for a message from our Principal, for a glimpse at our staff, for glimpses into the children's work, we beseech you turn the pages, and trust that therein you will find much to interest and please you.

Education of Indian children in the St. George's School, and its relation to the institution and the child's relation to the future life in the community.

By Rev. A.F. Lott, Principal.

"It is not my privilege in a small school magazine to deal with this subject in detail but in a cursory manner, I trust, give our readers some idea of our purpose and aim.

The child's education is liberal and scientific. It is our aim in so far as possible to fit the child for post-school days, taking into consideration his surroundings and environment together with relations to others.

By a study of the Indian home life, with its primitive and listless methods, lack of family discipline, slight knowledge of physical care, lack of thrift and consciousness of what the morrow may have in store; naturally calls for an all-round preparation and knowledge of the essentials of home and family life. To cover the above needs each department gives the child an opportunity to acquire not only a knowledge, but form habits which will to a large degree at least in a great many cases lead to a change, from the primitive life, to the modern ordinary civilized methods of living.

To carry out this aim our schoolrooms are equipped with the latest and most up-to-date necessities in enabling the teacher to give every attention to the academic training of the child, equal to any public school in the province. This not only gives the child from the part of the school a fair standing with every child, and also from the child's outlook a feeling of equality and consequent fearlessness.

From the schoolroom we turn to the separate departments wherein is given the practical scientific training demonstrating if possible, the academic work of the schoolroom. The girls receiving instruction in domestic science, sewing, laundry, and music and needlework, i.e., darning, knitting, and crochet-work. The boy receiving a general training in carpentry, blacksmithing, shoe-repairing, harness repairing, and a scientific training in agriculture in every department covering crops and growth of field crops, animal husbandry, horticulture, poultry, etc.

The agricultural curriculum included throughout calls for a staff efficient in individual departments, and also a knowledge of health, welfare, and mental study. Psychology is a necessity in order that the best may be drawn out of the individual child. We realise the outstanding fact that a child's character may be made or broken during this critical period of mental development. A very close study of each child is stressed as a very important factor. Children being imitators, carefulness, watchfulness, on the part of the staff must be constant and exacting, remembering always that the tremendous responsibility of the care in bringing up young lives, no setback must be fostered, prejudices must be cast aside; quality recognition, and every opportunity must be given to a graduate of an Indian residential School in the needed sustenance of uplift which he or she has been so carefully taught through school life.

A study of the home as we have seen is essential to the training of the Indian child. The general advance of the Indians to the modern civilization has been rapid and great care must be taken to enable the child to become his own judge in accepting on the one hand, the higher ideals, and on the other, to reject that which might tend to retard and degenerate his training.

Application of the child's scientific training is in a great majority of cases, and impossibility. When he graduates, he returns..."
to the reserve to settle on his little ranch, but finds that when his mind would work, his hands are tied because of lack of initial pecuniary assistance to equip his ranch with those things with which he has been taught to work. This difficulty should be looked into by those in authority and a larger opening made for this condition.

We have also to say that the Indian child has in his white brother a handicap in the fact that that confidence which the child has learned to partake of during his school days is not a strong as it might be. We therefore would ask that in conclusion, our readers will think of those who are giving their life for the uplift and advance of the aborigines of our land, and even a word of encouragement, or an act of kindness to those who have been our care, would be some reward for our energies and prayers.

We would ask, in conclusion for everyone "not to think of his own things only, but in also of the things of others."

"Our Flag".

The flag of our nation is made of three parts. One is St. George's Red Cross with a white background, the second one is St. Andrew's Cross a white cross with a blue background, and the third one is St. Patrick's Cross, a red diagonal cross with a white background. Long ago, the flag of England was only the Red Cross with a white background, then Scotland joined with England, when they had the red cross with the white cross with the blue background together for a while. Afterwards Ireland also joined with them, thus the three countries joined together with their flags to make one flag, with the three crosses. The colours of the Union Jack are Red, for bravery, white for purity, and blue for loyalty.

James Raymond.

Sense for cents.

One evening, our Principal was strolling through the Boys' basement, when he detected Henry Spinks, a humorous little individual, playing with the boys' towels. The Principal looked strongly at him, and said "Well, young fellow, what do you think you're doing?" "Where do you keep your sense?" He thought a moment and replied, "In my pocket, sir." "How much?" "Two cents, sir". The Principal laughed, and left him.

Simon Baker.

The following are compositions written by pupils of the Senior Grades as prize compositions in connection with special weeks or seasons, such as "Save the Forest Week", and the Bounty Season on Crows, etc.

"Our Forests"........Kenneth Walkem, Age 16, Grade VIII.

"The four principal trees of British Columbia are the Douglas Fir, Red Cedar, Western Hemlock, and Western Spruce.

The estimated amount of lumber in British Columbia is over 700,000,000 feet, board measure.

We are told that the last great stand of timber trees in the world are in British Columbia, and that is because all the other trees have been either burned, used up for lumber, or attacked by some disease.

The Douglas Fir is over one hundred fifty feet in height, and from four to eight feet in diameter; the Red Cedar is about one hundred fifty feet high, and four to nine feet in diameter; the Western Hemlock is about a hundred feet in height, three to six feet in diameter, and the Western Spruce is about one hundred fifty feet high and has a diameter of three to six feet.

The Red Cedar is light, red, and will not shrink or expand when dry or wet. The Hemlock is pitchless, strong, white in color, and light. The Spruce is light, while the Douglas Fir is a very tough and heavy wood."

"Our Duty to Our Forests".......Kenneth Walkem.

"Last year, in 1925, there was reported a total loss of over two million dollars by fire, and all this occurred in 2,521 fires.

Do you think we could decrease this amount? Yes, we could, but we must remember that this has been going on for fifty years.

If we let our forests burn, we will have no more timber to build our new schools and houses, and where will the poor children live. We MUST save the forests.

Don't let there be only one "Save the Forest Week" in a year. Let all the fifty-two be forest weeks.

It costs money to put fires out, but if people will take more care, there will be more money saved.

Forests give a living to millions. We must save our forests."

"The Crow, an Asset or Liability"......Janet Peters, age 17, Grade VIII.

"The Crows are birds that like to live where human habitation is, and are seldom found in barren lands.

In British Columbia, there are two kinds of crow to be found, the American and Coast Crow.

The American Crow is the most destructive of the two, as it lives farther from the coast, where the land is not densely covered with thickets, and so has more chance of getting at bird-nests; while the coast crow is less harmful.

Every year during the three months of spring is when they are the most bothersome. They destroy the birds' nests, eat their eggs, and young, none of which would be of great value as game and insectivorous birds. The marsh-nesting birds, such as grouse and pheasant are more easily destroyed as they are the most helpless.

Although the crow is so destructive, they do a little good."
"The Humble Crow"...........Peter Antoine, age 16, Grade VII.

"There is much talk about the crow these days, and people are debating whether the crow is useful or destructive. The Provincial Government has put a bounty on the crow in the hope of reducing them in numbers. They have increased in number greatly and are a menace to our useful birds.

There are two species of crow in B.C., the Coast Crow, a less destructive creature, and the American Crow, the brainiest of all birds, and very cunning in his ways, and has the reputation of a robber. In the nesting season of the birds, the crows devour young insectivorous birds, and destroy the eggs. In this way the crow is very destructive as the birds he kills, would have done ten times as much good as he would.

It seems that the only enemy of the crow is man, and the crow is very wise to man's ways. It would take a good hunter to get at them nowadays, but man takes advantage of them in the nesting season, as it is the only opportunity that man has. It seems very cruel to attack them at this time, but he is compelled to do so, in order to check their increasing numbers.

The crow is a friend in some countries and an enemy in others, and I do not know if we should condemn this creature entirely, as he is useful to a certain extent, but not enough to balance his wickedness, and therefore I think that man is only right to declare war upon this cunning black outlaw, because he preys upon many insectivorous birds that are beneficial to farmers."

"The Hawks"...............Adeline Phillips, age 16, Grade VII.

"There are eleven kinds of hawks, some are destructive and some are useful.

The destructive ones are the Cooper's Hawk, Hoshawk, Pigeon Hawk, Sharp-shinned Hawk, Hen Hawk and Duck Hawk. They should all be destroyed. The useful hawks that should not be destroyed are the Red-shouldered hawks, Red-Tailed Hawks, Marsh Hawks, Sparrow Hawks, Fish Hawks and Night Hawks. The Red-Tailed and Red-Shouldered Hawks are the biggest and yet more useful than other hawks. You may wonder why I say the Fish Hawk is useful, but it is because the fish hawks eat the dead fishes that got swept ashore by the tides.

The destructive hawks that were mentioned in the second paragraph eat the smaller birds that really do more good to the plants, than the destructive hawks, which also kill the chickens, ducks, and other barnyard species.

The useful hawks eat insects, worms, and other little harmful bugs that do nothing but destroy the crops which are so valuable to the farmer.

Some hawks should be all destroyed for they are of no value to farmers, while others should be left alone to increase in number."

"The Crow"........Joseph Antoine, age 15, Grade VII.

"The Crow is a carnivorous bird and will carry away any carcasses that he finds. He is very destructive because he steals the birds' eggs, and even kills the valuable birds around the farm, which are the farmers' friends, and even attacks the game birds."
such as grouse, pheasants, ducks, etc. The grouse is not destructive because he could kill more grasshoppers and insects in one day than a crow could in a week.

The Crow is useful for two months only, July and August, but when the grain ripens, he eats more than what he is worth.

The Crow is very cunning and follows man, and the only enemy is himself mankind.

It is said that if there are less crows, there will be more game and song birds, and the farmers will not have such a heavy loss.

Crows are regular pests pretty nearly all the year around, excepting July and August."

School news.

Quite one of the most eventful incidents of our school year was the visit of our Bishop, the Rt. Rev. Walter Adams, M.A., D.D., Lord Bishop of Cariboo, for the purpose of conferring the rite of Confirmation on one of the largest classes ever assembled at this school. The evening of April 22nd, the eve of our patronal festival of St. George, will be long remembered by many, especially the following, who that night, quite willingly and gladly, took on their own behalf, the fuller duties of the Christian Life; Elizabeth Walker, Margaret McNally, Mary Murray, Jane Brizman, Rosa Thom, Elvira Newall, Alice Clark, Eliza Edwards, Julia Marshall, Gladys Wish, Willie Smith, Norman Dunstan, Kenneth Walker, Joseph Antoine, John Brizman, Allan Pizzey, Samuel Henry, Tom George, as well as eight adult members of the white community outside of the school.

A beautifully decorated chapel formed a beautiful setting as the Bishop, vested in full robes and mitre, exhorted the candidates in the new duties that they were about to take upon themselves; then, with the words of the "Veni, Creator Spiritus" still in their hearts and minds, each candidate came forward for the "laying on of hands." The Bishop met each of the candidates after the service, and in honour of the great event, asked the Principal for a special half-holiday for all the children of the school, which request, needless to say received the unanimous applause of all the children, who hang in this manner to extend their thanks to Bishop Adams for his kindness.

---

It was on January 23rd, that the first signs of impending sickness broke out in the school, and in two weeks time the place was under quarantine for small-pox. About twenty-five of the youngsters were down with the dread plague, but we are indeed thankful and happy to say that it was of a mild type, and that thanks to the close care of Dr. Wilson, the school physician, all the children got over it well, and are now fully recovered. Two of the children developed scarlet-fever and were isolated for a while, but are fine again now. We sure do not want to have any more of that kind of trouble in St. George's.

The difference in gain between the girls and boys, although the girls are fewer in number than the boys, may be accounted for, not so much by increased interest in the drinking of milk, but by the fact that they were more seriously underweight than the boys who spend more time in outdoor occupations. The children are very pleased with their record increase and are all out to make it even greater in the half-year that this issue brings to a close. The number of children now underweight according to the American Child Health Association Scale is now negligible, and these children are receiving special attention.

Our school uses on an average of 100 quarts of milk a day, all produced from a herd of Toasted Holsteins, many of whom are pure-bred; the whole herd being quartered in a first class barn, all cattle therein being tested regularly for T.B.

It is also interesting to those interested in feeding children, that this increase of 745 lbs. cost the school exactly $2.23 to obtain, as the cost of milk, butter, and eggs for the half-year amounted to just $1700. But that it is well worth it is clearly shown in the happy faces, increased interest in study, and healthy dispositions of the children.

---

It is not often possible for the children to be entertained by outside people, on account of the distance of Lytton from the city; but we cannot let this issue appear without extending our sincere thanks and appreciation to Miss Lillian Hovay of Sheffield, England, who as the guests of Mr. and Mrs. Graham, came to the School in May, and gave an entertainment that will long be remembered by all who were privileged to attend, and we all hope that Miss Hovay will come again.

---

We are now living in hopes of the new school being started this year. The plans are completed and the surveyor has been to look over the proposed site, which is situated on the farm near the new barn. Nearly a mile from the present school, the new building will overlook the Fraser River, giving a far better location to the building than the one we are in at present. The picture on the back of this issue shows the present building which is now twenty four years of age, and is in need of immediate replacement. Just what is to be done about moving the beautiful old church which the spiritual life of the school revolves, is not yet decided, but we hope that it will be possible to move it down, as it is one of the finest church buildings in the interior of the Province.

---

We wish to extend our thanks to the various kind friends and well-wishers who wrote to us regarding our first issue. It is nice to find that our efforts to tell just what is going on here are appreciated and we hope that this issue will please all who read it.

In closing our little magazine, I would like to put in a very wonderful piece of poetry that just seems to express something that we would like to put across to the children. Mr. Buckpitt, our Junior Teacher, passed it along with this introduction:

"Friendship".

There are hermit souls that live withdrawn
In the place of their self content.
There are souls like stars that dwell apart
In a fellowless firmament.
There are pioneer souls that blaze the paths
Where highways never ran.
But let me live in a house by the side of the road
And be a friend of man.

Let me live in the house by the side of the road
Where the race of men go by.
The man who are good, the man who are bad,
As good as bad as I.
I would not sit in the scorner's seat
Nor hurl the cynic's ban.
Let me live in the house by the side of the road,
And be a friend to man.

I see from my house by the side of the road-
By the side of the pathway of life
The man who press with the ardour of hope
The man who are faint with the strife.
But I turn not away from their smiles and their tears,
Both part of an infinite plan.
Let me live in the house by the side of the road,
And be a friend to man.

I know there are gladdened meadows ahead
And mountains of wearisome height,
That the road runs on through the long afternoon
And stretches ahead into night.
But still I rejoice, when the travellers rejoice,
And step with the strangers that mean,
But let me live in my house by the side of the road,
Like a man who dwells alone.

Let me live in the house by the side of the road.
Where the race of men go by.
They are good; they are bad; they are weak; they are strong;
Wise- foolish- as I am.
Then why should I sit in the scorner's seat,
Or hurl the cynic's ban?
Let me live in my house by the side of the road
And be a friend to man.
Ottawa, June 25, 1926.

Dear Mr. Scott—

I am anxious to know whether the Dept. intends to proceed with the erection of more than one unit of the new school, as a great deal hinges on this possibility of my being able to get turned this coming year.

I have lately had a delegation of my outside staff asking if I had thought of any arrangement for the education of their children. I have on the staff four married men with families ranging in number from one to three; four of these children together with my own child are of school age and it is natural that we should become anxious.

I have for the coming winter arranged a program whereby I intend sending two of the outside staff to the University for courses on Breeding of cattle and hogs and Poultry raising. Both men approached me concerning the possibility of their continuance on the staff, owing to the above coming difficulty stating that they did not think it would be fair to the school to accept this training and perhaps in six months have to resign their positions. I of course from a business point of view could not provide this course unless a guarantee of continued service could be given. Both men are agreed to give this service provided I am in a position to provide means for the lower school education of their children. Both are good men and are good for years in the school. They have gone so far as to say that they are willing to spend their share in paying a teacher if some provision for a school room could be made.

It has been my object to make provision for these children as well as my own in the New School which could easily be done with the two units of the school built and the Principal's residence attached.

You may perhaps think there is no necessity for scientific training of outside staff but in order to compete with the scientific advance of agriculture and to run the farm and make it a financial success it is a necessity besides we are training boys to go out on ranches on the several reserves and they should be trained to make success of the work. This can only be accomplished by having a touch of scientific training during their school days.

I am interested in the work here and feel I can make a success but wider scope must be given else the School is bound to come to a standstill and I am sure this is not what the Dept. wishes any more than I do myself.

I have written re the status of our Dairy herd and it is essential that I should take every care in the development of the herd as it is now, and will in the future become more and more a great financial source but without an efficient herdman.
it cannot go forward as it should. There must be individual responsibility and interest. This Mr. Tims gives and his departure at the present time would be sadly detrimental.

While Mr. Stemp is not in immediate need of education for his child it will not be long ere he too will have to vacate his position for the same purpose.

The Farm Manager and The Handy Man are now approaching the same difficulty to say nothing of my own little girl who could readily be sent to school after next midsommer vacation, and for whom I shall have to make provision.

It is needless for me to go into other details concerning the immediate attention of getting into new quarters as these you have had and know the difficulties surrounding the work here. I can truly say that we would be much happier in our work and administration if we could expect to be rehoused in; or during the coming year.

I hesitate somewhat in presenting these things to you as you have many demands but one cannot allow them to remain in obeisance when confronted with them.

Trusting to receive a favorable reply which will allow the needed assurance to the men and will also comply with my present plans in making provision for more scientific training for the boys. With this training the men could make the work on the farm more interesting in the way of judging, maximum production, and study of soils, filling a gap in the necessary education of the boys.

Yours very obediently

[Signature]

LYTTON B.C.
THE CRUSADER.

CHRISTMAS 1926.

EDITORIAL.

A quarterly review of current events in the life of St. George's Indian Residential School, at Lytton B.C.

Once again at the approach of the festive season of Christmas, so dear to the heart of the child and grown up, we present to our readers just a summary of events that have taken place in St. George's School in the term now closing, with the hope that therein they will see signs of progress, or advancement in the work of the children. In our own small world it is sometimes hard to note progress and this sending abroad of our efforts is done with a view to receiving kindly criticism. Our thanks go out to those who so kindly wrote about our Midsummer Number, and their suggestions are deeply appreciated.

Nothing very exciting has happened in the school this term. We have more children than ever before, with a rapidly growing waiting list. This condition seems to be typical of all the residential schools, a sure sign of increased interest and desire for education on the part of the Indian people. And this interest is real, is strongly evidenced by the parents of many of our children, who constantly visit the school and urge and encourage their youngsters to greater and bigger efforts. And the children themselves seem to become more and more interested as the years go by, and now that we have started to get pupils into High School the work should broaden and become more intense. It is not easy to teach Indian Children, they are tremendously handicapped; but they do try; they are the whole very very good, and they want to learn. So it is worth while.

The children are all looking forward with the keenest anticipation to the annual visitation of childhood's greatest hero, Santa Claus himself and we hope that it will be possible to give them just as good a time as they have ever had, and better if we can.

So in closing we would like to wish all our friends the true blessings of Christmas with the hope that the New Year will be one of success and fulfillment of hopes, and we ask you to remember us at St. George's, to think of the children, to pray and hope for them that they may reach manhood and womanhood, filled with health, of success, spiritual and material which will enable them to go forth as leaders of their race and tribe.

Editor,

A CHRISTMAS MESSAGE

From The Principal

THE hands of Time's clock have again made the complete circuit and we find ourselves approaching Christmas of 1920. It seems only but a short period since our message of this season one year ago was asked for.

During the year changes have taken place. We miss old faces that now have taken their place. Our numbers have increased. We are thankful and trustful that all has been God guided and while we visualise these additions and changes we realise that in our lives there enters again, in a deeper sense at Christmastide the Babe in Bethlehem stall. The year has brought its changes but in that Child we find no change. We can truly say that "through all the changing scenes of life there is one 'who changeth not' but whom is the same Christ Child 'Yesterday today and forever'." He is still the One whose face is radiant with God given love, still the Saviour Who, although with Him no change is found, has seen the scenes of changing hearts and minds in years gone by, and we find ourselves one as "He is one", sometimes perhaps with hearts wrapped in swathing clothes yet one as found in Him. This thought brings us closer to each other and although changes have taken place we find, influenced by the Christmas message of last year, we who are left of the old together with the new, have on the whole prepared ourselves for a brighter and happier Christmas now upon us.

We need not repeat again the message of last Christmastide but bid ourselves call to mind what was said and in a wider sense find the Christ Child in our work, in our play and in our worship, so that with hearts and minds uplifted by the Holy touch we may not hesitate to chant again, with the angel hosts,

"PEACE ON EARTH GOOD WILL TO MEN!"

Mr and Mrs Lott and Staff wish all the boys and girls and all our friends

A MERRY CHRISTMAS

and

A BRIGHT AND HAPPY NEW YEAR.

A CHRISTMAS LEGEND by Kenneth Walkem.

When the three wise men set out on their journey to bring presents to the King, they stopped for a night at a jolly, red nosed man's house. The man told his wife to give the men something to eat and make the beds ready for them to retire. When morning came he asked the three wise men where they were going.

They told their story of the Child Jesus who was to be their future King, and they were going to bring Him presents, and the star was their guide. The jolly red nosed man said "I will bring Him presents too, but I will start to-morrow". The next morning he started out, but there was no star to guide him. So he traveled and traveled until one night he stopped at a lady's house. She had a little boy so he thought that it might be the child he was looking for, so he gave his presents to the child, but the mother told him that the child he was looking for was still far away.

So now he still travels and travels looking for the Child Jesus until now. Every Christmas he comes down the chimneys to bring presents to the boys and girls, so he might happen to give a present to the King.

So this man whose name is Santa Claus still travels around the world and he is the oldest man on earth. Just you take a look at his white hair and beard next time you see him, but he has not lost his red nose and he is as jolly as ever.

Joan of Arc by Eva Tooney.

Once upon a time there was a French girl named Joan. She lived with her father and mother. One night Joan went to bed and dreamed that a voice was calling her to help in the war against the English, so she jumped up and told her father about it, but he only laughed and said "What can a girl do in the war?"

At last she persuaded her father to let her go. When the English soldiers saw Joan carrying the Fleur-de-lis in the lead of the French army they thought she was a witch and turned around and fled from their enemies.

When King Charles of France heard of Joan he said that she must stay and help them in their wars. The next time the English troops came they seized the French soldiers and put Joan in prison, and afterwards put her to death by burning her slowly as a witch.

The French will always remember Joan of Arc for her gallant deeds.

LAURA SECORD'S BRAVERY by Ethel Bertrand.

James Secord a Canadian, lay sick when he heard the plans of the Americans. Only twenty miles away his fellow men were waiting death and there was no way of warning them. "They must die for lack of warning" he said to his wife. But Laura offered to go, for she was brave and loved her country.

Her journey began hour by hour she walked and scrambled onward. The sun sank, but still she journeyed, until at last her labour ended. The Indians rushed at her from behind a tree, then she thought her labour was of no use and that death was to be her fate. But she soon saw that they were friendly to her and led her to the officer who listened to her story. They lauded her for warning them and brought her to a farm near by to rest.

The officer made new plans and at the dawn of day the battle began and lasted for two hours than the Americans gave up the fight with the Canadians, and even to this day Laura Secord's brave deed is still remembered.

VANCOUVER IN THE YEAR 2000. by Rosie Cisco.

The city of Vancouver was named after the great explorer Captain George Vancouver, who explored around the South Coast of British Columbia in the year 1791-1792.

Vancouver's population at present is 117,000, but it will increase in the years to come. It is situated near the coast and has a port where exporting and importing is carried on to a great extent from all parts of the world, all through the year.

In 73 more years, Vancouver will develop into one of Canada's greatest cities, airplanes will take the place of automobiles and electric trains will be invented, that will go at the rate of a hundred miles an hour or more.

Those who wish to live in Vancouver in the year 2000 will have to keep their health rules.

I hope those who read the story above won't consider me as a prophet, for I only hope to draw your attention to what I imagine Vancouver will look like in 73 more years.

A FRENCH EXPLORER. by John James

In the year 1678, La Salle one of the great heroes of France set out to explore a vast river which was called afterwards the Mississippi River. For company our hero had with him a brave Italian officer, Tomi, two missionaries, a ship called The Griffin, and a few Indian guides.

He sailed from Montreal down through the great lakes to Lake Michigan, but when he reached there he found out that the food supplies were not enough for the expedition. So with an officer in command he sent The Griffin back to Montreal for more supplies.

When the boat had been absent for a long period La Salle
It was approaching winter, so La Salle decided to walk on with his little band on foot and after having a long and weary walk, he stopped at a place on the bank of the Illinois River. Here La Salle left his men, retraced his footsteps back to Montreal for to get food. In his absence, the mates he left behind were attacked by the Iroquois Indians and on La Salle's return he found that only a few of his men were left. So with the few men who were left La Salle set off once more in a small canoe that he had brought with him down that icy and dangerous river, but after toiling for some days the rapids soon became at ease and it got wider and wider until at last La Salle filled with great joy saw before him the shimmering blue waters of the Gulf of Mexico. For having reached there in safety they all sang praises to God, and built a pillar on which they floated the Flag of France.

La Salle thought that it would be better to colonize the area he had explored and build a city at the mouth of the river. With this in mind he went back to Quebec and sailed back to France to tell the news to the French Government. The government was very pleased to hear this and the following year scores of men were sent over to build the city, La Salle in command.

As they sailed down the St Lawrence River and through the lakes they stopped at an old fort. While in the fort some of his men grew mutinous and one of the ringleaders of the mutineers stabbed La Salle in the back and that was the end of this great hero-explorer of New France.

Florence Nightingale

Florence Nightingale was born in a small village of Derbyshire, and while yet a little girl, everybody noticed how kind she was to animals and poor people.

One day a shepherd was going to shoot his dog because he thought it's leg was broken, but Florence Nightingale came to its rescue by bathing its leg and finding out that it was only badly bruised.

She spent her youth in learning how to nurse the sick and care for the poor. So when the Crimean war broke out she went with some trained nurses to care for the wounded soldiers who were in bad need of proper care.

We think of her as one of the bravest women we know and are proud of her, as she was the first lady to establish a hospital for wounded and poor.

MADALINE'S BRAVERY.

BY

Gladys Wish.

IN New France a fort had been built by settlers who left it along with two soldiers and an old man, women and children. Madaline and her brothers were amongst them. Madaline was only fourteen years old.

The girl thought it was safe to go outside the fort so she went out to the river's edge. She had not been there long when she heard a yell from the woods. Knowing the Indians came to attack them she ran quickly to the fort which seemed so far away. She shouted for help but none came to her aid.

Madaline got inside the fort and was safe; but for only a little while. She saw logs had fallen from the walls so she asked them to help her put them back. When they had done this Madaline went to where they kept the gunpowder. There she saw the two soldiers one holding a match which was lighted. Madaline asked what he was going to do, he said he was going to blow the house up. "You coward!" Madaline said "go and help us fight the Indians". The soldiers went.

Madaline took a gun for herself and gave one to each of her two brothers and told them to fight for their lives. They had been fighting all day but when night came the Indians went away thinking there were more than a hundred men. Madaline being the Captain put her little bunch at their posts, and told them to keep up during the night. All had been quiet for a part of the night and then one of the soldiers called Madaline and showed her dark figures outside, which they found out afterwards to be cattle which had not been captured by the enemy. They brought these cattle in one by one in case the Indians had been hiding behind them.

They had been fighting for six days now and were very tired at last Madaline sat down and went to sleep. When she woke up she heard heavy footsteps, so she ran out to the gate and said "Who's there", they replied "France". Madaline was very glad so she opened the gate for them. They had come to help these people so Madaline and her friends were relieved from their task in keeping the fort from being destroyed by the enemy.

Sir:

I am just in receipt of a copy of a letter sent you by the Rev. A.R. Lett, principal of St. George's Indian Industrial School, in which he is pointing out the difficulties under which he is laboring, and asking about the prospects for the new school building.

Mr. Lett talked this over with me, and is most anxious, if possible, to try to get the two units built this coming spring, as the appropriation was not passed last spring, which necessitated the postponement of the building for a year, so he is wondering whether it would be possible to have what was expected to be appropriated last year added to this coming year's appropriation, and thus get the two units built at the one time.

I might state that Mr. Lett is doing excellent work and working up both the school and the farm. Things are certainly in a far more satisfactory state than they ever have been, and I certainly would like to see the start of a new building. Dear Mr. Scott,

In view of the scientific advance of the Agricultural Industry throughout the Dominion, necessitated by forced competition internationally, it is my belief that wherever possible this spirit of advance should be fostered in our Indian Schools.

Our Indian population throughout the Dom. if properly equipped in districts where agriculture predominates, could be taught to take care of a part of this vast industry. This training can be readily and successfully handled through the schools established by the Dept. for the education of the Indian child.

This training would vary according to situation and should be adapted to natural climatic production and change of surrounding individualized production, for e.g., we in B.C. must adapt an extensive mixed farming training while in the middle west a scientific knowledge of wheat growing.

It seems to me that this is, every day, becoming a great need from two points of view.

1. Wherever a farm is connected with the school, no matter how large or small it may be, it cannot be run in a hap-hazard manner else it will soon become a liability instead of an asset and the Dept. will be obliged to carry it at a severe loss. The day even of a successful practical farmer has passed, and he finds that he must accept science with it else he finds himself at the wrong end of his financial sheet. This I am afraid has been the case with many of our school farms and except we observe scientific production, and everything that goes with it, we cannot produce the required marketing standard in order to compete with producer who is alive to the assets of scientific production grading and etc., and who by his quick adaptation of science acquires the highest value for his production.

This year at the school we produced thirty-two head of select hogs on which we made a clear profit of three hundred and twenty-five dollars. These pigs were all marketed before they were six months old and commanded a premium of two cents a lb. for select. I also had one batch of pure bred Birks two of this batch I sold for herd sires to ranchers in the neighborhood and brought me ten dollars each over the marketing value. Three sows I have kept for breeding and the remainder sold as selects.

This condition is applicable to every branch of the farm and pays in every case.

2. The training would give greater interest to the Boys in their work. They could be taught judging of animals; judging and sel-
of poultry; judging and selection of seed; grading of fruit and
etc.

It would also equip the boy to take care of his future in
giving him trained scope to compete with his white neighbor
and in many cases take away from him the fact that, espe-
cially in this province, he is obliged to look to foreign
element for his training. On the other hand be obliged to work
for undesirable instead of becoming a citizen worthy of the
Indian Departmental School.

This year I have planned to send two of the men employed
as instructors to the University for Short Courses in Agri-
culture and will perhaps take one myself if it is possible
for to work it in. In this manner I could with no great ex-
pense begin opening up the way for such training as is neces-
sary to keep the school on a scientific productive standard
and also to give the boys a trained opening into a lively-
hood wherein they would stand not as wards of the Dept.,
but as independent citizens needing no help other than their
school training and perhaps an initial start. This latter of
course governed by the aptitude and general display of interest
and etc., the boy shows in his school period.

The courses this year following each other it will not mean
extra help as during the winter months things are a little
slack and the regular work can be easily carried on with the
remaining members of the staff hence the expense incurred
will not exceed railway and streetcar fare board and lodging.

This would amount approximately from fifty to sixty dollars
for each man, and I would be greatly obliged if the Dept could
see fit to carry the expense incurred.

I am firmly convinced that this course of procedure will
in every way help us over a number of difficulties.

I wish to thank you for interest taken and trust the New
Year will bring with it many prosperities for the Dept.

Yours very obediently

Sir:

Herein, I would like to draw to your attention some of the conditions existing at St. George's Industrial School.

The boys and girls dormitories are both over-crowded and the ventilation is wholly inadequate. The boys dormitory is so poorly lighted and dark that very little sunlight enters the room. The beds are so close together, in both dormitories that there is scarcely room to get between them.

The heating system cannot supply the necessary heat, during the colder months.

Water has to be drawn at times and pails used to flush the toilets. With this condition, toilets have become plugged and overflowed and the contents have leaked through to the basement.

The laundry, I do not consider fit for any person to work in, particularly in cold weather. The floor which is of boards built on the ground is falling in, in places, and the building is in such a state of dilapidation that wind blows through it. The children working in the building are cold, while breathing-in damp steamy air.

Since school opened last fall, seven cases of Pulmonary Tuberculosis have developed among the children. I think that the conditions cited above are to be seriously considered as predisposing factors to the development of this disease, to which Indians are very susceptible.

These conditions have existed since my coming here over three years ago, but as there have been rumors from time to time, of a new school being built, I have hesitated about writing you.

The Principal is doing the very best he can under existing circumstances, and it is only, I think, the fact that he has hesitated in adding expense to the Department that he has carried on to this period. Furthermore he has intimated his resignation if conditions are not changed.

As Health Officer, for this district, I will have no hesitancy in recommending the condemnation of the present buildings if some move is not made to better conditions before the beginning of the next term. The only remedy is, the erection of a new school, which should be proceeded with, without further delay.

Indian Agent,
