AN EASTER MESSAGE FROM MR. LETT.

The Editor of our school magazine suddenly appears before me, intimating that an Easter message would not be out of place. A busy principal wonders what he shall give.

A thought of the past three months brings with it the passing of a strenuous winter, during which sickness has left its mark among the children. Two, our Father, in His infinite mercy, has called others home unfit for school work. New faces have appeared to take their places. So the quarter has gone emerging in Springtime and Easter, the former with its sunshine and flowers, the beauty of God's creation; the latter with its message that one day all shall meet again in the glorious and triumphant resurrection. Difficulties arise, sorrows sorrow fill the heart, vacancies appear; but to us, as to Mary Magdalene in the garden, a risen Christ spoke: "He Is Risen". Only these three words, but what a meaning. Members of the Staff, children and readers, what a warmth of comfort and assurance the words carry. A living Jesus to cheer our way, to guide our goings, to listen to our prayers and help us over our difficulties. These words however full of meaning can take their place. How beautifully the thought blends with the life of Spring, everywhere presenting itself. Surely we should be thankful for the life that lives and truly sing on Easter Morn, with hearts of love and joy:

"Christ is Risen, Christ is Risen, He hath burst His bonds in twain"
"Christ is Risen, Christ is Risen, Alleluia! Swell the Strain."
Arising to the feelings of one who has grasped in reality the supreme thought, "Christ is not dead but He is alive forevermore."

EFFECT OF HABIT. SOME DESIRABLE HABITS

"Habit is a cable. We weave a thread of it each day, and it becomes so strong we cannot break it."

Scientists tell us that each thought and act of mind leaves a path on the brain. Repeated actions deepen this path and makes it more difficult to act in another line, and easier to follow the beaten path. An education along any line is but the result of path making. We can see, then, the importance of making paths both good and true, and of changing very quickly when a wrong course is begun.

During the early years of our life we may acquire good habits nearly as easy as careless ones, so in our daily actions we need to have this object in view above all others—character building.

A few of these desirable habits we should all strive to acquire, as follows:

1. The habit of happiness.
2. The habit of thoroughness.
3. The habit of neatness in our work.
4. The habit of promptness.
5. The habit of politeness.
6. The habit of appreciation.
7. The habit of attention.
8. The habit of cleanliness.
9. The habit of thoughtfulness.
10. The habit of pleasure in work well done.
11. The habit of correct speaking.
12. The habit of unselfishness.
13. The habit of mastering difficulties and not complaining.
14. The habit of telling the exact truth.
ACTIVITIES AMONG THE GIRLS.

It seems but yesterday since we were exchanging Xmas and New Year greetings and now these winter days lie far behind us and Spring is in the air. We have had a number of ups and downs among the girls in the last three months. First of all we had the flu epidemic which drove more than half our number to bed when we were all nicely better, hence made its cruel attack and has been most reluctant to leave us. Now everyone is getting quite chirpy again with the exception of two girls still in hospital and we trust they will soon be better and back amongst us.

During the winter we commenced a course of lectures on First Aid and sick nursing for the seniors. Everyone was very enthusiastic and entered into this important study with great zest.

We have also had special nights for drill games and basketball, these evenings I need hardly add were enjoyed to the full.

Just at present our entire energy is being devoted to our concert which we hope to give about the end of April. The seniors are giving a dialogue which includes songs, pianoforte solo recitations etc. The 'Sons' are doing their bit too and working hard with their singing and hope to cheer everyone up with their "Songs of the Fair". Last but not least we come to the tiny tots. These little ones have worked splendidly this winter and just now they are passing away with their fun drill and action songs and they wonder if you will like them in their fairy costumes.

Our week end rambles get more and more interesting, for each time there is some fresh token of Spring to cheer us on our way, and as we climb up and up through the scented pines we feel that it is good to be alive and able to enjoy all the beauties of God's wonderful world.

IN MEMORIAM

We were all exceedingly touched by the passing over of Mary Clarke. Her sweet and gentle manner made her greatly beloved by the girls, and we shall miss her very much.

One of our older boys, Samuel Justice, has also been recently called from our midst, and is greatly missed by all of us.

SPRING'S MESSENGER.

I met a merry little breeze Then o'er the meadows swift it flew,
As it went gaily by, I heard it whisper to the trees, This little mused breeze,
"Lo! Spring is coming nigh." Arousing every flower it knew.

Then bending low I heard it say And waking all the trees,
To the sleeping flower beds, Until at last the whole wide earth
"Awake! Awake! Spring's on the way, Was clad in garments fair,
Come, raise your dainty heads." And Spring itself had given birth
To blossoms everywhere.
THE CADET CORPS.

The work of the Cadet Corps during the past five months has been full of interest, pleasure, and profit for boys and instructors alike. The course of training is extensive and varied covering such subjects as Squad Drill, Physical Training, Signalling, lectures on First Aid, Health and Hygiene; Clean Speech, Sport, and Living, and last but not least Basket Ball, Volley Ball, and baseball games, all of which go a long way in developing a boy's body, mind and character.

At first our Physical Training and games were confined to Tuesday and Thursday evenings, but it was soon found that this was impracticable as the number of boys was too great for the limited space in the play room where our drills and games are held. In order then to get the greatest possible good out of our work, the classes were divided into Juniors and Seniors in the afternoons taking P.T. and games from 4-45 to 6-35. The seniors and the juniors who work in the afternoons taking the evening classes at 7-15.

The boys right from the beginning have shown wonderful aptitude in learning the new exercises, so much so that now they can go through all of the 40 different exercises 32 times each in their proper order with very few words of command or instruction.

In the past few weeks we have been practicing building pyramids for our concert which we hope will take place next month.

After the P.T., the juniors play basket ball quite a number of whom are showing signs of becoming really good players before another season comes around. The seniors in their snappy white Gym suits play after the juniors. They play a series of five games, the team winning every out of five are declared the winner of the series.

Now that the evenings are getting longer we will soon be practicing squad drill and signalling outside where we will have more scope.

The boys have shown a great interest in the First Aid lectures and demonstrations which are given on Monday and Friday evenings in the dormitory. Talks on Health and Hygiene, and on Clean Speech, Sport, and Living are also given on these evenings and are having an influence on the lives of the boys.

Besides Basket ball the boys now play baseball and volley ball at every opportunity. We expect to begin a series of games with the boys from Lytton in the near future.

About the end of Feb. a system of prefects was instituted the following five boys being elected by ballot. Norman Dunstan head prefect, Simon Baker Charles James Kenneth Wallis and Raymond Thorpe. They are responsible for promoting a good feeling amongst the boys and creating a spirit of loyalty to the School. Each Prefect has his own particular duties to perform in connection with the work of the Chapel School and Farm, and so far has been very successful.

We have had a few hikes since Christmas, the first one was to the Rabbitry an account of it will be found elsewhere in this issue. The Flu' and the bumps put an end to our hikes for a time but since then the boys have been to Lytton two or three times, across the river twice and once on a moonlight hike up the 47 road. We left the school about 9 o'clock and went quite a way up the mountain behind the school stopping now and again to admire the wonderful view of the mountains across the river. We got back about 9-15 everyone having enjoyed the outing very much.

We will soon be starting training and getting into shape for Sports Day on the 24th of May when the boys expect to break a few "world records".

HEALTH HABITS.

Most defects in children, yes in grown-ups too, are due to our general ignorance of the laws of health. Getting rid of these bodily defects is only the beginning of health work. Every machine not only needs occasional repairs but must have plenty of good fuel and oil and frequent cleaning in order to do its best work. In like manner the human body must always be given opportunity to renew its activities from day to day by rest, sleep and proper health habits.

These health habits are as old as the hills. They have been necessary for health for ages, and their faithful practice has kept wild animals in an enviable state of physical perfection. Human life, however, has lately become so complicated by the many discoveries and inventions and offers such a great choice of conduct that we need supervision and guidance in our daily programme, in order that the doing of a few things which make for health may become regular and habitual.

A few of these habits are as follows:

1. Eating the right foods at the right time.
2. Sleeping until fully refreshed and taking needed rest between times.
3. Breathing pure air and seeking the sunlight.
4. Vigorous of body and mind.
5. Regular use of the toilet.
6. Keeping clean without.
7. Keeping in good humour.

Such habits are simple and easy enough for the child of any age, if conditions for their practice are kept favorable. By practising them ourselves and encouraging their practice at home and school, we can do much to develop the right type of happy, healthy, young Canadians.

KEEPING FIT

Breathe deeply when in the open; breath is life. Every breathing means an even pulse. Anger and jealousy shorten the breath and shorten life, because they disturb the circulation and interfere with digestion. Bathe regularly; thus is the skin kept active and elimination made easy and natural. Drink a glass of warm water before breakfast and before bed. As for your enemies, forget them. Besides your daily work have a hobby—music, chess, books, gardening, riding. Every day read a little poetry, look upon a beautiful picture, hear a piece of choice music. These things love the soul; they rest and they refresh.

Mary Ann Phillips.

If we were to examine the trees found in this locality we should find that which largely predominates is the Western Yellow Fir, or commonly called the Bull Pine. I shall give you a few facts about this tree:

TO TELL WASPS FROM BEES.

The bees live through the winter because they have lots of honey to eat, but the wasps don't have anything to eat so they all die, except their queen. The wasps' nests are made of paper which they make of wood; the bees' homes are made of wax. Both wasps' and bees' nests cells are six-sided. Wasps always eat anything they can like people but they can't eat honey. They eat sugar when they can't find honey. Bees have kind of a tan color, lighter than the wasps, which are yellow. The bees are shorter than the wasps. The bees are always inside boxes or their own hives but wasps live outside. People don't keep wasps. The wasps always have their cells turned downwards but bees put theirs straight up and down, so the little ones won't fall out.

Joy Dunstan.

THE HUDSON BAY RAILWAY.

As the government has lately started work on the Hudson Bay Railway, I will try to write a brief note on that railway.

You would think that a railway track was always level and the rails always parallel, but this one is different from those of other railways. It is winding, sliding, and looping, and is crazier than any one you have ever been on. Often the train will run off the track or stop for repairs, which takes a lot of work for the section-men, who are our track makers.

In order to come this railway will be of great importance, it will be able to bring manufactured goods of Europe right to the back door of the prairies. It is 670 miles from the centre of the prairies to Edmonton, the terminus of the railway, and about 2,000 miles to Montreal.

Silk is manufactured from cocoons spun by which are raised in China and Japan. These silk worms are kept and fed with mulberry leaves until they spin their cocoons. The Japanese get these and pull the silk very carefully so it will not go to pieces.

CARRYING MAIL IN NORTHERN B.C.

The men and women who live in the very cold northern part of our province are very glad to get their mail. In the summer it clears up and the mailman has a much easier time than in the winter. He has a very dangerous job but I guess he likes it. In the spring, when the ice is breaking up, he has to carry the mail on canoes and these are often upset in the rough rivers. In the winter he carries the mail on sledges which sometimes slip over the mountain-side. Once in a great while the mailman has passengers. He is quite happy then as he can talk to them. At times a mounted policeman goes with him. Once he took with him a murderer and a mounted police. The murderer's name was Davis. He had killed his partner but couldn't be buried alive on account of the frozen soil. He kept the frozen body in his cellar but he was out of luck for the mounted police passed that way. He asked where the partner was and asked other questions then got a little suspicious when he heard the answers to his questions. He made a search and of course found the body and arrested his murderer. Even bishops travel across the frozen north to preach to and confirm Indian children. They have missionary stations up there. I wouldn't like to live there myself.

Henry Jacott.

Extracts from "Readers" by J. B. Priestley:

We are often addressed as "gentle reader" but never as "ardent reader". Yet real enjoyment of literature requires an "ardent reader". We are too apt to think or read as the most passive of our pursuits and to forget that, though it demands a passive body, it requires a most active and adventurous mind.

We are all readers now-a-days; that is we all devour masses of print, but there is reading and READING. The average educated person of today probably scans more words in a day than a scholar, a man absolutely devoted to learning, of four centuries ago. But let us ask ourselves are we really reading, are we engaged in an active pursuit, rambling with another mind, living strenuously for the time being in another world or are we merely staring at print with only part of our mind engaged. The latter type of reader will be satisfied with almost any rubbish, but the former literature will not do at all because it has no much it is a tonic, not something to doze over, something to keep a person from thinking, as is a great mass of our books and magazines of today.

The reading of these literary masterpieces however, demands an arduous and adventurous spirit. We first must master the words, then the thoughts and pictures to be reproduced in our imagination. Then there is the progress of the story to be followed, its scenes lived in the mind, its emotion caught and felt. Consider what adventures the mind undertakes in such reading and then dare to say that this is a pursuit for an idle hour, first cousin to an after-dinner nap.

Should we be fortunate enough to meet the author even the most unlettered person amongst us would be quivering with excitement and enchanted by his words. But in his book we have something that his friends never had, we have him hour after hour at his topmost height, his tales shaped and refined by art, his thoughts purified and perfectly phrased.

To the ardent reader, then, good books are the gateways to real adventures.

Simon Baker.

On New Year's afternoon, Mr. Henderson took about fifteen boys for a visit to the Rabbitry which is about a mile and a half from here. It took us about twenty-five minutes to walk it, as the road was wet and muddy which made it a little difficult in walking. Some of the little boys who went were behind us walking fast, trying to keep up with us. As we were nearing the Rabbitry we saw five cows grazing beside the road, three of which were white in color. We took a rest for awhile where a sign was put up for the Rabbitry. We went down a road which led towards the river a little ways and we reached the Rabbitry. Just as we met in the gate we saw a sawmill which is run by an old fashioned engine which has been there for about five years. When we reached the place where the rabbits were Mrs. Dewdney took us around showing us the rabbits and telling us the different names and some other things.

First we looked over the ones which were in the barn. They are kept in there for the purpose of breeding. There were another bunch or about a hundred yards away from the barn which were kept in a handy box. The boxes are moved to a different place daily. It leaves the manure just where it is and the rabbits have their box clean. The ones in the barn are harder to clean than the formula is done at morning and evening. They are fed with hay and chop.

They have eight different kinds of specimens which are as follows: Squirrel, New Zealand, Silver Tavern, Chinchilla, which are the majority of the rabbits, Silver Glaciers Havana Silver Blue Cosmos and Blue Cosmos, a new breed which is also called Silver Tips. A lot of the rabbits had very excellent fur. Some of them won First Prize at the Vancouver Fair.

We spent over an hour at the rabbitry during that time we had looked over all the rabbits that they had about 300. Some of them are for meat and some for fur. Their fur is worth from $10-00 up and a pair of rabbits is also worth from $10-00 up.

There are also 15 or 20 chickens and two goats at the rabbitry one of the goats being milked twice daily.

THE LIFE OF ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON

Hazel Phillips Grade VI.

The life of Robert Louis Stevenson shows how weak and courageous can overcome everything. Almost from his birth in the year 1850 he was handicapped. Because of his mother's ill-health he grew up as a sickly child. He spent his childhood in his nursery, gazing through the window at the busy streets below.

His old nurse would tell him fantastic stories of Scottish peasant life.

When his parents took him away from school, he accompanied them on their journeys in England and through the continent of Europe, and sometimes would write down anything that was interesting.

While he was at the University in Edinburgh, his friends judged him by his ungainly walk and untidy clothes and they considered the shall of more importance than the kernel. They did not take notice of the hours he used to spend with pen and paper figuring some difficult problem of composition not to make a reward but to attain a far distant goal. In this way who could later see the wonderful faith in his own talent which characterized his whole life.

His parents next forced him to study for the law in which he managed to pass his final examination with credit.

He wrote more and more industriously and finally won had some of his works published. When he was 23 years old his health broke down completely and even his life was "dispirited," but mind conquered body and he recovered enough strength to struggle bravely, on his self chosen path.

He left Scotland and went to live in London and Paris and there he found more appreciation.

The first of his writings of any account which reached publication appeared in 1876 when he was 26 years old. These were essays which were afterwards put together and entitled "Vitrinibus Pudicisque" and familiar stories of men and books. These showed that his toil was bearing fruit. Even these were coldly received by the public. In the next two years he managed to get a little over $200-00 for the first time.

After fourteen years R.L.Stevenson attained his ambition and fame. He now took his place at the head of a band of English writers who were greatly encouraged by his example. He crossed the Atlantic for the second time to New York and there he made a great success. Then he sailed to Honolulu and from there to Samoa. He bought an estate and lived there for the remaining fourteen years of his life. These last four years were filled with many great works. One of his best books is "Catriona" and best of all is "Weir of Hermiston" unfortunately he did not finish it.

Few men of note have been more criticized in their early days and more honored in their later ones.

BRIDGING SYDNEY HARBOR.

At Sydney New South Wales spanning the entrance to its magnificent harbor, one of the world's largest bridges is under construction. As this work so closely resembles the proposed bridge over the Lions Gate Vancouver, it might be interesting to know about this bridge. Sidney's bridge, the contract for which was let in 1926, has been under discussion for fifty years. In fact the first reported design seems to have been prepared by Mr Peter Anderson. His scheme however was not carried through as the people were afraid that if two bullock wagons happened to meet in the centre the structure would collapse.

Meanwhile the population of Sidney was increasing at an enormous rate until today it is 1,250,000. By 1921 traffic had increased across the harbor from 16,500,000 to 42,000,000 passengers and it was admitted on both sides that something must be done immediately. The contract calls for construction to be carried on from both sides at once, the bridge to be completed in five years that is by 1931. Certain of the lighter steel materials must be made in Australia, the granite for the foundations must be taken from New South Wales quarries. Already 150 men are employed in these quarries and will be for the next five years. It is anticipated that the undertaking will provide work for 1500 men for several years.

THE LEGEND OF THE CHILICAT BLANKET

In mythical times the daughter of a chief went out with a party of women to search for wild fowl. Stepping in a bear track she loosened her pack and impatiently cursed the bear family in gnarls. She started to adjust the pack and lost composure. Dusk was coming on, and she heard a footstep behind her. Turning around she found herself in the embrace of a youth. He whispered soft words in her ear; he was handsome; it was dusk; she followed him to his house to become his wife. Deep in the forest they reached a village of bears where she learned her husband was of that tribe.

Eventually she escaped and flew to the shore. Seeing a fishing boat she cried for help. But the fisherman would not approach until she promised to be his wife. When he touched the canoe with his killing club and the vessel sprang to land, the woman stepped in just as the bear and his friends emerged from the woods. The rescuer was human but was the benevolent sea-spirit Chilicat.

The canoe, with its occupant, now put out to sea, and descended to the bottom where the spirit lived in a great stone house. He told the woman he was already married to the Lynx but he would kill her, as she ate human flesh and was cruel to man. Upon arriving he wrapped the woman in his canoe-mat and carried her through to the rear apartment. He told her not to pay any attention to anything she might see or hear but she passed through. She saw the Lynx wife weaving a beautiful robe. This first Chilicat blanket.

METHOD OF WEAVING CHILICAT BLANKETS

Anyone looking at the forms overleaf would at once say that they were those used in painting, never in weaving. Naturally, for these Indians did all their weaving of this type from painted models. Before a woman attempted to do the weaving she would get some old man, known to be artistic, to make her the pattern-board. This would be on the same scale as the final blanket but would consist of only the right side. As the woman worked she would measure off, exactly, the distance off a colour she wished to make. Two blankets can often be seen with barely a stitch of difference.

These blankets were woven only by the northern Indians and they had plenty of whale or goat wool. To shear the coat they first killed and skinned it; the women could now pluck off wool and hair, throwing away the latter. The women would squat down with a basket of this wool and roll it into a thread on the thigh with the palm of the hand. Then there were elaborate ceremonies in connection with dyeing the wool. Only three colours were used, black, yellow, and blue. The blue was obtained from copper, the black from huckleberry, and the yellow from a kind of moss. Where two colours met the uneven edge was embroidered in white, as can be seen in a coloured picture.

All this careful work was done by hand. It would take about a year for a woman to make one blanket and she would use three goat skins. Although a blanket brings good European money, women can make many in other ways such as in the cannery. This is a pity but it will be even more of a pity when the British Columbians of the future have to go to Berlin or London to study the work of their own Indians. However most of this work is outside the province.

Paper making is an important industry of British Columbia.
A great deal is made at Powell River, because there is plenty of
wood around there. The hemlock is the tree that is used for making
paper. First the tree is cut into small bits; then washed until it
is clean; after that it is boiled, stirred, and beaten into pulp.
Then it gets pressed with some kind of a machine and made into
paper.

Paper is not only made from wood, but also from grass and
reeds, but the cheapest kind is from wood. That is why so much of
it is used.

Paper is used for a great many things. Some of these are
reading books, school books, newspapers, writing paper, etc.

In the olden days paper was so valuable and scarce that the
people used to chain their books, but now there are heaps of them
and they don't cost as much as they did, since it is far easier
to get the paper.

I beg to acknowledge your telegram dated April 29th, as follows:

"Jim Baker dead body going down tomorrow C.P.R., leaving here 1.30. I shall pay all expenses here. Is there any tribal or any other fund whereby I may get a refund."

In regard to this matter I beg to say that I arranged for the removal of the body to the undertaking parlors of Harron Bros., North Vancouver, to await arrangements for burial, on Saturday the 26th. ult. On Sunday, May 1st, I received a telephone message from Mr. Andrew Paul, Secretary of the Squamish Tribe, stating that a new casket would be required for the burial of Jim Baker. I telephoned to Harron Bros., undertakers, to find out the reason for this request and was informed by them that whoever shipped the body from Lytton crammed the remains into a coffin which was too short by eight or ten inches, and that the relatives were greatly disturbed on this account and had demanded that a new coffin be supplied so that the body may be buried decently. Mr. Paul was to have been at my office by appointment at ten o'clock this morning to further discuss the matter but up to the present moment - 4:30 P.M. - he has not arrived. I understood from him that the Indians wish the Department to pay for the additional service.

In answer to your enquiry as to whether any funds are available for a refund of the expenses incurred by you, I wish to say that if the body had been shipped in a decent and proper manner I would gladly have recommended to the Department reimbursement of any reasonable expenses from the funds of the Squamish Band as the boy Baker was an orphan and therefore

Rev. A. R. Lett,
Principal, St. George's School,
Lytton, B.C.
May 2, 1927.

in the indigent class. Before I can take further action
I would like to have a report from you on the subject.

Yours sincerely,

(G.C. Perry)
INDIAN AGENT.

P.S. I have since ascertained from Harron Bros.,
undertakers, that the Indians who accompanied the body to
Vancouver called their attention to the fact that the
casket was too short, and that is the reason why they
promised to look into it and opened the box.
Dear Mr. Perry:

Your letter of chastisement received and must hasten to say that I am extremely sorry this trouble has occurred. It really has added to my weariness over the loss of so many children this winter. I have to date lost from the school 13 children 6 of whom I buried within the past three weeks. I held out hopes for Jim to the very last as he was so robust and STRONG.

I personally helped put his body in the casket. The undertakers evidently made a mistake in my order as when we went to put the body in it was short but with a little elevation of the knees it seemed quiet comfortable and I did not really think that there would be any necessity for re coffining. If I had thought this I certainly would have returned it for another.

Simon was with me and I asked him to tell his grandmother of the shortness. I really was at a loss to know what to do as perhaps none others were in stock and the matron wishing to get the body away. The grandmother also wished to get away so that she could bury on Sunday.

This occurring has given me an added feeling of sorrow and regret, unable in reality to express my feelings.

The telegram to you was sent forward in the best of spirit before the casket came and thought if there was any possibility of getting the expenses returned I would be grateful as I can ill afford the extra expense however I shall bear these cheerfully together with Simons fare to Vancouver.

Again let me express my sincere regrets.

Believe me

Yours very sincerely,

SGD. "A. R. Lett"

P.S. I can to a degree appreciate the feeling of the Indians and regret it so much.

"A.R.Lett."
Sir:

I beg to transmit herewith a copy of an official letter addressed to Rev. A. R. Lett, Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C., also copy of the Rev. Principal's reply, dated May 4th., both of which will be self-explanatory, and relate to the recent death of Jim Baker, a Squamish Indian pupil of the St. George's Indian School.

I feel that the Department's serious attention should be drawn to the statement of the Rev. Principal that during the past winter thirteen pupils of this school have died, four of whom were buried within the past three weeks preceding these letters. I consulted on this matter with Mr. R. H. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools, for British Columbia, who informed me that he for the month of February last had addressed a report to the Department setting forth the adverse conditions under which pupils were living at this school. Mr. Cairns, I believe, pointed out to the Department that there were ninety-five out of approximately one hundred pupils had influenza at the school, that eleven had developed mumps and that one had died of pneumonia. He recommended the closing of the school and the return to their homes of the pupils unless steps could be taken by the Government to provide comfortable housing for them.

The spring having now come, improved weather conditions will possibly remove for the summer season

the menace

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

RE: PURCHASE OF PROPERTY

LYTTON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Relative to the proposal that the Department purchase the property at the Lytton Indian Residential School from the New England Company, for a consideration of £8,000, I wish to point out that the independent valuator you appointed made the following appraisal:

| Item          | Value   |
|---------------|---------|
| Land          | $36,020 |
| Buildings     | 13,420  |
| Furnishings   | 2,360   |
| Stock         | 6,265   |
| Implements    | 2,795   |
| Other Equipment | 3,940 |
| **Total**     | **$64,810** |

Not included in the appraiser's figures, are the barn and two cottages, which have been lately erected at a cost of $19,268, approximately $15,000 of which was from Parliamentary Appropriation.

I have reviewed the capital expenditure from 1920-21 to 1926-27, inclusive. And I find that from Parliamentary Appropriation the following improvements, other than the three outbuildings mentioned, have been made:

| Item                  | Value   |
|-----------------------|---------|
| Live Stock            | $6,463  |
| Mechanical Plant      | 8,047   |
| Irrigation            | 5,782   |
| Farm Machinery        | 2,840   |
| Furnishings & other Equipment | 2,375 |
| **Total**             | **$25,175** |

In addition to the expenditure from Parliamentary Appropriation, there has been approximately $7,000 worth of improvements paid for by the New England Company grant.

I believe that the appraiser's valuation was conservative. If 20% of the cost of recent improvements is
deducted for depreciation and the balance subtracted from
the valuator's figures, it would appear that the New
England Company equity is approximately $45,000. The
Company, in a recent letter, indicates that the property
stands on their books as an asset of £12,475, or approx-
imately $60,500. To this figure might be added $7,000 -
the value of the improvements paid for from the New England
Company grant in recent years. Allowing for depreciation
and for the increase in land values during the years, I
am satisfied that the proposed purchase price, $8,000, or
$36,848 at current rates of exchange, is quite fair and
reasonable. When the new main building is erected, the
property with its fine outbuildings and splendid irrigation
system will be a very valuable adjunct to our educational
equipment. The site is very attractive and the land, when
irrigated, quite fertile.

The New England Company have written in
part as follows: "That, if your Department would agree to
purchase the property immediately for the sum named ($8,000)
the Court would agree that the payment of the purchase money
could be spread over a period of years to be arranged, by
instalments, and they suggest that the most convenient form
of such an arrangement would be for the payments to be made
in equal sums paid yearly as principal and interest to cover
outstanding amounts at 5%. . . . . The maintenance
grants would be continued by agreement for a period of years
on the present basis." Another letter, referring to the
arrangement in the event of purchase, states that the Company
might be willing to continue the grants which they now give
and to add thereto the bulk of the interest derived from the
purchase money.

There is an item of $10,000 in the Main
Estimates as the first payment on the purchase price of this
property. I wish to recommend that the New England Company
be informed of our intention to purchase immediately, that
they be offered $10,000 in cash, $10,000 in one year,
$10,000 in two years, and the balance plus interest due in
three years' time. The last three payments would, of course,
have to be included in our Estimates. I do not recommend
that the New England Company grants for maintenance be set
off against the Department's payments of principal and
interest, as it would be a source of much satisfaction to me
if the Company indefinitely continues its grants and its
association with the Department in the conduct of the
Institution.

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Mr. Mathews:

I am very pleased to inform you that my plans for the Lytton Indian Residential School have rapidly materialized. Not only has Parliament provided sufficient funds for a new main building, but we have received a reasonable offer from a responsible contractor. Complete plans and specifications were prepared some time ago and I called for tenders, which were opened recently. The Department is quite satisfied with the figure $139,000, which was entered by Addison and Hill, of Vancouver, who have been found quite capable of handling the work. I am directing to you, under separate cover, a set of the plans and specifications, so you will know exactly what type of building is being erected. The dormitories and classrooms will be made ready for an initial enrolment of 150. However, if all available space is used, the building will accommodate 180 children besides the staff.

In addition to funds for the main building, Parliament has provided $27,500 for water supply, sewage disposal, shelving, cupboards, furnishings, salary of the Inspector of Construction and a horse barn. There was also a vote of $10,000 for a first payment towards the purchase of the property.

I have arranged application to His Excellency in Council for authority to award the contract and I wish to take advantage of the New England Company's offer to sell their equity in the property attached to the school for a consideration of £8,000. The Superintendent General has approved of this scheme and the Department will be glad to accept the proposal of your letter of June 22nd, last, i.e., spread the payment of the purchase money over a term of years.

I am making arrangements with the Department of Justice for the appointment of a lawyer in British Columbia, who will search title and prepare the necessary legal instruments. I am suggesting an Agreement of Sale with a consideration of £6,400, indicating a payment this year of £8,000, £8,000 in one year, £8,000 in two years and the balance of the consideration plus interest due at 5% in three years' time. In addition, there will be a Bill of Sale for all chattels with a consideration of £1,600, indicating a payment this year of £2,000, £2,000 in one year, £2,000 in two years and the balance of the consideration plus interest due at 5% in three years' time. ST. GEORGE'S RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL: I also visited and went over this school. However, they were in the process of breaking up, and there was no work being done in the class rooms. I might say that Mr. Lett, the Principal, who has been very seriously ill, had returned for two or three days to see that the children were properly despatched to their homes. Personally, I did not think he was fit to be doing this work. On my second visit I went round there with the Deputy Superintendent General. The kitchen was clean and tidy, as were the lavatories. I found the fire fighting apparatus in good order and fire escapes accessible, and it was reported to me that the hydrants and hose were in good working order.

The school farm has very good crops and, apparently, is very well run. The milk herd seemed in excellent condition and giving plenty of milk for the use of the school. The Manual Training done by the boys since my last visit is also very good, and they had done a lot of work in the way of gates and other things around the school property.

I am glad to report that at the time of my last visit there, I was informed that Mr. Lett, who was away taking a rest, has greatly improved, and considering that he was given up, he has made a marvellous recovery, and he hopes to be back, fit for work, at the commencement of next term. I do, however, think that an addition to the staff should be made, and trained by Mr. Lett, so that in case of sickness, there will be somebody who can take hold. It would also relieve him of a lot of the work that he is doing himself now, and which he should not have to do if things were properly arranged.

Yours truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill,

As you are aware, the Rev. A. R. Lett has tendered his resignation as Principal of the St. George's Indian Residential School. He wishes to be relieved of his duties by July first, next.

The St. George's Indian Residential School is near Lytton, B.C. It is located on Lot 11, adjacent to Reserve No. 2, in the electoral district of Cariboo.

The St. George's Residential School was taken over by the Department from the New England Company in 1922. During the fiscal years 1927-28 and 1928-29 a new building was erected. There is accommodation in this school for 180 pupils. Approximately 210 acres of land is under cultivation. A great deal of this is irrigated land.

The selection of a Principal for this school is in the hands of the Department - the understanding with the New England Company being that the Principal shall be a clergyman of the Church of England.

Before securing Rev. Mr. Lett's services, the Department communicated with Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D., D.D., D.C.L., General Secretary, Missionary Society, Church of England in Canada, and it was on his recommendation that Mr. Lett was chosen.

Rev. Mr. Lett has been allowed salary at the rate of $1,200 a year and Mrs. Lett, who acted as matron at the school, was allowed $240 a year. In addition to these salaries, living accommodation and maintenance are provided for the Principal and his family.

I am very much obliged by your letter of the 1st instant, and also for your cable, from which I note that the date of the very interesting ceremony at Lytton has been definitely fixed for June 15th. I do not quite gather from your letter whether you are likely to be in Ottawa at the time I mentioned, and as it is of primary importance that we should call on you we should of course vary our plans to meet your convenience. there.

From Brantford, where it is important that we should see the Company's lawyer, Mr Brewster, we shall go across to Vancouver, with a break in the journey giving a day probably at Lake Louise, and from Vancouver we have various people to visit. At Kamloops we shall be seeing the Bishop of Cariboo, to whom the Company has made a grant for a Missioner whose work lies among the old pupils of St George's School. At Vancouver we have to see the Archbishop of New Westminster with regard to another Mission which the Company is supporting or assisting in the neighbourhood of Alert Bay. A visit to Lytten, including the opening ceremony, will be the last of our undertakings, and I hope to be back in Quebec in time for the C.P.R. steamer leaving on June 23rd. March 30, 1928.

Dear Mr. Ditchburn:

For some time past I have been worried about the financial condition of the Lytton Indian Residential School. I am enclosing a statement showing the grants for current expenses that have been made from the time of Mr. Lett's appointment to the present date. You will notice that the school has cost the Department considerably more than the usual per capita grant. The most recent financial statement from the Rev. Mr. Lett is that for the month of January, last, and shows outstanding accounts of over $3,000. As you are aware, the entire responsibility for the conduct of this institution is now in the Department. Although Mr. Lett is in Holy Orders, we cannot ask either the diocesan authorities or any missionary society to assume financial responsibility.

I have recently received an anonymous letter and also a communication from Mr. B. Hodgkinson, senior teacher at the school, concerning whom Mr. Cairns reports very highly. These are enclosed for your perusal. I believe there should be a serious and careful enquiry into the management of the school. I have always been satisfied with the integrity of the Rev. Mr. Lett, but it is possible that he is not the good business man we require for this particular post.

I should like you to go to Lytton at your very earliest convenience for the purpose of a general enquiry.

Enc.

W. E. Ditchburn, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Box 666,
Victoria, B. C.
into conditions. You should take with you an accountant who will examine the books, receipts, etc., for a period of at least the last two years, and, if possible, from the beginning of Mr. Lett's incumbency.

The Rev. Mr. Lett has had a very trying time, and I am desirous that he be worried as little as possible by your investigation. He will perhaps be glad to have the accountant's check on the finances at the school, but the investigation into the complaints of the staff, of necessity, will be more or less unpleasant. However, I know that you will exercise your usual good tact and get to the bottom of the difficulties if at all possible. In addition to the financial management, the reasons for the chronic truancy and for the dissatisfaction of the members of the staff should be determined. I know that living conditions in the old building were far from pleasant; but, apparently, there are other causes for the unrest and lack of harmony.

I am informing Mr. Lett that you have been requested to make a general inspection. Even if there were no complaints concerning conditions at the school, it is now timely to have an accounting as we are taking over the property from the New England Company. Further, as the Company is sending a member of its Court and the Charter Clerk to Canada for the opening of the new school on June 15th, it is desirable that there be an inspection to see that conditions are generally satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.
March 30, 1928.

Dear Mr. Lett:

I have to inform you that final plans have been made for the official opening of the new building at St. George's on June 15th. Mr. J. B. Chubb, a member of the Court of the New England Company, and Mr. F. R. Bush, the Charter Clerk, have arranged to be in Lytton for the occasion.

In view of the approaching ceremony at the school and our recent purchase of the property from the New England Company, it is now timely to have a general inspection and an audit of the books. I am asking Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn to go to Lytton at his earliest convenience and to take an accountant with him. The Commissioner will enquire into the general management and conditions at the school. The audit of your books should cover the period since your appointment, if possible. The last independent accounting was in Dec., 1921. Please give Mr. Ditchburn every assistance.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. A. R. Lett,
Principal,

April 13, 1928.

Dear Mr. Lett:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo and am pleased to note that you are getting ready to move into the new building at the St. George's Indian Residential School. I believe it would be well for you to cooperate with Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn in the preparation of a programme for the official opening on June 15th. You should arrange for invitation cards, which should be sent to all those that would be interested. Care should be taken to include on the list for invitations officials of the various churches and both Federal and Provincial representatives. Special invitations should be sent to those who, if they accept, would be given a place on the programme such as Archbishop Sheen, the Honorable Mr. Berton, the Honourable Mr. Stewart, the Honourable Mr. Macdonald and Mr. H. J. Barber, M. P. You should invite Archbishop Casey and Very Rev. John Welsh, O.M.I., Provincial of the Oblate Order, and representatives of the United and Presbyterian Churches.

When it is determined what churches will be represented, you should ask one of the most prominent Reverend Gentlemen to prepare a short address on behalf of these other churches. Of course, Mr. Chubb, who will speak for the New England Company, and the senior officer of this Department who is present, should be on the list of speakers.

When Mr. Ditchburn and yourself have prepared a tentative list of those to whom invitations should be directed and a programme, you might let me review the result of your deliberations.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have to inform you that Mr. Comm. Ditchburn has just finished his investigation re anonymous report and financial conditions of the school.

As a result of his work he has found that the former is absolutely without foundation and with no warrant. It was the result of one of the members of my staff wishing to create a position with the Dept. for himself and thought the old conditions existing would be sufficient to make a report and the time opportune, undertaking evidently thereby a blow at myself as administrator of this Institution, anonymously allowing the report to go before the Dept. in order to leave and opening thereafter, if his efforts should prove fatal to me, to make application for the position.

The utter ignorance and folly displayed of his efforts will no doubt be forwarded to Mr. Ditchburn in due course. He had it true gathered around him three other members of the staff, which he, during the meeting of the staff, chaired by Mr. Ditchburn, termed represented the consensus of the opinion of the staff of seventeen.

Needless to say that I was by no means a little disturbed, and keenly felt the reaction he had driven us to especially since he always met us with a smile and was a regular communicant at the Chapel Alter. In spite of this fact I had seen through him and I had for the past month filling up information that might be used in case something should arise yet in some way not contemplating it would not be of such nature as that you have been obliged to enforce.

Re the financial condition of the school Mr. Ditchburn has found everything in order and the outlook of the School in this department in the very best condition.

We have been occupying the New Building for three weeks and are now very well established. We are already finding the work lessened and the organization and supervision easier maintained.

The lawns are seeded and the drive ways ready for gravel.

I sincerely trust that Parliament will be progressed and in time for you personally to be here on June the 15th.

I sincerely thank you for undivided interest and am thankful myself that the atmosphere has now been cleared.

Yours very obediently,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Lett:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, enclosing a proposal for the ceremony at the time of opening the new St. George's Indian Residential School. I believe the representative of this Department should be given a more prominent position on the programme. My suggestion is that he follow the representative of the New England Company. I had hoped that I would be present upon this interesting occasion; but I regret that it will be impossible for me to be in British Columbia so early in the year. Our Estimates have not been considered by the House and the date of prorogation is uncertain. I am writing to Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn, asking him to represent the Department and to convey the best wishes of the Honourable the Superintendent General and myself.

I have not yet received the invitation list that Mr. Ditchburn and yourself have prepared. You might let me have this as soon as possible. Before arranging for the printing of the programme, you should be sure that all those mentioned therein will be present.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Sir,

Lytton B.C.
March 1928

Reports on present conditions of work in above school

Staff.— This school is capable of producing and maintaining good results among our Indian Boys and Girls here, but its usefulness is much crippled by a weak policy of administration.

The school has been without a housemaster since Christmas—by May 1927, and the work has had to be divided up on to the present staff, particularly falling heavy on the Boys Matron and the Senior Teacher.

Boys Matron and Girls Sewing Matron are also very much overworked for want of further assistance, the latter particularly needing assistance in the making of necessary garments—blankets, sheets etc., needed for the new school.

There are many other points that might be discussed with profit, but all could be remedied by foresight and re-adjusted by any practical man of tact and common sense.

Finances.— These are in a most deplorable state and I believe the only remedy here is for a departmental audit of all accounts both past and present, and thus put the institution on a sound business base.

e.g.—The expense and receipt accounts given at the recent inspection for the month of January, could not possibly bear scrutiny, as there is no attempt at showing a true balance.

The staff received no salaries from Dec 15th 1927 until Feb. 17th 1928, when they each received two months arrears. Since then—nothing.

We are living from hand to mouth daily, and the place hopelessly in debt.

Farm.— No preparation as yet for any work there, most of irrigation pipes channels full of weed, sticks and stones. A very poor lookout for this year's crops.

Fuel.—Bad, and has been all through the winter, with the results that we have had bitterly cold rooms, much sickness and general discomfort, much of which could have been avoided by a little care and attention.

School.—Rooms on various occasions being only 40° 44° 48° and 50° for working in.

Clothes could not be washed and dried as they ought etc.

Dairy.—O.K.

Sport, Recreation etc.

Wretched, little interest, leading to unrest, mischief and constant running away.

With reference to this latter item, I may that since re-opening school since the summer vacation we have had no less than 35 runaways giving an aggregate loss of 235 days up to date.

Supervision—for this current year practically nil, owing to principal supervising building operations at the new school.

That this report on conditions as they are here,—is incomplete—will be very obvious to you, but sufficient has been mentioned to call for some remedy, re-organization, and re-adjustment in order to ensure success.

The inside staff have striven hard to keep things going, but the breaking strain is now reached, and hence this report.
Your inspector Mr. Cairns has visited, but whether he has made his report or not is unknown to us, but each one is ready and willing to continue his or her work ungrudgingly to the end, if only we can work under a semblance of human sympathy and living conditions.

Yours faithfully,

One of the Staff.

Of this, however, I feel that you are already aware.

At the new School I met Mr. B. Hodkinson, the senior teacher, privately, and informed him of my intention to investigate the complaints contained in a letter signed "One of the Staff" which he had forwarded to the Department with his letter of the 24th of March, and I asked him if he was prepared to support the charges for which he apparently had taken responsibility, and he stated that he was so prepared. At this meeting I laid before the Staff a summary of the complaints, but as Mr. Hodkinson stated publicly that he was responsible for the letter, I then read it in full to all the members of the staff which comprises thirteen persons. After reading the anonymous letter and hearing Mr. Hodkinson's statement that he took responsibility for it and that it represented the consensus of opinion of the full staff, I was very much surprised to learn from ten of the thirteen members that they disclaimed any knowledge of the document whatever, and stated that they had no complaint to make; they had found the Principal, the Rev. Mr. Lett, extremely sympathetic and that he had tried to do everything humanely possible to keep them comfortable under very trying circumstances. There is no doubt about it but what conditions during the Winter at the old school were anything but favourable in the way of supervision, heating and general accommodation. There appears to have been plenty of fuel, but the boilers of the heating plant were corroded owing to the use of the alkali water and consequently it was impossible to get but very little heat.

With regard to the first complaint that the usefulness of the School had been crippled by the weak policy of under-staffing, I am of the opinion that such is not the case, as the staff at the school was sufficiently large to fully manage the institution. It is true that at the time the anonymous letter was written (March) Mr. Shoregold, the headmaster, was absent on account of illness, but it was found inadvisable to make another such appointment in view of the fact that it was not definitely known whether Mr. Shoregold would be able to return to duty or not. I am inclined to the opinion that the complaint in this connection was made by Mr.
Mr. Hodkinson with a view to the possibility of his promotion to the position of head-master, if not to the principalship of the School.

The financial situation of the School has been fully reported on already, but in passing I may say that it is difficult to understand just how Mr. Hodkinson, or any other member of the staff, was cognizant with the matter, as Mr. Lett gave me to understand that he had not informed any of the staff as to just how matters stood.

The complaint that there had not been any preparations made on the farm and that most of the irrigation ditches were filled with weeds, sticks and stones with the consequence that the outlook for this year's crop was very poor, I may say that this complaint was not found to be correct, as it was clearly shown by Mr. Stemp, the irrigator, that the ditches were cleaned out a full week before the water was turned on. The farm itself at the time of my inspection was in splendid condition and the outlook for a bountiful crop this season is assured, barring some unforeseen circumstance.

With regard to the complaint about lack of opportunity for recreation, there appears to have been some merit in the same so far as it applied to the old premises, but conditions were unavoidable in view of the fact that the stoves had to be set out in the boys' recreation room for heating purposes and no organized games could be carried on. This condition, no doubt, led to unrest among the pupils as on account of the severity of the weather, sports on the playgrounds were practically impossible with the consequence that a number of the pupils left the School without leave.

There is some merit also in the complaint that the supervision of the School had not been all that it should have been owing to the Principal giving more attention to the construction
construction of the new buildings than to the management of the School itself. As the new School is at least half a mile distant from the old one, it, of course, was impossible for the Principal to have as much oversight of the School then operating as was necessary, and it would have been much better had he confined his attention to the old School altogether. His action in this regard, however, may be excused to a considerable extent as he was extremely anxious about the new buildings and there had been considerable delay in the starting of progressive construction. With regard to this particular complaint, I took occasion to point out to the Reverend Mr. Lett that as he had a competent staff to operate his farm, he, for the future, should confine himself to the efficient management of the School, and he agreed that he would follow this course.

Upon conclusion of my investigation, I pointed out to the Staff that the letter sent to the Department by Mr. Hodkinson was extremely ill-timed in view of the fact that it must have been written practically on the eve of moving out of the old School into the new one where the conditions provided for plenty of recreation room, good heating, fuller control of pupils both inside and outside of the institution, and better management than had ever been possible in the old building.

In conclusion I deem it important to inform you that Mr. Hodkinson is leaving the School during the month of June as he is going to marry Miss Spencer, one of the sewing matrons, and as the building will not afford any accommodation for he and his wife, he has tendered his resignation. I feel that it is in the best interest of the School as the conclusion I have formed is that he is inclined to fault-finding and trouble-making, notwithstanding his ability as a teacher.

Archbishop de Fencier, of the Anglican Church, Vancouver,

Mr. Chairman, Lord Bishop, Ladies and Gentlemen,

I want today for a few minutes to take your minds back in retrospect—a backward look, and then when we compare the things that have been with our present undertaking we will all, of every race, of every age, whether the little ones or the old folk, or those of us who do not yet like to be called the old folk, have cause for rejoicing.

It is only a little over sixty years since the first Bishop of old British Columbia landed at Victoria, when the Right Reverend George Hills came to the new colony in 1860 and there were three clergy to meet him—three missionaries who crossed the gulf and went up the mouth of the Fraser and he came to a place where is now the City of New Westminster. There were four missionaries there and with these three made seven and the Bishop, who went up the country with horses visiting the natives, speaking to them of things of gold, not the love of earthly things but of the eternal gold which does not perish, and as he went through the country it was struck with the appearance, the vitality the foresightfulness and the intelligence of the original inhabitants of the land of your fathers.

About the same time a British Admiral was sent out to chart the coast, and that Admiral went up 300 or 400 miles to about opposite Metlakatla, when some war canoes of the Haidas and Nisgaas came along, and in the bottom of one was a heap of something. When they took off the cover here were the heads of enemies, as they had been on a war expedition. One of their Chiefs was in that canoe and that chief's name was Edinshaw. The Admiral returned back home that here was need of missionaries for British admirals have ever been men who have feared God as well as being loyal subjects to King and Country, and backed up the Bishop in the efforts he was making. Here are a people, the original inhabitants in this British Columbia, whose mental ability can be seen in their faces, their thoughtful look; strong in physique, and with intelligence in their faces; and soon a missionary came for the north. I mustn't dwell at length on that work, that is just one little item.

The week before last I was in the City of Prince Rupert, attending a meeting for the election of bishop and representatives for the synod of Canada. The Church has led the way and shown the State, and the Church will yet continue to teach the State, as it is here to do. At that synod there were representatives from Indian villages who had equal right to vote for Bishop with their white brothers, and surprising to me, one strong bodied, intelligent Indian was elected to represent that diocese at the synod, the general synod of Canada, and that man's name was Edinshaw, the grandson of the old Chief of Edinshaw, who met the Admiral with his enemies' heads, a man who can stand on any platform and speak with intelligence equal to that of any man. That is what the Church has done for the red Indians of British Columbia.

I was in
I was in a little church in an Indian village just last week—forty-eight or fifty came for Confirmation—a church built by the Indians themselves; a fine building, with a good choir, a young Indian with his baton leading, sang an anthem that would not have disgraced any white church. On the wall, this is what took my eye, was an inscription with the names of some young men of that village who had given their lives for king and country, the same as our sons had given their lives. That also is the result of the teaching that is given the Indians in our province. I might speak at length, if time permitted, of the men of the Indian race who served overseas with the Canadian battalions. I always made a point of enquiring if there were any Indians in the different divisions from Canada, and always I found some of them, fine young men who were just as eager to do their part as any of their white brothers. All this is the result of the Church and school education.

I can think with a very vivid recollection of coming to St. George's School, Lytton, eighteen years ago, and looking at the beautiful home on the hillside, one couldn't but appreciate the foresight of those who selected these lands for this purpose. Many were the interesting and I hope pleasant and inspiring meetings I had with many of you. We had two hundred Indians in church. I remember going across the river for Confirmation services, and coming down this side of the river and meeting almost all the settlers, and very happy these recollections were. What the first workers in this province eighteen years ago were able to undertake, are now having this delightful result.

Another memory is in London, England, of many business engagements there, and of going up to the court of the New England Company. I certainly enjoyed it as over there they take time to enjoy these things, more than we allow ourselves from business. We do not divide the time well, as at the lunch where everybody took the time to do things as they should be done; to tell of the interest that they had and continue to have for the Indians in our Canada. It was a delightful memory of goodwill and fellowship extended to a fellow traveller in a far country, and all were heartened and helped considerably by the warmth of your representative who assured me that they would stand behind any effort for our Indians which was considered and accepted by those in authority here.

I am sorry I was so late but misfortunes will happen and when I saw the Indians still coming up the hill in their wagons and on foot I knew that I would not be so very late. Among several things that held us back was puncturing a tire about four miles below Lytton, which makes me think of a story,—for we wanted to be at Lytton, but could not get there. There was an old darky called Sambo, who had rather an affection for his neighbor's hen roosts, but he went the way of all flesh and left a wife, and she prayed thus for Sambo, "Oh, Sambo! Oh, Sambo! I hopes you is, where I knows you ain't," so I wished I was in Lytton at St. George's School, where I knew I wasn't.

The New England Company is not going to give up its work with the Indians of British Columbia entirely, and that is how Mr. Riggs came as an extra missionary to Lytton. It is part of his work to look after the old boys and girls who have left the school.

I wish the Thompson Tribe to remember that the New England Company is continuing the work that built the old school.

Address by Rev. Mr. Ditham, superannuated Anglican clergyman, who founded the St. George's Indian School, at Lytton, B.C.:

This is the first school with Indian boys in Lytton, which was started at the old Court house. The school was a night school from 7 until 9, when it was dark.

The next school was at Yale. I had a fine lot of boys there, good boys; and then Bishop Sillitoe came and asked me to go to the girls' school to see if I could do something for them. I went to help the school and then came up to Jacob's Mt., Gus Benson had a hotel which we bought for $400.00, lock, stock and barrel. We took that land to establish a school. It was a good school, and was called an industrial school. One day a lad, now an Indian teacher, was going down to Yale, and saw a sheep running away, and he couldn't catch it, and after the sheep came Mr. Small in his cassock, and after him came Mr. Edwards in his cassock, with a big knife. They had a bad time at that school. Sometimes hadn't much to eat. Mr. Keefers, the C.P.R. engineer, after whom Keefers was named, used to get them over on Sundays, and other times, and give them a feed. They sometimes had nothing to eat down there. They did not know how to kill a sheep, and the sheep got away.

After the Yale school was established, Bishop Sillitoe and Mr. Moody, who was on the court of the New England Company at Yale girls' school, and Sister Althea, who was instrumental with her father in having me look around to find out a suitable location to build a boys' school. I went to a good deal of trouble about it, and after a while decided to buy Tom Seward's ranch, and my commission from Mr. Moody was to come up to Lytton and lick it into shape, and I think I licked it into shape. The New England Company wished to provide education for Indian children. No man's work is more telling than building up and making a people. That was a doubtful question at one time, "Mr. Ditham," said Mr. Lett "built up the school," and Mr. Lett called me an old man; and Mr. Moody told me to lick that school into shape, he better be careful I don't lick him.

Mr. Lett: The boys know it sometimes takes a little licking to keep it in shape.

Mr. Chairman, Archbishop, Lord Bishop, Ladies and Gentlemen:

I am very pleased this afternoon to be here, but I can assure you my words will be few.

It was perhaps through the New England Company, I might say, that in 1898 I had the pleasure of crossing over to a little Island church in Ontario in order to take the opportunity of preaching for one year at this place in the place of the Rev. Mr. Roberts to a number of Troquois Indians, and I think it was that touch with the Indian people that caused me in 1891 to come to British Columbia, and from that time to this I have been enjoying the work with the Indians, especially amongst the boys and girls.

Now I wish to say to you boys and girls here that your school life is part of you, it is part of your heart and soul, and when you go out of St. George's School you will carry in your heart part of the school, part of St. George's School, and you must try to be a credit to your school.

When I was leaving for this visit to St. George's School, I asked Peter Antoine, a boy who used to attend St. George's School, what he would like me to say to the boys of St. George's School, and he said for me to wish you luck, and I do, I wish you luck from myself and my school and from Peter Antoine. I wish you every success now and every success in the future.

I hope that what you are taught in St. George's School will become such a habit that you will always carry this teaching with you, and become an influence for good in your home and on your reserves. That you will always remember the good teaching of Mr. and Mrs. Lett, and I extend to both you and them the good wishes for every success of the Coqualeetza School.
