Address by W. B. Pitchburn, Esq., Indian Commissioner for British Columbia:

Mr. Chairman, Archbishop, Lord Bishop,
Ladies and Gentlemen, and Indians of the Thompson Tribe:

After having listened to such fluent addresses from these different gentlemen, who have covered the ground so well, I can hardly know what you can expect me to say on this occasion, because it has left very little to be said in the way of sentiment and appreciation. It is possible, however, that I may be able to give some information as to the amount of work the Department of Indian Affairs has done for the Indians of British Columbia on educational lines. I had fully hoped that the Deputy Superintendent General would have been here, and he fully expected to be present, but he did not remain in session so long, and only prolonged this last Monday. However, I think he will pay British Columbia a visit this summer, and I am sure he will take great pleasure in coming to Lytton, and pride in visiting St. George's School.

The completion of this school, while it is only one of the many in the links of the Department's chain of education, shows evidence of the desire of the Department to endeavor to put the Indian children of British Columbia on the same plane educationally as their white brothers, provided those Indians will take the opportunity of allowing their children to become educated. There are facilities in this school, and in all other residential schools just as good for making first class scholars and students, as are in the Public Schools of the Province for white children. In fact, I am pleased to say, to those who do not have the opportunity very often of visiting Indian schools, that the progress made by these Indian children is remarkable when they pay any sort of attention to their studies, and when you take into consideration the fact that these Indian children only study on the half time system the progress they make is marvelous. It is really wonderful how they get along, and I can assure you that compared with white children the progress made by Indian children is equal, if not better than that made by white children.

We have in British Columbia sixteen or seventeen residential schools of the same class as this. We also have in the Province, forty-two day schools. The Department finds it necessary to establish day schools. We prefer residential schools, as it is more permanent, but in many cases the day school is found necessary on account of the physical condition of the children. Ordinarily before a child can become a pupil of a residential school it must pass a medical examination, and only those who are qualified can enter; therefore it is necessary that the education of these others should be taken care of as far as possible under the circumstances.

In the sixteen residential schools there are 1700 pupils at the present time, and in the forty-two day schools where the education is more or less intermittent, approximately 1400. We have between 83 and 8400 Indians in British Columbia, and in the vicinity of 3200 children attending school, and as time goes on, facilities for attending will be improved.

Our programme
Our programme of construction is not complete by any means, and consists of the rebuilding of Indian schools and building of new ones. It is not many years since the Government of Canada decided that the education of the Indians should be a capital charge against the administration of the country, and therefore my Department, since that date, has been in a position to lay out a programme and consequently large amounts of money are being spent every year. When British Columbia first came into the Confederation in 1871 I don't think there were any schools in the Province. There were certainly none in Colonial days, and the Colonial Government put no expense whatever in the matter. In 1872, when British Columbia entered the Union, Indian education was then taken up more particularly by the Missionaries and Churches, assisted to a limited extent by the Department of Indian Affairs. It went along that way for a long time, with very little action on the part of the Government, but as time progressed the Missionary Societies called upon the Department for greater assistance, with the consequence that amounts have crept up tremendously, until about twenty years ago, the Department went into cooperation with the churches and societies on a fifty-fifty basis. The Church would spend so much and the Government a like sum until the last few years at which time the whole cost of the Indian education was taken over by the Government, assisted to some extent by the churches and Missionary Societies. As an illustration of that statement, I will tell you that for the first seven years after 1871, the total amount of money spent by the Government was only $12,000.00; from 1881 to 1891, it jumped to $71,000.00; from 1891 to 1900, it was $451,000.00; from 1900 to 1910, it rose to $766,000.00, and in the next ten years it overdoubled at a cost of $1,694,604, and during the last eight years a sum or over $6,000,000 has been spent. I think it only fair that I should let the general public know to what extent the Department is going in its endeavours to place the Indian children in a very real position to get a fair education. It is not our fault if the Indians themselves do not take advantage of the opportunities offered.

New schools have been built at Sechelt, Kuper Island, Sardis, Fraser Lake, Cranbrook, Kamloops, and lastly, this beautiful school at Lytton. On the programme the schools to be built are a new school at Alert Bay, and another will be necessary for the Indians in the Chilcoten country, and also one near Prince Rupert, also the old school at Mission Junction will have to be replaced by a new one in the very near future.

When that programme is finished, I think that the Department will feel that it has done all that it is necessary to do to afford a reasonable amount of education amongst the Indians. I know that these schools are doing good work, how good I will leave to Mr. Cairns to tell you as he is the Inspector of Indian Schools and keeps trace of what advance is being made in education.

I cannot think of anything more to say except to express my pleasure at being present at the opening of this beautiful school, which has taken the place of the school on the hill, which has outlived its purpose.
Address by Mr. R. H. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools of British Columbia:

I am very pleased to have the opportunity of standing before you and telling you a few things about our school system.

A few years ago we found ourselves in peculiar circumstances. We had no Course of Study nor authorized text books for our Indian Schools. For instance a teacher would come here from Prince Edward Island say, and ask, "What books have you got?" We would have to say "We have no books of any sort. No Course of Study of our own." As the capital of Canada is in Ontario, all our books came from there, and they had the viewpoint of Ontario. But we have changed that now. Although we have no Course of Study of our own, we unify our work in this way. Each Province has its own Course of Study and its own schoolbooks for Public Schools, so we use the text books and Course of Study of the Provincial Schools of each Province. That is, take St. George's School, we use the Course of Study and text books of British Columbia, as we do in all other schools for Indian children in this Province. The Indian Schools in Saskatchewan use the authorized books of that Province; and so on throughout Canada.

Today we have a number of young people educated in our Indian schools who are taking a course following out their Public School course with advanced work, where they work in High School or college side by side with children of the white schools; and according to the last report, we have in Canada 190 pupils who have finished their Public School course and are now taking High School, Business College, University and other advanced work. In the case of these last, the Department assists. In our own Province, we have in round numbers 3000 pupils, and in a small population like this, there must be quite an influence on the Indian race, as we are turning out about two hundred pupils a year.

As an example of an Indian pupil taking advanced work and coming out with flying colors, take the case of a little Indian girl of the Haida tribe from the north. She was ten years of age, couldn't speak English and hadn't been inside a school in her life. She was brought down to Coghataetza, where she attended classes on the half time system. In the six years she passed her Entrance, which is less time than the average child takes in the white schools, where the course is for eight years full time. She went through High School, and then I had her sent to Normal. She got her teacher's certificate and went to teach in a school up in the Cariboo, where she taught for months. The trustees were very pleased with her teaching and had no idea she was an Indian, thinking she was French, so she did not meet them crying to the prejudice against Indians in some quarters - against an Indian teaching in a white school. But unfortunately for our experiment as to her future progress, she met a white man, married him, and is now living happily in domestic life near Fort Simpson.

ST GEORGE'S SCHOOL, LYTTON, B.C.

EDITORIAL.

The term just closing is possibly the most important one in the history of St George's. First of all about the middle of April we left the old school to enter the fine new building, an event to which many of us had looked forward to with bated breath for a long time. But it was worth waiting for and we can all look forward to the future with renewed vision and brightened hopes.

The school was however not officially opened until June 15th when before a large and representative gathering the Arch Bishop dedicated the New Building to the education of the Indian children.

This service has been dealt with at length elsewhere, so I will pass on to other matters.

Another very important event in the life of the school was the confirmation of a large number of boys and girls by Bishop Adna, on Sunday 24th June. The service was a very impressive one and will be long remembered by all who were present.

On June the 17th the ladies of the Sunday School Van gave an address to the children who all listened very attentively.

Our Sports Day May 26th was again very successful John Johnson winning the Bishop's Cup which is presented annually to the best all round athlete, and John Walker winning the Principal's Cup.

In spite of adverse circumstances the Cadets were highly commended by Capt. Currie, the Inspecting Officer for their discipline and the manner in which they executed the various movements and exercises in their Squad Drill and their Physical Training.

A new venture in the school is the formation of a troop of Girl Guides and Boy Scouts, the girls in blue and the boys in khaki looking very fine and smart.

We are glad to report that this year we have three scholars taking High School work and six writing their Entrance Examinations. We wish them all success and will be looking eagerly for the results in a few weeks time, very confident that all the names will appear on the "Pass" list.

Just one word in closing. I hope that all the children will remember Bishop Adna's message to them. Let us repeat it here.

"For this God is our God for ever and ever. He will be our guide unto death."

Mr and Mrs Lott and Staff all join with me in wishing you all a happy holiday.

The Editor.
The formal opening of the New Building of St George's Indian Residential School took place on the 15th inst. This marked an occasion in the history of the School, second only to its foundation by the New England Co (the oldest "missionary Society existing") in 1901.

The gathering was very representative of the community: the Indians, The Dept of Indian Affairs, The New England Co and the Church.

The proceedings opened by a short address by the Principal followed by the singing of 'O Canada' by the children. The Principal then took the primary part of the Dedication Service followed by the 'Nativity Prayers' by the Bishop of Cariboo in which district the school is situated.

Archbishop De Banziger addressed the gathering and finished the service with the Blessing. During the service Psalms No. 127 and Hymn No. 606 were sung; both appropriate and in keeping with the service.

Then followed speeches by the representatives of the Dept of the New England Co, Mr Batchelor, Mr Riley as representing the his school at Bardie and the United Church of Canada, and the chiefs of the Thompson Indians for whom children the School was founded built and rebuilt. We have now a modern Residential School very highly equipped in every department and will be a joy to the parents of the children under education here, to the children themselves and also to the Principal and his staff.

THE DEVELOPMENT OF INDIAN EDUCATION.

Mr. Ditchburn Indian Commissioner for B.C. spoke on the development of Indian education in the province beginning with the period immediately after confederation, pointing out that the rate of education had increased very rapidly and during the period of 51 years beginning with 1871 the Dept. of Indian Affairs has spent $6 million and a half of dollars towards the academic uplift of the boys and girls of Indian parentage. Today there are 16 residential schools handling 1700 children and 42 day schools with an average attendance of approximately 1400.

The program of construction was not in-sufficient and the Dept. wished to conclude this program as rapidly as possible so that the children out of a population of some 25,000 Indians in B.C. could be simply cared for adequately.

The Dept. of Indian Affairs was now co-operating with the several churches and should be a means in this way of Christian growth as well as spreading broadening of mind and intellect.

The aim of the Dept. was to give the Indian child an equal opportunity for development side by side with his white brother and so endeavor to make them responsible citizens and co-workers in the future growth of this fair Dominion.

Mr. R.H. Cairns Inspector of Indian Schools told of the development of Class Room work. The organization had now developed to the stage where the curriculum of the province was a workable factor in the schools, resulting in the fact that 171 Indian children were taking High School and other advanced work. Normal Training Depots were being established and it should not take many years before results in this important line of education should be seen.

Mr. Riley Principal of Sequaletza Institute expressed his gratitude in being able to be present at this important function in the history of St. George's School. Milestone No. 2 has arisen and I wish to tender the hearty good wishes for your success on behalf of himself staff and children and also for his church.

In speaking to the children he said that the ideal and its teaching would become part of their very being and hoped that as they physically grew to man and womanhood that they would individually and collectively be a credit to their mother school.

CANADA'S BIRTHDAY

The birthday of our Dominion on the first of July awakens only pleasant recollections. Looking back we see how patriotism had a rebirth at Confederation. It became possible for all Canadians to think and speak of Canada as "my own my native land." They were able to pronounce their desires and opinions with the voice of a united powerful nation. They could with united soul and force offer needed assistance to the Empire in times of necessity.

CONTRIBUTIONS FROM THE CHILDREN TO THE CHURCH.

OUR NEW SCHOOL

by

Our new school has been planned for some time, but it was not until last August that the contractors began work on it. It is two or three times larger than the old school, so there were quite a lot of contractors, bricklayers and others working on it.

In the winter when it was very cold part of the crew had to be lay off because the bricklayers could not go on during the cold weather. But while this cold weather was on none of the inside work was done.

We moved into the new school just after Easter. We got all the furniture down that was needed during the day, then after we had our last supper in the old school we put all our private belongings and bedclothes and started them to the new school.

We were all very glad to get down to our new house because everything is better and so much more comfortable than in the old school.

THE GIRL GUIDES

by

Our girl guides company started about two months after our holidays last year. Miss Richard is our Leader. We now have four patrols with eight girls in each. They are called the "Forest Patrol," "Tri royal," "Buffalo" and "Flag Bear" patrols.

We have our girl guide meeting on Mondays and Saturdays. We have camping trips and hikes during the summer. We must tell you of a girl guide picnic we had this year on Annapolis Bay, up at a place we call forty seven. First we fitted up our pavilion for two weeks, then we arranged to have the truck to take us there. Then we arrived at our chosen spot for the picnic, we had half an hour rest just before dinner. We divided our group into four parts such as the wood patrol cooking patrol water patrol and serving patrol.

After our dinner we had a wonderful afternoon spent on exploring, getting off trail and treasure hunting. We brought a lot of wild flowers and brought up of shrubs down, the colors and beauty of which were very beautiful.

When we finished our supper we waited for the truck to come back for us, our umbrellas and our flowers shrubs and plants.

At last the trucks arrived and we all climbed on for the homeward trip.

We had a concert during the winter and made enough money to get our hats belts shoulder straps and badges.

Our sewing room patron and a few of the girls and our dresses, and soon we will all be in full uniform.

ST. GEORGE'S SCHOOL SEPTEMBER 1928 LYTTON BRITISH COLUMBIA

EDITORIAL PAGE

The holidays to which we all looked forward so eagerly are over, and oh! how quickly the weeks flew by. I am sure that we all enjoyed them however and are so much better for them that now at the beginning of this new term we are ready to put in a good year's work. The class rooms have all been reorganised and are doing good work. The Girl Guides and Cadets have made a good beginning with their Fall and Winter program. Both of these activities will be dealt with elsewhere in this issue.

A new departure this term is the giving of physical training and organised games to the intermediates and the juniors. We trust that it will be the means of building them up into strong healthy boys.

Everyone is looking forward with a great deal of curiosity and interest to the entertainment that the boys are giving on the 1st of November. We hope that those boys and girls whose parents live in or near Lytton will write to them and tell them about it. The boys say that it is going to be the best entertainment ever held in St George's.

We are glad to see quite a number of new boys and girls in the School this term. We hope that they will be happy in their new homes.

We extend to the new members of the staff a hearty welcome to our School. Each one in his or her own sphere is doing a work which is bound to have a lasting influence on the lives of the children.

We would draw your attention to the front cover of our magazine which is the work of John James, and also to the back cover the work of Jane James. This is the result of a competition which was held amongst the senior boys and girls. Prizes were given by the Boys' Supervisor and the Girls' Matron. We congratulate all of those who took part on the very fine work which was produced, some of which is reproduced in this issue.

We hope that all the boys and girls in all grades will work hard this term, and we wish both Staff and children all success in their work.

THE EDITOR
THE PRINCIPAL'S PAGE

The vacation has expired and the school is again in full session. While the children have enjoyed the holiday of six long weeks at home, we find that they have returned with smiling faces evidently ready for a good year's work.

Since the new school has become a reality, there have been three or four new depts. in our work opened up. The continuation class room will afford opportunity of high school to four of our children who were successful in their entrance to high school exams. Another room has been opened up which we term the "Opportunity class room". Here we are trying out a new phase of work. A number of children who have lately entered school are of advanced age, ranging from 12 to 16 years. We can not do more than teach them the "three Rs". We are specializing in domestic training for the girls, such as sewing, laundry and kitchen work, etc., for the boys in the different departments of agriculture, and in the manual training room. The manual training dept which the new school has made possible has already proved its attraction for the boys. Creative ability is highly noticeable and we hope that during the year great results will be acquired.

Prizes are being offered for proficiency in all depts. both for the boys and the girls, which will be given at the year's work. Class room prizes are also being offered in each grade.

Some good news has come to us of late. We note that the Dept of Indian Affairs are contemplating moving our Chapel, which when accomplished will be a spiritual vacancy filled. We wish this work God speed. A store room is also being contemplated. Being short of storage capacity we feel that the Dept. is seeing into our wants in time to prevent any great loss which may occur owing to the lack of room to store our extra furniture tools, etc.

A new dairy will be built shortly of concrete construction with modern equipment installed. We should be able to take good care of the milk which is such a necessity for the health of the children. In passing I might say that the children at the present time are consuming per capita, one and a quarter quart of milk per day.

The farm on the whole has had a good year. We have just finished harvesting the third crop of alfalfa, and are now busy allowing twelve acres of corn. Potatoes and mangles are still yet to be harvested.

Our numbers have increased and we are expecting shortly to have 150 children in the school.

We are glad that the Boy Scout and Cadet movements for the boys and the Girl Guides for the girls are being continued. These organisations are working wonders with the children.

The new personnel on the staff are carefully working into their the grooves allotted to each, and all are on the whole looking forward to renewed life for the new era just begun. We all I am sure realise the importance of our individual positions in playing our parts in one whole organization and I hope with a prayer in our heart we trust that God in his infinite mercy will be our guide in this greatest wonderful work—the education of the Indian children of the Thompson tribes of B.C.

ACROSS THE SEA

P.C. Merratt.

TRAVEL to some of us, is an experience, to all it is part of our education. To myself, during my trip from England to Canada it was both. Amongst other things, the awfulness and beauty of the ocean was shown to me as well as the care that is exercised by the shipping companies in transporting passengers across the sea.

Now take with me in your imagination, an ocean trip from Southampton England to Quebec Canada. The whole of the wharf to which the ship is tied is bustle and excitement as passengers endeavor to make their way to the ship upon which they are sailing. Cars rush to and fro, porters loaded with the grips of passengers hurry from shore to ship and back again fearful lest they shall lose a goodly portion, cranes groan under the weight of their loads, the winches shriek and strain as pressure is put upon them, passengers rush hither and thither to see to the last of their baggage, and friends rush after them in case they shall be lost in the maze of corridors and last goodbyes must be said over the ship's side to those on the wharf.

Hoot! Hoot! The ships siren shrieks its warning and the cry of "All visitors ashore" comes from the deep throated members of the crew. Goodbyes are brisk partings quickly over and the last visitor has descended to the shore; the gangway slides from the side of our ship, ropes and hawsers are loosened and all is ready to head out to sea. Already the little tugs attached to bow and stern are snorting away like growling puppies on a leash, anxious to pull the great ship into the wider water.

A further shriek from the siren and we are off, slowly but surely our ship gathers speed, our tugs have done their work and are heading for the open. Away behind us the shore fades away into a mist, and sentimental members of our band crowd to the stern rail and watch old England disappear from sight.

Now all the passengers are not aboard yet for we have to pick up some more at Cherbourg on the coast of France, but fog and mist delays us and by this time we reach there night has settled and the fog has thickened. So dark is the night and so thick the fog that it is impossible for any big ship to enter port so she drops anchor out side and patiently awaits the coming of the tender from the shore that shall bring aboard the extra passengers. Soon the shrieking of a siren announces that the tender is approaching and our ship sends a reply, and then from out of the fog appears a multitude of lights which slowly take the form of a ship. This is what we are waiting for. It is truly a wonderful sight. Now she is alongside she has dropped her anchor, a gangway is put across between the two ships and the passengers begin to come aboard. Again there is much hustle and excitement but the whole business does not take long, and all being over we set sail again to the accompaniment of "Bon voyage" from the sailors on the tender, and the screech and rattle of chains as the anchor ascends from its ocean bed.

Hoot! Hoot! is the constant cry of our ship as she ploughs her way through mist and foam, and from the distance comes an answering hoot from some other ship whose lights we can dimly discern on the starboard.

The hour is now late and it is time for us to descend to our cabin, a tiny room but very compact with two beds fixed to the wall one bed over the other. It is easy for the man that sleeps in the
lower bed, but the man who sleeps on top has a little climbing to do before he can lie down. Sleep comes easily for the motion of the ship is more conducive to sleep than the rocking of a baby's cradle. Morning with the steward and a cup of tea, comes all too soon, but the smell of breakfast acts as a magnet to those who are hungry and one is nearly always hungry at sea.

Breakfast is now over and we wander on deck, gaze at the sea, talk to fellow passengers, perhaps read a book, or write a letter or perhaps we play some game such as quoits, shuffleboard, deck tennis or the like. At night after supper we read play cards or dance; anything for amusement, and as we play the ship continues her steady way across the ocean with the Captain and his officers constantly on the lookout for anything that may arise.

So the days pass on, full as we like to make them or as empty as it is possible for a day to be. Days and dates are lost right count of, only the number of the days aboard or the number of days to come are remembered.

It is now the sixth or seventh day and all is agog with excitement. Fellow passengers in the dining room ask us "Have you seen them?" "What?" "The berg," and as soon as breakfast is over we rush up on deck to view the sights. There they stand great masses of ice many times larger than this school, but as soon as they get into the gulf stream they will melt and become mere spots on the ocean.

Next day there's the cry "Land have you seen it?" and looking away to our right we can dimly make out the coastline of Labrador, and there on the left Newfoundland.

(In this little trip we have not been worried with sea-sickness—good for us that we have not for it is one of the most unpleasant experiences to encounter. In my own short attack of one evening's duration, to die or feel the ship sinking would have been a pleasure.)

The great ship carries on; each minute brings us a clearer view of the land ahead; each turn of the screw nearer to the land of our desire, yet farther from the bleak Home Country.

Now the land has become quite close; now we can see houses now cars moving along the road and here comes two tiny tugs to pull us into dock. Our sailors now throw rope to the waiting tug and as soon as these are attached the little tugs commence their work and tow their large sisters to the place where she is destined to rest.

As we near the shore more ropes are thrown and the ocean greyhound is made fast, the gangway is hoisted to the side of the ship, the ship settles down to a well earned rest and the passengers hurry to the shore glad to feel terra firma beneath them once again.

"Press on! If once or twice thy feet Step back and stumble, harder try,
From him who never fears to meet Danger and death, they're sure to fly."

THE FORMATION OF THE "GUIDE COMPANY"

Margaret McIntyre

LAST year in the month of October one of the teachers of the School, who once belonged to a company of guides, suggested the idea to the girls of forming a company of Guides.

One evening we all assembled in the recreation room, and sat down in a semicircle in front of the speaker. All were very much interested, and when the question was brought up, as to whether we would agree to the idea or not, you could hear nothing but a chorus of 'yes yes' from the girls.

Our Captain picked out three girls whom she thought would be capable of being leaders, and seconds to assist them. This all met with our approval. The first thing, the leaders and seconds had to get busy and learn the Guide Laws, Guide Promise and useful knots, so as to pass their Tenderfoot tests.

A friend of our Captain came for a few Saturdays and gave us lectures on being Guides. It was all very interesting. When the leaders and seconds passed their tests, they then got busy and trained the patrols for their tests.

We have every Wednesday evening and Saturday afternoon for Guide meetings and how we look forward to those days. We open the meeting by singing the National Anthem, then inspection takes place. After that we play competing games, and conclude the meeting with a sing-song.

The next question was about our uniforms. That was soon settled for the girls got up a concert and made enough to supply the company with belts and hats. The sewing matron and the girls were kept busy making our uniforms, but it was not very long before we were all equipped.

We were all excited when our Captain told us that our Commissioner was coming to enroll some of our Guides. At last the day arrived. We were determined to look our best. We took our solemn vow the Guide Promise in the new School which was not yet complete. We had little pins shaped like a clover leaf with our motto "Be Prepared" on them, pinned on our ties.

We are now all trying very hard for our second-class pins, which are more difficult but more interesting to obtain.

ON THE FRASER RIVER

Williamson Walkem

LAST June when I was to write my first year High School examination I had to go to Chilliwack for there was no High School at Lytton.

The Bishop of the Cariboo was here with Mr Cooper a friend of his from Pavilion, to confirm the older boys and girls of the School. Mr Cooper saying that the country was much to his liking was at once invited to go with us.

One Sunday afternoon we started off about two o'clock; we had a very nice trip although we had a blowout on the way. It was a lovely trip to Lytton where the Thompson River joins the Fraser. After leaving Lytton, we went far up the side of the mountain where the road was hardly passable although skilled engineering work had been done. We came to Jackass Mountain near Boston Bar, where once a whole team of mules had rolled over the mountain side into the river. Here we were about seven hundred feet above the river.

Leaving the mountain we reached Boston Bar and saw North Band just across the river. There were tunnels, bridges, springs creeks and two railroads far below us as we again left Boston Bar for Spuzzum where we crossed the Fraser and continued on our travels.

The river from Boston Bar is full of canyons, torrents and whirlpools; when we were far up the side of the mountain we could hardly see the river at Hells Gate Canyon, which is one of the most noted canyons anywhere in the world. It is about thirty feet wide and the river had been cutting its way through the solid rock for centuries.

Leaving Spuzzum we saw the most beautiful scenery in British Columbia. We stopped at the toll-gate and again when near Yale, where we saw salmon just filling a creek which meets the muddy Fraser at this point. Proceeding on our way we saw great canyons with the mountains towering above the river on each side.

Near the Chilliwack the river widens out and flows very slowly compared to the upper part of the river. This part of the road was much better. The cherries were ripe and the people were selling them to the tourists who were passing along the highway. We left Hope after supper and made a hurried trip to Chilliwack which was the end of our journey.

THE HIGH SCHOOL

MISS GREGGOR

THE High School section of St. George's School is the last lap in the race for an all-round education. A race not one of plundering blundering endeavor, but a race for the fulfillment of high or ambitions and noble aspirations.

It is here that the youth discovers in himself founts of untold hidden wealth. He is by this time, beginning to realize more fully that he is an individual, a personality with powers of his own to express; these powers is his chief ambition. He may have as a young child, vowed to have done those things which he felt he could do, but he did it for the sake of the act itself, for the mere desire of doing. When he reaches the High School age he wants more than this. He wants to become a man, to do things because they are of value to himself and to others. Feeling that he is necessary in turning the wheels of the circle in which he moves, he forces his way into various channels which appeal to him endeavoring to make a name for himself. Respect and admiration he wants irrespective of what he does or where he goes. If only lawyers and judges would remember this fact when they sentenced juveniles, many a mother's heart would be spared a grievous wound.

Although the High School section of the School was at a disadvantage to begin with in not having proper accommodation and the necessary books, it has been able to carry on. Now it is well established and undertaking tasks with real vim. New subjects such as Physics, Chemistry and Geometry are tackled and mastered. Plenty of opportunity is provided for mental gymnastics within the curriculum. In their work as well as in their play, they are learning of things about them and accordingly, how to adapt themselves to different situations which may arise. Thus equipped they should be able to face the world prepared and unafraid. It is really up to us to give them all the sympathy and encouragement we can.

Let me for one, be always able to say with the poet:

"May every soul that touches mine--
Be it the slightest contact, get there from some good
Some little grace, one kindly thought
One aspiration, yet unfelt, one bit of courage
For the darkening sky, one glimmer of faith
To brave the thickening ills of life,
One glimpse of brighter skies beyond the gathering mist,
To make this life worth while,
And Heaven a-surer heritage."
Forest Products of British Columbia.

JOHN JAMES

ALONG the Pacific Coast of British Columbia as far north as the north end of Vancouver Island, grows the most valuable timber in the world.

Amongst them the Douglas Fir is the most valuable. Its diameter averages about eight feet and its height from a Hundred and Fifty to Two Hundred feet. It is chiefly used in the making of bridges, wharfs, masts, Hardwood floors and furniture.

The next tree of importance is the Western Red Cedar which grows to a height of about a hundred and fifty feet. It is used in making shingles, canoes and laurels.

The next comes the Sitka Spruce. It grows mostly in the Queen Charlotte Islands and is used usually in the pulp-mills and for the making of aeroplanes.

The Western Hemlock is also of some value, but is surpassed in quantity by the inferior Hemlock of Canada.

THE FRASER RIVER

Paddy Kelly

THE Fraser, the largest river in British Columbia, runs past our school. It is eight hundred and forty miles long. The Thompson River is the largest tributary, it flows into the Fraser at Lytton.

There is good fishing at its mouth, and numerous ships and smaller fishing vessels travel upon its waters. Large canyons and rough rapids occur frequently.

The river starts in the Rocky Mountains near the Yellow Head Pass. As it nears Lillooet the roughest rapids called the Alexandra Rapids occur.

New Westminster is the largest city along its banks. The two railroads, The C.P.R. and C.N.R., and the Cariboo highway follow the course of the river as far as Lytton.

The river was discovered by Simon Fraser in the year eight-hundred and eight, and was named after him. It is rather a muddy river flowing very swiftly in some parts.

"THE CROSS OF SAINT GEORGE."

Rev. S.F. Higgs

Boys and girls and peoples! I wonder how it is that we usually measure happiness. Is it by what we receive or by what we give? Most of us will agree that there is something much more joyful in giving than receiving, and so some measure of joy is mastered out to me in so far as I am giving some little time to writing this, and maybe the joy is not all mine, for by the time you have read this you will find that you have had to sacrifice some of your precious minutes to give something for nothing. So we are all happy.

Now let us for one minute, take our minds off all but just one thing with which we are familiar, the School Flag, the emblem of St. George of England which is the central structure of the flag of the British Empire.

We can rightly be proud of our flag—the broad red cross on the white background—and is there not a great significance in this emblem for us? Red is the color of blood and blood is the sign of life, the purer and richer and redder the blood, the stronger and purer and sweeter will be the life. Then the blood red cross on our banner means LIFE! And the background is pure white, and if our lives are to be vigorous and unimpaired we must seek now and always to make their backgrounds glistening white, not the blanched whiteness which speaks of disease but the polished brightness of a life rightly lived.

Boys and girls do you understand? Don't let life be an endless search after good things for ourselves, remember how St. George risked all for the safety and happiness of others.

Schools are just the grandest places on earth and St. George may be as grand as any if our motto be LIFE in the purest fullest and bravest sense, remembering always to preserve before the all-seeing eyes of the Almighty and Loving God a background which is spotless white.

It is not growing like a tree
In bulk, doth make man better be;
Or standing long an oak, three hundred year,
To fall a log at last, dry, bald, and bare;
A lily in a day
Is fairer far in May
Although it fall and die that night
It was the plant and flower of Light,
In small proportions we just beauties see;

TEN JUNIOR CLASS ROOM.

Miss Bruce.

One of the most interesting depts. of St George's may truly be said to be the Junior School Room. The children come here to learn and it is in this division that they first come into actual contact with the tools of learning. To many it means the opening and conquering of a new world of knowledge. To the majority, eager for advancement, school is a serious place, where one must work to the best of one's ability. To others school is just a new experience which at first is very amusing, but later becomes just another duty, that follows in the day's round.

The Junior School Room is made up of 'A' and 'B' sections.

'B' section is the primary class. Here we find serious little anxious to handle the tools and yet rather timid to cut them into use. But with the passing of the first strangeness comes a confidence that remains with them always.

'A' section has gained that confidence. They have explored and gained a fairly good control of the language. School to them is no longer a new experience, neither is it a serious business. The beginning of their school life is a thing of the past, the end a thing in the distant future. Their work is competitive, their school day a competition, permeated with that sense of friendly rivalry, that is present in all class rooms.

Hence you see the Junior department is an opening and continuation of the first stages, in the education of the children of St George's School.

CANADIAN GIRL GUIDES AT ST. GEORGE'S SCHOOL.

Miss Richmond.

The Girl Guides, although a world wide movement did not reach St George's School until Oct. 1927. From its first mention in the girls playroom until the present it has filled a place in the girls' life which other activities have failed to supplant.

Of course the chief trouble has always been lack of funds, but here the girls have done their work and part nobly, both in contributing their two cents weekly and also in working for their concert, by means of which they were able to buy hats and belts for themselves. The material for their uniforms was given by the school and was made up by the girls under the able direction of Miss Spencer who was then sewing matron. We have to thank the first B.C. Lone Rangers for our paddy green ties which we proudly wear to show that we are members of the 1st Lytton Company of Girl Guides, the first native Company in B.C., and the second in Canada.

At present there are twenty-eight girls in the company grouped into four patrols, the Red Rose, Primrose, Forget-me-nots and the Laffodils. These patrols carry on a friendly warfare in their endeavor to come first in neatness games etc.

At the meetings which are held on Wed. evenings, instruction is given in first aid, signalling and all branches of guide work. I think I am safe in saying that Wed. night is the most enjoyable evening of the whole week.

Guiding is intended to instil in the girls comradeship, loyalty, obedience, and above all to guide or show them the way to upright womanhood. We hope that this is being accomplished in the 1st Lytton Company.

St. George's New School

Our new school is built of red brick with a flat roof. The walls inside are plastered and the stairs and the basement floors are made of concrete. There are four dormitories on the girls' side and four on the boys' side. The boys and girls have each a sitting room or study. FIRST IMPRESSIONS OF ST GEORGE'S SCHOOL

Miss Tebbutt

They are varied and contrasting. Perhaps I should start with my arrival in Dayton. I was met by your beloved Principal who gave me a small but pleasant surprise. How different was this bluff hearty man from the picture I had formed in my mind. Mr Lett introduced himself quite informally, giving me a feeling that in this new country away from all I loved, I was not to be without a friend.

We started off over the winding road to the school. Soon I beheld before me an old dilapidated building. Surely this was not the building! You see boys and girls I had not heard of your new school. What a difference when we came in view of the building of which you are so proud. What a fine place, an ideal situation—with the grand old hills all around and the river running below.

I entered the building and gradually I came to know each member of the staff. Then I was shown over the school. First we entered the schoolrooms, how nice and airy the place where boys and girls must enjoy their studies. Then I had a peep into the dormitories where each little bed was in place, everything bright and neat. When I entered the Dining-room I saw for the first time the young people who live at St George's, and day by day I have grown to know you by sight and by name and shall go on through the year gradually getting acquainted with you known and loved of B.C.
ONCE upon a time there were two boys in the school, named Peter Ender and Smith Bant. They spent their time in singing and telling stories to the little boys before they went to bed. They were the best of friends and shared with each other, their fruit and candy, and so they were very happy.

One day Peter grew tired of being good to Smith. "Smith" said he to his companion, "life is very dull with every day the same I am tired of seeing you so cheerful so let us have a quarrel."

"Very Well Peter," said Smith looking rather grave, for he did not like the idea. "But what can we quarrel about?" he asked.

"Well" said Peter doubtfully, "I can't tell you not to use my bike because you never use it anyway. And I can't steal your fruit or candy for you always want me to share yours. "I have it" he cried, after a moment's thought; "Smith, do you see that sack of good red apples over there, you say its yours, and I'll say its mine so we'll have a squabble."

"All right," said Smith, "only you must begin." He clenched his hands and tried to look ugly and Peter did the same.

They were quite changed from the kindly smiling boys they had been a moment before. Peter pointed to the sack of apples and said gruffly, "I want you to understand that those apples are mine, and if I catch you trying to steal some I'll knock every hair off your head until you are bald."

Such fierceness made Smith jump. "I beg your pardon, pardner Peter," he said in amazement.

"Don't call me 'pardner'," was the rough reply. "Behave respectfully to your betters. Understand that that sack of apples is mine, do you deny it?"

Smith could hardly get his breath but he managed to stammer out, "Your apples are they?"

"Yes, my apples and mind they belong to me, and I am going to have them."

"Why of course they're yours Peter, and if you'll wait a minute I'll get you some more."

"I suppose we must give up trying to squabble, for it takes two to make a quarrel," said Peter.

So they burst out laughing and went into the basement to share their apples.

From that day on they have never quarreled. Instead they have told stories to the little boys and then sent them to bed.

We play Basket ball at night after the smaller boys go to bed, and we all enjoy playing it. There are just certain nights that we play on and these are Tuesday Thursday and Saturday. Once there was a bear who was hungry, for he hadn't had anything to eat for a long time. MONDAY AND FRIDAY NIGHTS.

Hazel Phillips

I am going to tell you how we spend Monday and Friday nights before we go to bed. Whose are the two nights we always look forward to? Oh, I mustn't forget Wednesday night when we have fun again at our Girl Guild's meeting.

After supper when we have finished our work we put on our gymnasium clothes and hustle into our big Gymnasium.

The 'Seconds' choose their side and start as soon as they can, for they cannot stay up as long as the seniors.

You should see the girls playing with all their might, we certainly have an exceptionally good time. My and the shouts from the onlookers when the ball falls into the basket or happens to slip down into someone's eager hands. Off it goes this way and that way and into a basket. Then the senior team goes on for a while. They are a strong team alright. Most of them being promising good players. We all play with pep in this game and it keeps us feeling fit till the next night.

ACTIVITIES AMONGST THE BOYS.

The course of training which is given to the boys after school is extensive and varied, covering such subjects as Squad Drill, Physical Training, Signaling, lectures on First Aid, Health and Hygiene; Clean Speech, Clean Sports and Clean Living; and last but not least some of the games—Basketball, Football, Volleyball, and group games all of which go a long way in developing a boy's body, mind and character.

We have our Squad Drill P.T. and games on Tuesday Thursday and Saturday evenings from 7 to 9 o'clock. The juniors and intermediates have their time in the morning from 10 to 11 o'clock and in the afternoon from 2 to 3 o'clock.

The boys right from the beginning have shown wonderful aptitude in learning the new movements and exercises. At present we busy practicing and perfecting our physical work for our concert which will be held early in Nov. Look out for the date.

The boys have also shown a great interest in their first aid and we are also practicing for our first aid demonstration.

We have greatly enjoyed throughout the summer, our visits to the old swimming hole. The boys certainly have a great time. If they didn't get into the water fast enough 'Sandy' chased them back in, but the boys didn't mind that in fact they rather enjoyed it. Unfortunately it is all over for this year.

Sometimes in the evenings we have sing songs round the piano which we all enjoy. I don't know whether those who listen to us enjoy it or not, but anyway whether we 'Sing' or not we make a joyful noise.

Our Labor Day picnic which is dealt with elsewhere was a great success. We went across the river, had our lunch near the stores then went to Earlscourt and got some apples, swam for an hour or so then home.

Our hikes have started, our first one being taken the other evening in the moonlight. We all are looking forward to this being our best year at St George's School.

Dear Mr. Chamberlain:

Dear Dr. Scott:

I am writing a letter to you, the nature of which might at first seem a little puzzling, but of which you will understand the reasonableness. It is written in confidence and is not intended to convey any impressions of illwill felt or expressed towards anyone.

From information received I feel that there is a possibility of the Principleship of St. George's School, at Lytton, becoming vacant. This may or may not be likely, but at any rate it is a possibility, and in consideration of this I am writing this letter.

We have met in Lytton, Dr. Scott as I have been in the Indian work for three years now, and was here during your visit in 1928. Since I arrived in Lytton, through personal contact with the Indians, living in their homes, entering as far as possible into their lives, I have learned to love them, and would say with certainty and humility that I would consider it an honour to devote, and if necessary, to sacrifice all I possess in their service. This is not said idly as I realize that the future prosperity of the Indians, if it is to be more than an ever elusive ideal, will only be purchased by the
exp diture of still more service and sacrifice on the part of Christian men. If it were not for the love that I have for the Thompson Indians I would not consider myself in any way capable of assisting them in the great effort that they are making and must make to secure for themselves a creditable position among the civilized people of the world today.

And this letter is expressly an offer of my services, in the hope that such as they are they will be accepted in the event of a vacancy occurring at St. George's School, whether it occur soon or at some distant date.

It is necessary to advertise myself, and I hope you will not consider me presumptuous in doing so.

I shall be 27 in April, having been ordained in 1927 at Lambeth Palace, Eng., by the Late Archbishop of Canterbury, for work among the Thompson Indians. I was educated at King Edward's School, Birmingham, and St. Augustine's College, Canterbury, where I spent five years in special missionary training, and obtained my L.Th.of Durham University. I left home on the completion of my college course and have been working in Lytton until now.

I am keenly interested in sport, having had the opportunity of leading my college friends in several departments of this integral part of School life.

I have had a fair amount of contact with the St. George's School as I am chiefly supported in my position here by the New England Company for the purpose of caring for the ex-pupils of the School.

During the past year I was successful in obtaining, from Archbishop de Fencier, a cup which was presented to the School for competition upon the lines of the English House
tem; and under the name of the Divisional system, this competition has been introduced, as it was submitted by me, into every branch of the School life --- work, sport and industry, and in the words of the Principle to me a month ago; "It has revolutionized the whole School". I mention this in an endeavour to indicate the deep rooted interest which I feel, and will always try to express in the future prosperity of the Indians.

I have no knowledge of the salary paid to the Principle of St. George's School, and whether it is small or large it does not act as a deterrent or an attraction. The money end does not influence me so long as it is adequate.

My interest in the Indians, Dr. Scott, is genuine. Since the beginning of the year Dr. Renison, the Dean of Christ Church Cathedral, Vancouver, B.C., offered me the position of curate at the Cathedral, a position holding very great possibilities to a young man, and in almost every respect more congenial than the Missionary work I am doing; not to mention a 50% increase in salary and a greatly reduced overhead. To arrive at a decision was difficult, but in deciding to remain in the Indian Mission work I feel I have done what is right, and I shall be happy to devote many more years' work in the cause of the people, whom, as very dear brothers and sisters, I love.

I returned from Vancouver, Dr. Scott, with the conviction that I had been guided to decline the offer of work at the Cathedral because there was a very special work to be done before I severed my connection with the Thompson Indians; and I feel that if, as a result of the Principleship of St. George's School becoming vacant, and my recommendation being satisfactory, I am enabled to occupy that position, I can best express my real love for my new countrymen through the channels which such a position offers.
I may be premature in submitting this, but I do it with confidence. Dr. Scott assured me that should such an occasion as I suggest arise you will give this your apt consideration.

I have, what I imagine is not easily obtained, the confidence of the Indians, of this I have been recently assured in an unsolicited recommendation which the Indians sent to the Bishop of Cariboo, asking that my position among them be made a permanent one; they have asked my permission to send a similar letter to you, and under the circumstances I have expressed my willingness for them to do so. Other qualifications, such as I possess, may be better deduced from recommendations from several people, which I can subsequently submit, if you should require them.

For the present I am pleased at all times to forward the work which the Rev. A.R. Lett is doing at the School.

With pleasant memories of our meeting in 1928,

I am, Sir,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

P.S. I am enclosing a copy of a letter of recommendation which I received from Dr. S.F. Tolmie at the beginning of the month.

Dear Mr. Strang,

For the past couple of years I have been thinking of making application to the Department for the extension of our Summer holidays to eight weeks, instead of six. My reasons for coming to this conclusion are twofold; one is, that our children realizing that their white neighbours receive two months vacation and that they themselves should be recognised accordingly. In a great many cases their return to school is tardy and it has been very difficult to get the children back by the 1st. Sept., in fact for the last two years I have not been able to make up my full quota for quite two weeks after the school has opened and have therefore not been able to do much in the class rooms for that length of time. The fact of the children knowing that neighbouring schools receive two months holiday increases our difficulties.

Secondly, some of our teachers wish to attend Summer Schools and their return here in the middle of August interferes with the course as such courses do not finish until about August 25th. It is true that this year there may not be any Provincial Summer Schools, but this will only apply to 1931.

I think on the whole it would be a benefit to the children and to the school if the Department could see fit to allow us a full two months vacation, and trust that this application will be favourably received.

There has heretofore been strong objection in the Hop Industry where so many of our Indians have been putting in time, but the majority of our children coming from families who depend on their own farms, relieves this objection, and I really think that the children would be better for the added two weeks.

Yours very obediently,

Sir:

I have your 9305-06 of the 14th instant, with enclosure, concerning an extra two weeks' holiday for the pupils of the St. George's Indian Residential School. The difficulties concerning which Mr. Lett writes are common throughout Canada, and, after careful consideration, the Department has decided that 43 days' holiday with grant is all that can be allowed. There are a few exceptions, where there are seasonal occupations and where the children accompany the parents, but this does not obtain in central British Columbia. If, in any particular year, it is desired that the 6 weeks be changed, to permit of teachers attending a convention, the Department has no objection, in other words, have the annual holiday commence on July 15th.

Concerning the comparison that is made with the provincial public schools, it is simple enough to explain to the parents that these are day schools and that Indian day schools take two months' holidays. Residential schools, however, are allowed but 43 days with grant.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Dr. Scott,

I have been feeling lately that I should have a recess and wondered if you could see your way clear to allow me two and a half months holiday, with salary and fare East, having almost ten years service without break or expense to the Department.

I would very much like to go East to visit my Mother who is getting on in years and is anxious to see me, and also to spend some time with friends. I would like if possible to get away by the 1st June, or shortly afterwards, returning to open school in the middle of August.

I feel the need of a period away from the school as my health has not been good of late, being unable to cast off Bronchial trouble and having also been under the care of the Doctor for an ulcerated stomach. The change in climate and a lessening of responsibility I feel is very necessary.

My car has covered a mileage of some 40,000 and is therefore due for some expensive repairs, unless it is re-placed and in order that I might be independent when in the East, I wondered whether it could be arranged to allow The New England quarterly grant to go towards a new car and also my fare, turning in my present car locally, which would bring in $200, and picking up a new car at the factory, saving freight by driving back

as I would then visit friends in Manitoba and Alberta.

AUDIT REPORT

Period January 1st. to July 15/41.
Date of Audit - October 9, 1941.

In accordance with instructions the financial transactions of the school were thoroughly examined so far as they related to the period, January 1st., to July 15th., and certain transactions which had received criticism in preliminary reports by Departmental officers were carefully investigated.

REVENUE

Either the former principal had received no instruction as to the method of recording financial transactions or he had ignored them. His only book of original entry for Revenue received was a common exercise book, or scribbler. Monies received were entered therein without mention of date or the name of the party from whom received, and the jumble of figures with recapitulations and adjustments, made it extremely difficult to pick out the cash items accurately and impossible to assign a particular item to its source.

The totals from this record were entered in the cash book each month and allocated to "Farm" or "Miscellaneous."

The entries in the exercise book or Cash Blotter were checked against the entries in the Cash Book, and the Cash Book entries were checked against the deposits of the School account in the Bank of Montreal, Ashcroft, B.C.

Speaking generally, it was ultimately possible to reconcile most of the entries and the differences are small. There is an apparent double entry of a cash item in the Blotter and Cash Book in July. An account rendered to the Post Store appeared to be outstanding - amount $61.14 for June, although there was an entry in July for $61.85. Enquiry at the store showed that a cheque had been issued for $68.14 covering also an account of $7.00 of which there was no record in the School office. Another item received from another source was for $15.71 and this was recorded, but the next entry was for $65.85, and it is reasonably evident that an error occurred.

Another item in February was for $1.46, but the only sale for a similar amount at that time is for $11.46.

Certain Revenue for sale of beef - lot 47 - was not put through the Cash Book, but this will be reported fully in a later section.

Farm Sales

Farm produce, including meat, dairy products, vegetables and fodder, surplus to school requirements, is sold at prevailing wholesale prices, principally local dealers. The Farm Manager recorded these sales in counter sales books and from the duplicates the school principal prepared monthly statements which were rendered quite promptly so far as I could ascertain. Unfortunately, copies of statements as rendered, except for a few current ones, were not available and I was informed that these were destroyed when the account was paid or carried forward. It was not possible, therefore, to check the Farm Manager's record against the statements issued, nor to check the statements against the receipts in the Cash Blotter. This applied particularly to the small cash sales which could not be identified in the blotter except in a few instances.

An additional complication which affected sales was the transactions in beef from lot 47, and these are described here before attempting the reconciliation between Farm Sales and Farm Revenue.

Beef - Lot 47

On November 30th., 1940, Mr. Lett borrowed $1,000.00 in his own name on a demand note from the Bank of Montreal, Ashcroft, to cover the purchase of thirty-one head of cattle for which he paid $1105.00. The cattle were placed on Lot 47 and subsequently sold to the School, or local dealers, as beef at prevailing prices. A separate Bank account was opened in the name of A. R. Lett. The loan was increased on January 28th., 1941, by $110.00.

Credits for sales put through this account amounted to $1175.92 between January 1st., and July 15th. Bank charges were $31.09 and a balance of $74.83 was transferred on July 14th., to the School account and credited to Farm Revenue.

Two additional animals were purchased from an Indian (Spike) from School funds, and one died, making the number for disposal thirty-two. Nine were sold to the School,

The School Principal evidently made a practice of handling various transactions and funds outside the main School account, in whole or in part, and there is no complete record of these activities available; further information is desirable particularly with respect to the operation of a booth selling Ice Cream, Soft Drinks and Candy on May 24th, last.

Sports Day - May 24th

A member of the staff - Mr. Egleston - was assigned to the refreshment booth and, although he was not available for questioning at the time of the audit, he has made a statement to the Acting Principal and to Inspectors Coleman and Barry, that the receipts turned over by him to Mr. Lett were approximately $152.00. There is the possibility that some accounts were paid from the proceeds by Postal Money Order as was done with other candy transactions and it is quite probable that Mr. Lett can furnish a complete and satisfactory explanation, which he should be requested to do.

Handicrafts - Manual Training & Wool

Articles made of various woods are produced by the Indian Boys under the direction of Mr. Maclean. They vary from small bric-a-brac to fairly large pieces of furniture. They are sold at the School through local stores and some articles are on consignment to merchants at more distant points. No definite records are kept of these articles and transactions. Any cash received in the office is credited to General Revenue.

Mr. Maclean makes some sales and sends out local consignments, and the former principal did the same and established most of the selling prices, but neither apparently kept any record.

It should be a simple matter for the Instructor to furnish the office with an inventory of finished articles on hand, and to supply a weekly list of additional articles produced. The selling price of each article should be determined so it is placed in stock and not varied without the approval of the Principal.

Articles sent on consignment should be invoiced and an account opened for each consignee. Counter sales slips should record every article to leave Mr. Maclean's stock and every article returned to stock. A separate account should be opened in the General Ledger for this class of handicraft.

The same procedure should apply to articles of wool, etc., produced under the direction of Miss Joblin.

The Revenue marked "Handicraft" in the Cash Slatter totals $191.84 for the period under review, exclusive of the rent of $50.00 per School month for Manual Training.

There are no particulars as to source and no distinction between the two classes of Handicraft.

A list of articles produced from September, 1940, to June, 1941, as prepared by Mr. Maclean, is attached.
Handicraft articles are on consignment at the R. R. Stores and the New Lytton Hotel, Lytton, and Cottage Crafts, Hope, B. C. It is also surmised that articles are on consignment at the Hudson's Bay Co., or Spencers, Ltd., at Vancouver and Victoria, B. C., but apparently there is no record and no present member of the staff knows definitely. The situation should be amended quickly.

Lease Rentals

The former lessee of Lot 47, George Henry, claims to have paid rental in full for the term of the lease which expired prior to the period covered by this audit. Payments are stated to have been in cash or produce. Receipts cannot be produced. The Indian Commissioner is furnishing the Department with a detailed statement.

EXPENDITURE

Payments through the School account totalled $21,324.16 and accounts payable at July 15th, totalled $2,976.26. This latter figure appears to be complete although there is the possibility of other unpaid accounts turning up.

There is no system of recording commitments. Purchase orders are not used and even the Principal could have had no accurate idea of just what the School's liabilities were at any given time.

So far as could be ascertained from the vouchers and information available, all the expenditures, paid and unpaid, are a proper charge to the School with one or two possible exceptions. Monthly paylists were not prepared but a check of the salaries and wages, including Mr. Lett's indicates that these charges are correct.

It has not been possible to determine the unpaid accounts at January 1st., 1943, so that the true expenditure applicable to the audit period cannot be ascertained.

The account of the Fraser Valley Produce for $34.00 covering Ice Cream supplied to the School for May 24th., has not been paid. It can be paid as the Ice Cream was undoubtedly supplied and Mr. Lett can be asked for an explanation of the operation of the refreshment booth on May 24th., and his apparent failure to account for the estimated receipts of $150.00.

The account of Mark Drummond (Ashcroft) for $129.22 covering fencing supplied to the School has not been paid. At least the cheque is being held. This could be released as the account is in order.

Cheques Nos. 155 of June 24th., for $114.00 and 165 of July 9th., for $105.65, total $223.65, were made payable to George Henry, the Indian employed at Lot 47 to attend to the bear cattle. This Indian was also paid wages by the School at the rate of $50.00 per month.

The Indian's story is that he was requested by Mr. Lett to endorse these two cheques, but that he did not see or otherwise handle them.
Investigation shows that Mr. Lett took this way of securing part payment for beef supplied to the School and deposited this amount to the credit of his special beef account to help retire the Bank loan mentioned previously.

It is clear, after considerable investigation, that these monies are accounted for and that no loss to the School resulted, but the manner in which this transaction was put through, and indeed all the transactions relating to lot 47, leave Mr. Lett open to most severe censure.

Balances of accounts payable at July 15th., remaining unpaid at time of audit, are Kelly Douglas, $200.00; Leckie Shoe Co., $200.00; Gillespie Grain Co., $100.00, and Vancouver Island Coal Co., $500.00 - a total of $800.00. These will be retired when funds are considered to be available for this purpose.

A list of accounts payable at July 15th., is attached.

A statement of disbursements by accounts is attached.

Compensation - B.C. Workmen's

To comply with the requirements of the B.C. Act the following employees are subject to deductions for medical aid and the School is required to pay the usual assessment.

Laundry Matron - Miss Augustine
Manual Training Instructor - Mr. Maclean
Engineer - Mr. Cooper

Mr. Jones, the Farm Manager, under an arrangement made by Mr. Lett with the agent of the Mutual Benefit Association, Vancouver, has a personal accident policy with a premium of $2.50 a quarter. This has been in force two years. Mr. Jones pays the premium and is then reimbursed by the School for one-half of the premium.

Mr. Jones' explanation is that it is considered cheaper for both employer and employee than ordinary compensation contributions.

The transaction appears to be quite irregular and the Indian Commissioner, Major Mackay, is being asked to discuss the question of compensation as it relates to the School with officers of the Board in Vancouver.

GENERAL

It is obvious that there has been no effective Departmental or financial control of the operation of this School. One man, the Principal, has been in the position to spend large sums of money as he saw fit and has not been...
required to maintain even simple records of his transactions. He has engaged in various ventures outside the School accounts, but on behalf of the School, and has used the School credit in doing so. The finances have, accordingly, been quite involved.

However, there is nothing in the record to show that the late Principal, Mr. Lett, used School funds for other than School purposes, provided he can furnish a satisfactory explanation concerning the disposition of the cash presumably received from Mr. Eggleston on May 24th. He deserves criticism for the manner in which the funds were handled.

The true standing of the School's financial position has not been disclosed and if the Department is entirely responsible for the operation, then steps should be taken to instil an effective control.

Monthly estimates of expenditure and revenue could be submitted through the Indian Agent at Lytton, to the Commissioner at Vancouver, for approval. If these were followed by a monthly financial statement the Commissioner could accept some responsibility for the School's operation. Consideration should also be given to having the Indian Agent countersign all cheques drawn on the School account.

Receipts, purchase orders, paylists and timesheets should be introduced and the Principal should engage a suitable clerk to ensure that records will be kept properly.

An interim financial routine was prepared and left with the Acting Principal, Mr. Stewart, and this could be confirmed or amended by the Department, as considered advisable. A form of financial statement was included and a copy of the instruction is attached.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, was present at the School during the greater part of the audit and afforded valuable assistance, as did the Indian Agent at Lytton, Mr. Strang.

Appreciation is also due to the Acting Principal of the School, Mr. Noel Stewart, and the Farm Manager, Mr. Vaughan-Jones, who produced records and information and afforded every possible assistance.

The audit was facilitated by the preliminary investigations made by Agencies Inspector Coleman and School Inspector Barry.

I am satisfied that I received all the information available at the time of audit.

Financial Routine for Acting Principal Stewart

1. Secure a supply of receipts books with suitable stubs or preferably in duplicate and issue a receipt for each item of cash received in the office. Mark the office copy very plainly with the account to be credited.

2. Enter receipts in Cash Book from the receipt stubs or duplicate and make the distribution to accounts at the same time. There is no apparent necessity for a subsidiary or supplementary Cash Book.

3. See that the bank deposit coincides with the total of receipts to the time of the deposit.

4. Request the bank to allow deposit in full and make a debit for any exchange on cheques included in the deposit.

5. Write cheques to cover all disbursements. If necessary to make cash payments, write cheque for total of a list and deposit. Suggest advance for principal and all cash disbursements for expenses to be later paid by cheque, restoring the advance to the original amount.

6. Enter cheque number on each paid voucher and file vouchers in cheque number order by months.

7. Show allocation by accounts on voucher or cheque stub and distribute accordingly in cash book.

8. Endeavour to pay all accounts in months in which they occur to simplify determination of current standing at any month's end.

9. Definite pay list should be prepared at the end of each month, showing gross salary or wages, deductions, net amount, distribution of deductions by classes, such as board, N.D.Tax, Workmen's Compensation, War Savings Certificates, Etc.

Cheques can then be written to the staff and employees and also the Department of National Revenue, Workmen's Compensation, War Savings Certificates, etc., from the same voucher; i.e., the paylist. If possible, date the cheques the last day of the month or period embraced.

10. When the Bank Statement is received, enter any charges for exchange as one amount, total and cross-balance the Cash Book and reconcile with Bank Statement.

12. At the end of each month write a cheque in favour of the school for value of farm produce delivered to school and deposit this. This will bring this transaction within the scope of simple cash book system.

13. To avoid opening ledger accounts for the present, the following procedure could be adopted:

"After the monthly totals of the cash book have been entered and balanced, post the previous total immediately underneath and add to give totals to date. This three-line total plan will give essential information and facilitate the auditor's check."

14. Any further development of accounts to be maintained should be advised by the Department.

15. Centralized control of school finances is essential and this applies particularly to the ordering of goods or services and payment for the same.

All orders or commitments should be placed or incurred only with the approval of the Principal or his Deputy, and any emergency order placed otherwise should be confirmed immediately. A supply of official purchase order forms would be an advantage, and these should be numbered and copies filed.

When an invoice is received, the copy of the purchase order should be attached and filed with the account when paid. If all orders bear an estimated cost, the orders remaining on file will furnish a total at any time of outstanding accounts or commitments.

Payment in cash by employees should be permitted only for necessary travelling expenses, small items for freight, express, etc. These claims for reimbursements should be submitted at least monthly, and these accounts should be paid by cheque.

16. Some endeavour should be made to budget the school and, very particularly, the farm's finances. The farm manager and other heads of departments should furnish the Principal with estimates of revenues and expenditure for the ensuing year. These should be examined carefully and discussed from time to time and then fitted into the budget which the school knows from experience is reasonable. Monthly estimates should then be submitted to the Principal for approval of the next month's programme. Expenditure must be kept within income.

17. The Manual Training section should list the current stock of saleable articles—priced as agreed upon. A list of additions to stock should be furnished monthly. All sales, whether for cash or on consignment, should be recorded by the school's sales book. These should be in triplicate—one with the books, one with the office, and one with Mr. McLean. Returns to stock should be recorded in the same manner and plainly marked "RETURNED".

Stock taking should be at least annual, and this should be carefully checked and balanced with the book record.

Accounts should be opened for all persons having goods on consignment.

18. All transactions should go through the school books and there should be no separate ventures with separate bank accounts.

Purchases of candy should be paid for by the school and proceeds of sale credited.

As you are no doubt aware, a recent audit of the books of the St. George's Residential School indicated that the bookkeeping was extremely unsatisfactory as it did not show the financial position of the school.

I refer to the fact that we feel that Indian residential schools should not engage in extensive commercial activities. Dear Mr. Jones:

I desire to refer to my letter to you dated May 6 of this year and your reply thereto dated July 10, 1941.

You will be interested to learn that we have appointed the Reverend C. F. Hives as principal of the St. George's School, Lytton, British Columbia. Mr. Hives, I may state, has had 25 years' experience in the operation of Indian residential schools. Half of this period was spent by him as principal of the Lac la Ronge Anglican Residential School, Saskatchewan, and half as principal of the Shingwauk Home Residential School, Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario. Mr. Hives reported for duty at the St. George's School on October 20.

I am personally of the opinion that we have been fortunate in securing the services of Mr. Hives. Apart from his lengthy experience in Indian educational work, he has always been deeply interested in the welfare of his pupils, not only during their sojourn at school but during the years immediately following their graduation. Mr. Hives has always been recognized by the Department as one of our most successful principals, and I feel confident he will be in a position to make a worthwhile contribution at the St. George's School.
