Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have received your letter of February 17th, your file 165-0-1 regarding St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C.

The attention of Reverend Mr. Hives was called on three separate occasions to the instructions issued by the Department with respect to the monthly financial statement required and, each time the Principal promised that the return would be submitted without undue delay. Just prior to the receipt of your letter, I wrote to Indian Agent Strang instructing him to visit the school and, if necessary, assist the Principal in compiling the statement required. On February 20th a copy of the financial report covering the period October 1st, 1941 to January 31st, 1942, was received here and, it was assumed that the original copy of the report had been sent direct by Mr. Strang to the Department. Mr. Strang has been requested to advise me just what was done in this connection and, instructed to submit these returns in future to this office for transmission to the Department. I enclose herewith an amended copy of the return in question received from Mr. Strang today. In discussing the matter a few days ago with Mr. Hives he assured me that, in future, these returns would be sent in promptly.

Although it was difficult for me to arrange to do so, I have found it possible to visit the school on two occasions since Mr. Hives assumed his duties as Principal. Outside of evidence of dissatisfaction among the teaching staff, and indications of a desire on their part to resign, things appeared to be satisfactory, considering that Mr. Hives was new to St. George's and its problems, and that he was in the process of organizing the school along the lines he felt would produce the best results. Perhaps I should add, however, that I was somewhat disturbed to find a tendency on the part of the qualified teachers to seek employment elsewhere.
At the present time, I doubt, if Mr. Hives has a single teacher on his staff holding a Canadian Teaching Certificate. Inspector Barry and I were very sorry to see Mr. Noel Stewart leave St. George's. The reasons for Mr. Stewart's resignation are not entirely clear but, it would appear that it was largely due to very definite differences of opinion with respect to the academic work and control of the children. Mr. Stewart's record with the Department is regarded here as a highly satisfactory one, and it is unfortunate that at a time when so few certificated teachers of his experience and ability are available, that we should lose him from our service. These matters are mentioned at this time not in any way as a criticism of Mr. Hives or his administration of the school, but to advise you of the changes that have occurred in the teaching staff since Mr. Hives took over.

In addition to my own visits to St. George's, Inspector Barry spent some time at the school on November 17th, and Mr. Indian Agent Strang is a frequent visitor and, according to Mr. Hives, has been most helpful to him.

At the request of the Reverend Principal, I have arranged for Inspector Barry to visit St. George's on Tuesday next to assist the teachers and lay down a plan of work for the various grades for the balance of the school year. It is also intended to have Captain Barry make a thorough inspection of this school sometime in May at which time it should be possible to make a fairly accurate assessment of the class room work accomplished and the general administration of the school under the Principalship of Mr. Hives.

I shall have Inspector Barry report briefly on conditions as he finds them at the school following his visit on Tuesday next, and will furnish the Department with a copy of same when received. In the meantime I should like to assure you that your instructions with respect to keeping a close check on the administration of the school will not be overlooked.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Major MacKay:

At the direct request of the Rev. C. Hives, and acting on your instructions, I have visited the St. George's Indian Residential School, Anglican Church, Lytton Agency. Yesterday I was at the school from about 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., and again from 8 p.m. to 10 p.m. To-day I was at the school from about 10 a.m. to 2:30 p.m.

During the morning and afternoon sessions yesterday and again this morning I spent the whole of the available time in the classrooms. The various teachers were given detailed instruction and advice with regard to the work to be undertaken in each Grade and Sub Grade. Mr. R.M. Allen, the teacher of the senior boys' observed while I taught in Miss A.M.H. Flower's senior girls' class and Miss Flower observed while I taught in Mr. Allen's class and also while I was in Miss J. Hives's classroom. In this way Miss Flower in particular and Mr. Allen to a lesser extent obtained some knowledge of the work to be done in subjects and Grades not taught in their own classrooms.

At the close of the class instruction yesterday afternoon I held a teachers' meeting to answer questions and deal with more general professional matters not covered during my actual visits to the various classrooms. In addition to the above teachers Mrs. I. W. Ansell, teacher of the Primary Sub Grades attended this meeting.

In the evening and at the request of the Reverend Principal I gave a lecture lasting about an hour on Indian Education in B.C. This lecture was similar to that given some time ago to the University Branch of the British Columbia Teachers Federation at the University of British Columbia. After the lecture I answered questions, some dozen or so members of the staff of St. George's School were present at this lecture. Following the lecture refreshments were served in the Principal's residence to all members of my audience who cared to attend.

During my stay at the school I visited the children at their meals on two occasions, and also with the Reverend Principal visited the kitchens, boys' basement, Manual Training shop and certain other parts of the school.

The whole of my visit to St. George's School was for the purpose of rendering any assistance possible to the new teachers and to the Reverend Principal himself. It was in no sense an inspection of the school, and therefore the usual report is not being forwarded. A regular inspection will be carried out at a later date.

My last report on this school is dated September 10th 1941. At that time Mr. N. Stewart was Acting Principal of the school, and was also in charge of the Senior Boys' Class. He was a certificated teacher holding an Alberta First Class Certificate and had ten years experience in Indian schools.

At the time of my last inspection the remaining classroom teachers were:

Miss Dora P. White  
First Class B.C. Certificate  
and nine years experience in Indian schools.

Miss W. Fisher  
Second Class Manitoba Certificate  
and fifteen years experience including two years in Indian schools.

Miss E.H. Walkem  
Indian, on first appointment with only a few weeks teaching experience and holding an Interim First Class B.C. Certificate.

The whole of the above qualified teachers have left St. George's School since the appointment of the present Principal and are now engaged in war activities. As far as I can discover none of these teachers were satisfied to remain on the staff under the present Principal.

I am particularly sorry to lose the services of Miss Walkem, towards whose education at the Victoria Normal School the Department had made a grant, and who did splendid work here I find by the response to my questions and teaching in the Junior Classroom which she left only a few weeks ago. The various Grades taught by her are well above the average for this time of the year.

It is of course particularly difficult to obtain qualified certificated teachers at the present time. The teachers listed below none of whom hold Provincial Certificates are at present in charge of the various classrooms.

Senior Boys:
Mr. Richard Edward Allen, age 31, educated Vancouver College and at the Anglican Theological School attached to the University of British Columbia. Mr. Allen has Senior Matriculation standing and has taught for some six years in Private Boys' Schools in Vancouver and West Vancouver.

Senior Girls:
Miss Alwen Mary Homer Flower, age 35, educated in England and holding the English Board of Education Certificate for Elementary schools following a two years training in Truro, England. This girl has had some ten years teaching experience in English elementary schools.

Junior Grades:
Miss Jean Leona Hives, age 21, daughter of the Reverend Principal. Miss Hives passed part of the Junior Matriculation test in Ontario and took at least one year's music in Toronto.

Primary Room:
Mrs Ivy Winnifred Ansell, age 36, Mrs Ansell did not complete her certificate as a teacher in England where she however taught about two years. Coming to B.C. she taught for about four years in various private schools.
Of the above teachers only Miss Flower can be considered a professional. She appears to me to be a highly capable teacher. Mr. Allen may or may not prove a success. As far as I could learn in Vancouver he is not noted as a successful teacher. With the professional assistance which I have given to him during the present visit to St. George's School he may do better. Though he is qualified to enter the Vancouver Normal School he would not appear to have considered it worth his while to take the course there, and has therefore no B.C. certificate.

Miss Hives is only acting as a substitute teacher in the classroom till such time as the reverend Principal can find a qualified teacher. She was and is also acting as a girls' supervisor at the school, or in some such capacity. Miss Hives is most anxious to teach as well as she can and I do not think she is neglecting the classroom work.

Mrs. Ansell does not appear to me to be a very successful teacher, but here again she may do much better now that she has some idea of what is required in the teaching of the Primary Sub Grades in an Indian school. She has a very good background and was at Oxford following her partial training in England.

Apart from the fact that none of the teacher at the school hold Provincial certificates recognized in Canada, I must say that the general conditions found to exist in the various classrooms are quite satisfactory at the present time. The whole of the teachers are sincere in their desire to do their best for the children. They all appeared very glad indeed to have my advice, and all took notes throughout my two day visit.

After my proposed regular inspection of the school in May next, when various standard tests will be given to the children, it will be possible to judge better the success or failure of the various teachers now employed at St. George's.

The food being supplied to the children appears to me to be excellent in every way.

Fire drills are organized and the Manual Training is being properly carried out.

The children appear quite happy. They are certainly under much better control than on the occasion of previous visits. I do not know just how much corporal punishment there is at the school. This matter will be gone into in greater detail in my next report.

From the various Class lists handed to me by the teachers there would appear to be 79 boys and 84 girls at the moment in the school. I saw all of these children except one boy in Grade 3 who was ill. I am not perfectly certain that these numbers are correct but they may be taken as approximate.

The whole of the school was much cleaner than on the occasion of any former visit.

I trust that the information contained in this brief report on my visit to St. George's School will be of assistance to you and the officials of the Department.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Mr Hoey:

Many thanks for your letter received today. The little present enclosed with this letter will surprise you, won't it? But it a relic of the past administration of St. George's, Lytton. Not during the administration of Mr Lett, I am happy to say, but not so many years ago. I was talking to a man the day before yesterday, who was a pupil of the school, when they were in use. And although he assured me he has never been a victim, yet he had seen them used on boys and girls. He said two girls ran away, and they were chained together and driven home in front of the Principal. They used the shackles to chain runaways to the bed. They also had stocks in the playgrounds. And they were used.

I am telling you this, because I want you to know how very much has to be irradiated from the memories of these people, before they will develop confidence in the administration of this school. And until that confidence is developed, very little will be done in the matter of autonomy and pupil organization. It will come. I know it will come, by God's help. After I came here, I looked into the matter of forming groups and placing captains and their respective assistants at the head of each group of 12 boys. The Sr. Teacher said it could never work. He ridiculed the idea, and gave no support or encouragement to the movement. He has gone, and rightly so. I have kept the idea alive, and the captains have been recognised. Recognised by the payment to them of one dollar a month, and I know it will succeed. During the last six months, I have tried to teach my boys just one thing; A sense of Honour. Toward the end of the term, they were just beginning to realize a little of the glory of it. And next term they will realize more.

After years and years of mal-administration, please don't look for definite results too quickly from St.
Georges! But it will come, With God's help, and your interest and human sympathy you won't be disappointed.

Kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

Principal.

Dear Parents & Girls & Boys:

I wonder how you are standing this hot weather? Of course, you are all so used to it, you will not notice it like those who are new to the country. I am very glad you are all away from this hot building. It really is terribly hot, no matter where you go. It is also terribly quiet since you left for your holidays. No laughing is heard, or crying or shouting or singing. Not even the banging of doors or the hurrying of feet up and down the stairs. Sometimes it would be quite nice to hear the boys with their heavy boots running around. It is really no nice place to live in when Indian girls and boys are away. At least, I would not like to live here very long without them. There are too many lonely rooms.

I do hope you are all enjoying your holiday time. I know you girls and boys will enjoy your holidays if you do not think too much about yourselves, and try and help your people all you can. And of course, you parents will enjoy having your children home if you can get their love and respect. You will get the love and respect of your children if you can show them the right way of living. Love and respect does not come by handing out candy to your children, but just by living kindly decent lives. Remember what I tried to tell you girls and boys at our last service in the chapel. It is your duty to love your parents. To be faithful and true to them. You want have them for many years, and when they go, you cannot have a chance to help them; no matter how sorry you may be.

Many of you were at the races last Wednesday. I also went for a short time. But it was so very dusty and hot; and I thought the people all looked tired and hot, as though they would rather have been having a nice quiet time at some lovely green cool place like Botanic Lake.

I felt sorry for the horses. They too, were hot and dusty and tired; and when the men shouted and swore at them, they were confused and frightened. I expect they thought human beings are queer kind of animals. I like horses. They are so clean and decent. They don't get drunk and shout and curse and swear, and use God's name in a bad way. And when I saw two men bucked off, almost as soon as they got into the saddle, I felt like clapping for the horses.

We are working and making some changes; and I think when I write to you again, I shall have more news for you about the changes we are making, and the new people who are coming.

Take care of yourselves, girls and boys, and try and be a blessing and a help to your people.

God bless you all,

Your friend

August 3, 1942

Dear Parents & Girls & Boys:

There are so many things I would like to say to you, I shall have to be careful and not make my letter too long. And in case it may be too long, I shall start by telling you of the arrangements for meeting you on Thursday August the 20th.

Mr Vaughan Jones will take the big truck to Merritt and meet the Merrit pupils at noon, Thursday August 20th, and will also gather up the pupils who leave on the way. Be sure to be there on time, so that he may not have to wait, or return without you.

I shall go to Ashcroft on the same day with the School bus, and will be at the Ashcroft Manor at noon. All pupils from that district please be on hand.

It would help quite a bit if all pupils living around Lytton, and on the other side of the river toward Lillooet would come to Lytton. We have to be so careful with the gas and tires these days.

I do hope you have all had a good holiday, and that you are all looking forward to the coming term at school. I am looking forward to it with a great deal of pleasure, for I would like it to be the best in the history of St. George's. There will be quite a few changes in the staff, though many of the old staff will be with us. Miss Paladeau, as you all know married the Baker man, and we have a man to take her place as Boys' Supervisor and Vice-principal. His name is Mr Hothom, and he has had a great deal to do with boys. Especially sailor boys. I am sure the boys will like him. Mr Cooper also left, and we have a new man coming in his place. Mr Eggleston has left, and Mr Newton Thomas is now in his place. I know you will like Mr Thomas. He is the son of Bishop Thomas of the Diocese of Brandon, and Mrs Thomas is the daughter of one of our clergy. They have both been in the Indian work for a number of years, and know Indian girls and boys very well. They have a dear little boy of 2½ years of age, and his name is Charlie. There will also be a new lady in the Laundry, and three new teachers.

This year, I am asking Mr Mclean to take on a class of the older girls in the Manual, so that they may learn how to use a hammer and saw; so that they may be able to make little things for their home when they grow up. I think the girls will enjoy this part of their training.

I wonder what you have all been doing during your holidays. I hope you have all been useful, and I hope you have all been able to get in some swimming. I have not done very much, for there is not very good swimming around here. Next year, I hope we shall have a real swimming pool, made of cement, and clean and safe. I have seen many of you during holidays, and it has always been such a joy to me to meet you, and to get your smile and "Hallo, Mr Hayes" I have been so pleased to see how nice and clean you have kept yourselves, and so sadly I have not heard one single bad thing about our girls and boys. I have also visited some of your homes, and it has been such a delight to me to see how clean and comfortable many of them are. I love to see a clean, comfortable home. They seem to speak of love and happiness, which are the best things of life.

Well, what have I been doing? Weeding, painting and making jam. I never saw so many big weeds in my life. They really do grow wonderfully well in this country. If they had their way about it, they would crowd out everything else. And so we have to fight just as our soldiers have to fight the enemy, and let the good stuff grow.

Dear Mr Hoey:

It is just a year ago today since we arrived at St. George's; and I feel like writing a few lines to you, because you are too far away for me to come to your office to tell you that in spite of the world, flesh and Hitler, things are going along at a fairly normal rate.

In some ways, and at times the way has been difficult, but not more, and perhaps not as much as I expected, when I came here. And I think I can honestly say the situation is very much better than I expected, and we are confident of the future, so long as we keep our eyes fixed "Toward the Sunrising."

Our progress along academic lines has been rather slow on account of the difficulty of securing teachers. The original teaching staff did not stay long after I came, partly because they had already applied for war work, and partly because they could not stand the change. Not that any of them had either liking or respect for my predecessor, but they developed the foolish idea that they could be a law unto themselves, and such people are difficult to deal with. I was, therefore, relieved when orders came for them to join up. I have since found they were not loyal to the school.

The other ladies on the staff have continued, and I think they are fairly happy in their work.

I have not been able to fill the teacherships with certificated teachers; though all four classrooms are being taken care of by competent people, who have all had very good educational training, and are doing excellent work in the classrooms. In this connection, I wish to assure you that duly qualified teachers will be engaged when such are available.

One of our biggest difficulties is the matter
of salaries. Under the present per-capita grant, we are not able to pay present day wages, and yet I have been forced to raise salaries, in some instances, in order to retain or obtain services of staff workers. This is quite a serious matter, as I am finding it extremely difficult to make ends meet. Prices of pretty well everything have advanced. In fact, it is unnecessary for me to say how difficult it is to operate on the bare per-capita grant. Clothing and footwear is a very large item, but which must be met somehow.

The matter of obtaining meat is a very serious situation, and yet it should not be, and would not be if I had a thousand dollars to buy twenty head of cattle. Instead of which, I have to sit by and see the Jew come in and buy them from the Indians. If there is a thousand dollars in the coffers of New England Company, I do not know of any better way it could be spent than by buying cattle. We have the feed to fatten them, and there is no more profitable way of disposing of cattle feed than by feeding it. If therefore you can possibly send us a thousand dollars from New England Company fund, will you please write me by Air Mail, so that if possible I may get ahead of the Jew and safe guard our meat supply for the Winter.

Our farming activities have been quite good. We have had good crops, but the enormous amount of money we have had to pay out in extra labour absorbs a great deal of the profits. We can grow almost anything here by irrigation; but it entails a lot of hard work, which must be done by men and not by boys. During the twelve months we have had to pay $3200.00 in extra labour. This has been mostly to Indians, and so it has been well placed; but it is a serious drain on our financial resources.

Our relationship with the Indians is very satisfactory. They come around quite a bit, and I hear some very favourable comment from them regarding the school and the pupils. The pupils came back from holidays in very good spirits, and have settled down very nicely. I do quite a lot of visiting with the old people, and I know from experience, that this pays over and over again.

I feel the relationship between the school and the office in Vancouver is greatly improved. It is almost as much of a pleasure and privilege for me to visit the Commissioner in his office, as it was to visit you in your office. I never failed to bring back with me much encouragement from you, when it was my good fortune to visit you.

The Indian Agent, also, I think feels happier about the school, and is always very co-operative. I think
conditions, as they exist here today, are a help to him in his work.

We have had no serious illness or deaths during the year. This is due, to a large extent, to the jealous care exercised by the school nurse. As a matter of fact, if anything, both she and the doctor err on the side of too much care; which probably is erring in the right way.

The year has taught me many things. Things I should have learned long ago, and which would have made my former years more of a success. At Shingwauk, I was always looking for results, and tried to instill that idea into my staff. I suppose, to some extent, I should retain that idea. But by far, the most important object in this phase of life is to give and give and give. There are so few definite instances of permanent success and so many instances, glaring instances, of apparent failure in this work, I really don't think they are worthy of much consideration. But if I and my staff get hold of the true idea of life, in that it is a tremendous privilege and joy to give and being able to give of oneself, that, I feel overcomes the feeling of failure, when it seems to hold up its ugly head.

I am sure you must know what I mean. For I feel assure as can be you have come to that same conclusion in your own office. I have always had the idea you came to that office with very bright ideas of results from your labours. And although you have never said a word to me, I know there must have been times and times when you could have thrown it up for a more attractive and profitable work. Instead of which, consciously or unconsciously, you have been satisfied to give. Perhaps you have got hold of the joy and privilege. I hope you have, or life holds little else.

At present, I dwell on that subject at my staff meetings, and I think they are either seeing the light, or have already seen it and trying to give it to me.

In regard to the girls and boys, I like to speak of them as girls and boys, rather than pupils. I talk to them a great deal about the time when they shall grow up and live in little homes built by the side of rippling streams of water, with beautiful trees around. But just little homes full of life and happiness. I really don't think there is anything greater than that conception for these very poor and simple minded people. To some, this does not sound very ambitious. But at present, I am living for these children, and what the "some" think does not greatly concern me.
You'll think I am rambling on at some length; but I'd probably take up more of your time if I were in your office with you. And to me, it is time well spent, because I am more or less opening up my mind to someone, and that in itself is a good thing to do.

When we see the end of the war in sight, I am going to send you a long list of articles which you may be able to get for us from dismantled camps etc. There will be a great deal of it available. I should think, like there was in the last war, and a lot of this equipment, we have here, would sure look good on the scrap pile. But we shall try and make out until that blessed time, which we pray may already be peeping over the horizon.

And now, at the end of my first year at St. George's I want to thank you for all your encouragement and help.

With all good wishes to you and yours and myself and mine, and with Tiny Tim I would say. God bless us all.

Yours faithfully,

Foreword

It is after much consideration and with twenty-seven years of experience with Indian girls and boys that I venture to compile the following rules and advice, humbly hoping that they may be a help to those who labour for the welfare of Indian girls and boys.

Chas. F. Hives,
Principal.

May 7, 1942.

GENERAL RULES AND ADVICE FOR THE GUIDANCE OF STAFF MEMBERS

1. All Staff members are expected to be familiar with the duties of their own department.

2. Be sure, at all times, to keep your department clean and tidy. This is an important object lesson for the pupils.

3. Be careful of your actions before children. They are excellent imitators.

4. Do not discuss with the children matters concerning other members of the staff.

5. Try and develop good and safe leadership amongst the girls and boys. You will always find leaders. See that they appreciate the privilege of leadership.
6. Be careful in your method of punishing offenders. Do not give corporal punishment. If you think such is required, consult the Principal.

7. Be cheerful about your work, and try and show to the children the honour and privilege of being able to overcome a difficulty and to accomplish a task.

8. Take note of children under your care and see if they are enjoying life. Try to take a personal interest in each one. They are each different from the other, and require individual attention and understanding as far as you are able to give it.

9. In all your teaching with Indian children be THOROUGH.

10. Do not be offended if suggestions are made for the improvement of your department. Co-operate one with the other and with your Principal.

11. Consult your Head Matron and Principal if you find your work very difficult. They will appreciate this confidence and will try to help you.

12. Teachers are responsible for pupils during Recess time and for pupils going to and from classroom. They are also responsible for the sweeping and cleaning of their respective classrooms and for the Saturday morning scrub.

13. Children are not allowed in staff rooms without permission of Head Matron.

14. Supervisors must see that children's hair is cut regularly and decently. Also a proper record kept of all clothing and footwear given out to them.

15. It is expected that all staff members will keep reasonable hours at night, and under ordinary circumstances, lights must be out by 11 p.m.

16. Those in charge of machinery must be careful while children are around. They love to touch anything strange or attractive.

17. In good weather, the children must play outside. Teachers should insist on this at Recess time.

18. Staff members intending to be away for a meal, should notify the Kitchen Supervisor.

19. Girls going to the Gymnasium are to go in a body and return in like manner when leaving.

20. Girls and boys who appear to be over-tired in classroom or elsewhere, should be reported to Head Matron.

21. Dormitory supervision should continue after lights are out until all are settled down.
22. Boys' Supervisor should decide on the amount of clothing boys should take to the dormitory. Hats, jackets and boots are not required.

23. Children should not be in dormitory during the daytime without permission.

24. At all times insist on the dormitory being a dormitory and not a play-room.

25. Dining-room doors and cupboards to be locked when unoccupied, and children are not to handle keys.

26. Children are not allowed to go to the Indian Room without permission. And Indian parents, who come to see their children, must wait in the Indian Room.

27. Read carefully the rules for Fire drill.

28. All staff members should have a flashlight in their bedroom, in case of emergency.

29. One month's notice will be given for the dismissal of a staff member, and should any staff member desire to leave, the same consideration is expected from them.

30. The School is not responsible for medical treatment of staff members. The only two positions covered by Compensation Act are those of Laundry Supervisor and Engineer.

31. At no time is a supply of wood to be kept in the kitchen.

32. Matches are not to be left around where children can have access to them.

33. All children's mail, coming and going, must pass through the office.

34. In general, the Head Matron will supervise all domestic departments.

35. Staff members are expected to attend Daily Prayers as they are able. All are expected to attend at least one service of Divine Worship in the chapel each Sunday.

36. Growing children are all students of some kind and degree. What you teach them, while you are with them, will remain in them in some way or degree. Therefore teach them a love of truth and truthfulness. And the love of beauty, wherever it is found. Help them to know the value of these qualities, which are, perhaps the most important factors in the lives of all children. Teach them to be respectful and clean. Teach them kindness to all. You will find bullies amongst the boys. This is a bad element, but kindness will kill it. Not forgetting kindness and care to
animals. Teach them the importance of prayer. Don't let them neglect the bedside Prayer card, which all have received, and of which there is a supply. Teach them resourcefulness, and the importance of preparing to make an honest living with their own hands. Always try and keep before their minds the future with a home: A little home, well kept and full of Christian love.

Remember, above all things, these children have a personality of their very own. It belongs to them. Was inherited by them, and is a definite part of their make-up. The duty of all staff members is to place before them, through the medium of their own lives, the perfect character of the Divine Son of God. His life is simple enough for all to understand. His character, although the most human of all characters, requires diligent perseverance in copying, but is the salvation of human nature.
Rev. C. F. Hives,
Principal

Dear Mr. Melan:

I have your letter No. 165-0-4 of the 18th inst., relative to the list of books recommended for our use by Public School Inspector McArthur.

Your reply to my letter raises the questions in my mind as to what should be taught in our Indian School, and what are the relative values of each department of the school in respect to each other.

These questions should rightly be answered by a competent Inspector of Indian Schools in council with his competent assistants. The one who is inspecting our school is, I believe, held in very high esteem by his provincial Department, yet he does not give me the impression that he knows the Indian or what is best for his advancement. A knowledge of their character, personality and their natural tendencies comes only through years of contact with them, and cannot be acquired through the reading of romantic literature. And without that knowledge, one cannot supervise properly educational training, or give judgement on which part of the training should take priority.

During the past few months I have had to teach the senior boys. It has been rather a wonderful experience for me; in spite of the fact that it has tied me down, and I have had to work early and late in order to keep with my office work. They are fine boys, and work hard at their studies. I am convinced that they, as well as the senior girls, anticipate very eagerly the time when they will be looked upon as our equals. Therefore, keeping them in touch with the old Indian life, excepting what all Canadian children should learn of it in early Canadian History, cannot be of much value to them or their progress. I am of the opinion that Indian girls and boys are much more interested in knowing what other Canadians are doing in order to fit them for adult life, than they are in knowing what their ancestors used to do. They are wise enough to realize that if they live in the past, or try to copy the exploits of their forbears, they can never hold anything but an inferior position in any walk of life. Moreover, numbers of them, from their physical appearances, would pass for normal Canadians.
that number increases year by year. I don't think we could isolate the Indian, even were it wise to do so; and in the course of time they will become absorbed into the white population.

I feel that one of the chief obstacles in the education and training of our pupils comes from the criticisms offered from time to time by well meaning people who occupy prominent positions, and who have taken a sudden interest in Indian welfare. It is to be sincerely hoped that when appointments of School Inspectors are made, the candidates' years of successful experience with the Indians will figure highly in the qualification required. I feel very strongly that Indian welfare, and the proper administration of Indian affairs should and will depend on our educational system.

There are some who would place academic training or study before all other training. The academic is important, and we give it the lion's share of time and interest in our school. Yet there are other sides of their training which are of equal importance; and without which, academic training stands alone as a menace to the whole structure of the Indian educational system. The nature, character, personality and strong tendencies in the Indian must be studied. In fact, it is that background we should work on.

Take for instance religion. The Indian is naturally very religious. If he is not given a good type of religion, he will make one for himself. I know of this matter. I have seen it, and have heard much about it. And it is practised nearby. It is a kind of witchcraft or devilcraft; and they infuse it with certain of our Christian ceremonials; it hampers the work of the physician, missionary and school. It fosters superstition, degradation and a distrust of the white man. I spoke about religious education to Inspector Moirthur, but he is not interested. I am convinced of its importance in the proper development of these people.

Or take the matter of morality: Since I knew the Indian, I have looked upon him as immoral, not immoral. In this respect, I might say that I have never had occasion to expel a pupil on the charge of immorality during the thirty years of my work with them. Yet nature is very strong in them; and they mature much earlier in life than does the white child; therefore require to guide that part of their emotional make-up along sound and safe channels. If we try to segregate the girls from the boys too much, we do much harm, and defeat our aims of high moral character building. It is extremely important that our girls and boys should be brought together under a good social leader or dancing instructor. For lack of a better, I have taught them many of our best dances. I
even call off the old square dances; and they love it. If, through pressure of work or epidemic of sickness these social functions are neglected, the girls and boys become shy, sly and sneaky. The boys develop a dishonest streak, which finds them "on the carpet" for either being out of bounds or thieving.

There is the practical side of their training; which is very important. The boys love making and building. At present they are building a pig house; which, when completed, will be second to none in the country. The Manual Training Instructor and his classes of boys are entirely responsible for its construction. Besides such work, they make many wonderful things in the Manual shop. The girls do all the inside domestic work in a very efficient way under supervision.

I would not minimize the importance of the academic side of our work. It is very necessary for the quickening of their thinking powers and reasoning capacities. But if these are developed ahead of the others I have mentioned, one can expect to find "hot-heads" who love to organize Native Brotherhood movements and such like. These movements are bound to come; but unless they have proper leadership, and those leaders have something more than academic training, they can only bring disaster and defeat the aims of the Department and Church in their efforts to advance the Indian to the level of Canadian citizenship. I feel sure it would be far better for you and the Department to recognize and demand stability of character in these people, than evidences only of smart academic training.

This letter is longer than I had intended writing to you. But I have done it partly for my own protection. I feel we have an incompetent School Inspector from the standpoint of over emphasizing academic training. I do want you to know my aims; and to give you the assurance that what I have given to you above is what I feel we should practice with Indian pupils.

I would like to thank you very much for the little books you sent with the school supplies this year. They are useful, interesting and enlightening; and the pupils love them.

May I wish you a very Bright and Prosperous New Year.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Mr Philip Mclan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Dear Mr Hoey:

While listening to the C.B.C. news broadcast last evening, it was announced that the Department intends increasing and intensifying academic education of Indians. I am enclosing a letter which I recently wrote to Mr Phelan. I feel very strongly about the matter, or danger, of over emphasizing academic education of our Indians. I am of the opinion it can be overdone, so that the Indian becomes somewhat over-balanced with his own importance, and therefore becomes a menace to his own welfare and steady progress, which he should make in order to attain the social standing he desires.

There is a large percentage of Indians who are shiftless and lazy. Would it not be well to emphasize manual training in their education. We here, at St. George's, have our Manual Shop. The boys take to it; and like it very much better than they do the classroom. I do sincerely hope this matter will be taken into consideration.

It is too bad we are so widely scattered; for I am of the opinion that you could obtain much valuable help, if you could have a small conference of principals and teachers, representing a cross section of Indian work throughout Canada, and of the various churches, or religious bodies.

I am convinced that religion must have its place in the education scheme. Not altogether as a church matter; but as an integral part of the training plan recognised by the Department. These people are a religious people. Always have been. And if specific time is not allotted to this part of their development, they will, and do actually make a horrible form of religion, which is a menace to every effort we put forth for their welfare. And no amount of academic education will, of itself, eradicate it, or give to them the stability of character they need.

Another thing:- I feel we should be very
Much more careful in our choice of the ones who are to be given advanced education. They should be, not only capable of taking advanced education, but more important still, they should have personal qualities in themselves that will insure their making a fair success of their profession.

There are some, who are so intensely Indian, I feel it is almost a crime to encourage them to venture forth into professional life. At this moment we have a problem right here in the hospital at Lytton. An Indian nurse, fully qualified, has come to us. She is from Lac la Ronge. She is having an extremely difficult and unhappy time. Last week two nurses, (One of them acting matron) sent in an ultimatum, saying that if we did not get rid of the Indian nurse, they would quit before night. In honor, we felt bound to let them go. The only reason, as far as we could find out, for their action, was the fact that the nurse is Indian and has a higher professional standing than they. Moreover, any nurse or nurses, who would forfeit their positions at a moment's notice are not worthy of consideration. At the same time, the Indian nurse, who is efficient, honest, clean and of a high moral character, has a road before her, which, if she pursues it, will be almost a hell for her.

I am very anxious indeed to see, and if possible to witness to, the success of our work. And because of this; and because of the years I have spent in the work, I would ask for your liberal consideration of what I have written.

With all good Wishes,

I am, Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dear Mr Hoey:

I am writing you a personal letter about a matter which has caused me some concern; and about which I would like your consideration and advice.

Would you approve of my asking the W.A. of the Anglican Church to give us some support in the matter of clothing, linen and bedding. (I have by me a list of clothing etc., which I have to buy before Winter, amounting to approximately $1,000.00.) This would all be provided for by the W.A. if this school were supported by the W.A.)

But that is not my reason for asking the question. Heretofore, as far as I am aware, they have never been approached in this concern; neither has the Anglican Church, as far as I am aware, ever given any support, financial or otherwise, toward the maintenance of St. George's School. I am not making this statement in the spirit of criticism or judgement; but, in some way, the Anglican Church, is strongly of the opinion that St. George's School is part of her heritage and spiritual responsibility.

I do not know just how you feel about the matter, but I am very strongly of the opinion that the Church, whatever be her creed or denomination, should maintain, and encouraged by your Department to maintain, a spiritual administration over the Indians; and particularly over every department of the school life. I mean in seeing that the staff workers are people with definite Christian principles. My belief is that the Indian is naturally religious; and if those religious tendencies are not guided aright, their whole spiritual and moral character becomes warped/degraded.

From the way I size up the situation, and from a letter recently received from New England Company, this school of St. George's is not a Church school, yet the Anglican Church, through the principal appointed by you maintains her spiritual administrations and influence in the school. I presume such a condition will continue
so long as a prudent and efficient administration is maintained. But an ordained man fail to give the required satisfaction, and the school again became a problem, I presume, would appoint whomsoever they saw fit, in or out of the ministry; which would, of course, cause some uneasy feelings in the church.

As I have said above, I am very strongly of the opinion, that, for the best interests and welfare of the Indians, the school needs the administration and supervision of the Church. And the Indian needs the Church in his upward climb to social equality. But if the Church has not been subscribing in anyway to the maintenance of the school, I don't see how she can expect, or how the Department can give any sympathetic consideration to the Church's claims to nominate an administrator.

If, on the other hand, the Church, through any of her branches or channels, can show that she has subscribed to the maintenance and support of St. George's, no doubt her position in the eyes of the Department would be strengthened.

I would be very much obliged if you would let me know how you feel about this matter.

With kindest regards,

I am Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. [Signature]

Dear Mr Phelan:

I am writing you regarding the matter of applying to the Selective Service for my staff. So far, I have received very little help from them; and most of those who have come to me through the Selective Service office have been of little or no use. Pretty well, the type of people we are able to engage for this work are not in it for what they can get out of it. I mean, our best and most efficient workers are those who have a heart for the work. Generally speaking, Selective Service do not have that type through their offices.

A little while ago the District Enforcement Officer came here and raised trouble because I was not able to show that all my workers had not been engaged through Selective Service. It seemed to me he was rather unreasonable in the attitude he took. Anyway I tried to call on him yesterday in Kamloops, and he was not in. His second in command was, and I explained the matter to him. He said "Why not write your Department and get an exemption?" Hence my reason for writing you.

Last Spring I was greatly in need of a male help on the staff, and had advertised through the Selective Service in Vancouver. A man applied, but because we are in the Kamloops district, his application had to be transferred from the Vancouver office to the Kamloops office, where it was looked over and after a while sent on to me. I determined to work as fast as possible in securing the man, and jumped on the train at three o'clock in the morning. The train arrived in Vancouver, where the man lived, at 8:30. I immediately went to the phone and called up the man. The answer was "I am not interested, have another job."

If you can get us an exemption from all this fuss and unnecessary bother, I think you would be helping us out, and I could then apply through the church papers where we would be more likely to get the right type of workers.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I wish to acknowledge, and also to thank you for your letter of the 5th inst. From what I read in your letter, and in between the lines, it would appear that you are much more in need of sympathy and real help than I am. Although such a thought does not diminish my difficulties or worries, not that I am afraid of either difficulties or worries. What I do fear is the lowering of standards of living.

During my administration here, I have tried in every way to raise the standards of living, which I consider were, four and a half years ago, at a pretty low ebb. I am quite confident they have been raised; and to a standard which we should maintain. Our children are better fed, better clothed, more carefully and intelligently supervised, and more systematically and scientifically treated from the health standpoint. Consequently, they are much happier and satisfied. The parents seem to have more confidence in us. From past records on file, it would appear that there was a fair amount of adverse criticism of the administration here. If such exists here at present, I am unaware of it. From records of the past, truancy amongst girls and boys was a common practice. It is now an uncommon thing. Since last September we have had only three. They were very small boys, who went away altogether just before Christmas. They said they wanted to see the city Christmas lights. I have always felt truancy to be a good indication of the quality of supervision maintained in the school, as well as the standard of living.

We must maintain this standard of living. Our food, our clothing, our supervision, and our instruction and teaching must be equal in quality to that of any other well established boarding. But I cannot see how this can be done unless the present per capita grant is supplemented. I am well aware of the fact that the grant allowance is higher now than ever before; but so is the cost of living. Also the low missionary salaries seem to be a thing of the
past. Since the end of the war, I have been able to secure better teachers and supervisors. But have had to increase salaries. Last November I was fortunate in being able to secure the services of a young man, who had been Carpenter Instructor in the army. I find him an excellent man with the boys as Manual Instructor. He had just recently been married to a young school teacher. She is now doing excellent work in one of our classrooms.

I am very anxious to keep them; and naturally, the best way of doing this is to provide them with a decent home. At present they are living in one of the rooms in the main building. The cottage, which I hope they will eventually occupy is not fit to live in until it has been reconditioned. This he will do with his class of boys when we can buy the material.

I am writing the local Indian Agent regarding some of the most urgent requirements. I don't expect to receive everything we would like to have, but I would like to maintain, not only our standard of living, but also be able to keep our equipment and buildings in a good state of repair.

It would be a great privilege to meet a representative of the New England Company; and if I may look forward to that, I would very much like to prepare some interesting views of our work.

I cannot help but wish that I might be nearer to you. Not that I could expect to be of any great value or assistance to you, excepting I would like you to feel my good wishes in your very difficult tasks.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Hives:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 7th, in which you seek information with respect to the time when the representative of the New England Company is likely to arrive in Ottawa.

I regret to state that shipping conditions being what they are at the moment, I find it difficult to even suggest when this representative of the Company is likely to arrive here. I note with interest your reference to the fact that additional funds might be secured for educational work from the New England Company. I am disposed to think, with the information at my disposal, that we are more likely to lose the assistance we are now receiving. The New England Company sustained tremendous losses during the course of the war and losses from which they are not likely to recover in the immediate future, if at all. In any event, I think it would be very unwise to build up hopes based on the thought of additional aid. My personal opinion is that the time has arrived when the Canadian Government should assume full responsibility for the education of the Indian population in this country. It seems to me somewhat inconsistent that Canada should be granting loans to Britain on the one hand and seeking assistance in the operation of our Indian schools from missionary societies in England, on the other. However, this is a matter on which there may be room for argument and discussion.

Sir:

I am writing this letter in reference to a foolish letter recently received from you to Archie Blankinship; in which you ask if we treat him like a human or a dog. Why do you not come and see for yourself? You must have some reason for asking such a question. I'd like to meet you, and tell you a few things about St. George's School, and also a few things about the people who send their children here. I know quite a lot about them, for I have been in the work for over thirty years; and during that time I could not find a dozen Indians who have said a thank you for anything that has been done for their children, or given any support for their education or upkeep in any way. Yet they can write foolish letters like the one you have written, and say foolish and indecent things behind one's back.

You evidently have not received much in the way of an education, or you might know that a little boy like Adam, who has just entered the Kindergarten class could not possibly write a letter a few days after arriving in school. He, along with all other boys here of his size, age and standing in the classroom go to school all day. Dear Major MacKay:

I have your letter No. 7-II-I of the 9th inst. to acknowledge and reply. I wish to assure you that our dwindling surplus causes me not a little concern, but cannot do much about it, for I suppose every housekeeper will tell you the same reason that I have to give.

First of all there is the advanced cost of every commodity of food and clothing that we have to buy. Some advances in price are very much more than the increase in the per capita grant. Likewise the increased cost in fuel. These are the essentials of life, and we cannot cut down on them.

Next is the increase in salaries of the staff workers. I have had to increase all salaries in order to secure enough competent workers. My own salary remains the same as it was when I came, but all others have had to be increased.

Then the demands for a full time education for the pupils is also a tax on our financial resources. Very few boys remain out of the classroom and Manual shop. Which means I have to hire extra labour to do the work on the farm. This means paying out each month two to four hundred dollars.

I mentioned our situation to Mr Hoey, while I was in Ottawa, and his comment was that no doubt prices would go down to normal, and then our circumstances would improve.

I have the feeling that we shall improve our financial position in the near future, for we have a crowded school.

Yours faithfully,

A Defense of St. George's

THE WORK OF ONE INDIAN SCHOOL

By Rev. Canon C. F. Hives

Editor, The Sun, Sir,

The following headlines appeared in your newspaper last Friday: "Church Indian Schools held up by Indians," and "Church schools better as a protest against the headlines, but with an earnest effort to show what the Church has done and is doing for Indian education. Facts which are not generally known may be of interest and should not be lost if these ulterior and sinister criticisms are allowed to go unchallenged.

After reading over the account under the heading "Church schools" I started to find that the Indian young man who made the statement, comes of fairly good stock, and is far more to Church Indian school education than they can ever hope to repay. He is very grateful to the Church for receiving recognition or even appreciation from them for anything she has done. His attitude shows that hundreds have received an education and training which would otherwise never have come their way had it not been for the Church during the many years she has been engaged in this work. Never at any time has she called on them for any monetary payment; her own aim has been to give them what she could bestow upon them which shall eventually lead them to equality of citizenship with all other people of our country. More frequently than not, her efforts to educate have been met with prejudice from the pupils, and have required, on the part of the teachers much patience, faithfulness and perseverance, in view of the very limited financial resources with which to carry on the work.

A Family's Education

The young man who made the statement owns a St. George's School for years of his early education, which has, no doubt, been one of the contributing factors to his now enviable status as a student at the UBC. His sister holds a B.C. teacher's certificate, and maintains the same commitment which she owes directly to the education care and attention she received from St. George's School. Four other brothers received more than an average education at St. George's School. Three or four other sisters also received their education at St. George's School. Last Saturday I sat down and conversed with two of these sisters, who had come some distance to see me. While talking with them I felt very proud of the fact that this school had given them the opportunity to acquire knowledge and poise of conduct, has made them more than equal to the average lady of the land. They are able to converse with such intelligence. The father of this family held a very good position in a section of town on the railway. His income was sufficient to house him and his children to the village public school where he lived. He chose to send them to St. George's School. We now have several younger generation children of the family.

What It Costs

We have in residence at St. George's School 25 pupils, 16 boys and nine girls who are treated after as a family and are no cost to their parents. Until last October we received a per capita grant allowance from the Department of Canada which worked out to approximately $1.00 per child per day. Since then the grant has been increased and amounts to approximately $1.10 per child per day. In addition to this we must buy all food, clothing, pay all salaries, 20 in all, heat, light, fuel, and all other expenses connected with the institution. If this were a secular institution such finances resources would not be sufficient. Being a Church institution this grant is supplemented by financial aid from an old mission society in England.

Were we to close our doors many of our pupils would be absolutely deprived of a chance to attend school. To substitute the education they are doing by this school 20 day schools, each with a teacher's residence, would have to be opened (at least a very conservative estimate). Last year we added five new pupils, all between the age of seven and eleven. Without these had never had a chance to attend school. Five of these are there, but who would still be deprived to attend school had we not taken them in. Abolish the Church residential schools and you will find, or the taxpayers of Canada will find, that many millions of dollars will have to be found to supersede the present system. Or, if the matter becomes a political question the Education Department would quite a problem on their hands.

My teaching staff consists of four fully-qualified B.C. certified teachers, one principal instructor trained by the Canadian Army, and a good shop with some pupils took a gymnastic course with weightless gymnastics. Five of my pupils are attending high school in Victoria and are there every morning by our own bus and brought back in like manner in the afternoon. We have five more to attend high school next year, or rather next term.

I am very much obliged if you would send a reporter to visit our school. Please you will serve a good purpose by doing this and be the means of exploding some of the absurd criticisms which I feel have their origin in some rather small movement that would close Church residential schools and bring about their desired chaos in our social order. Your reporter does not need to earn his living here. He would find us doing the same one thing. Looking after a large and ordered family.

No Corporal Punishments

We are not perfect by any means. There are many, many things we would like to do more than we are doing. Many needed improvements we would like to make, but we make as time and means give us the opportunity. With the resources we have, and with the help of God whom we try to serve, we are not lacking in efforts to obtain wonderful results we obtain. During the past eight years we have had students who have graduated. During the past nearly three years we have had no cases of truancy. And during this time there has been no corporal punishments. These are facts which I think should speak louder than these headlines in your newspaper which may, perhaps, be of interest to the public.

CHAS. F. HIVES,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Colonel Neary:

In reference to your letter of the 13th inst. File 888-I (EI).

Miss Howe was a member of my staff from November 1946 to end of May 1948. From the standpoint of loyalty to duty, I could not wish for anyone better, but she caused a great deal of mischief and unhappiness with the other members of the staff, which in the end left me no other choice than to dismiss her at a moment's notice. It was either that or lose a valuable teacher. The administrator of the hospital at Lytton spoke to me not so very long before, telling me that he would have to ask Miss Howe to stay away from the hospital, as she was causing friction amongst the staff there. If you care to write to anyone at Moose Factory school, who was there while she was on the staff there, I think you will have the same story.

The rule here is that the staff members receive two weeks salary extra when they leave for their holidays, and if they return they receive two weeks salary on their arrival.

I dismissed Miss Howe on May 30th., and paid her in full to the end of May. I do not consider that Miss Howe is entitled to any extra salary after being dismissed, and I am sure that the members of my staff would uphold me in my action. I try to be fair in all my dealings with my staff; but there are times when disciplinary methods have to be used.

If it is the wish of the Department that I should send to Miss Howe the money she demands, I shall do so; but from a legal standpoint, I understand from the Unemployment office that when a person is dismissed from a position for any serious charge, such as that which caused Miss Howe's dismissal from the staff of our school, no bonus would be given.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Major MacKay:

I know I should not be writing direct to you about my worries, but from my experience with you in the past, I feel sure you will realize that I would not bother you over our affairs if matters were running on an even keel. From the standpoint of order and progress, happiness and good health amongst the pupils, and good relationship with the parents, I don't think I could wish for anything better than what we are now enjoying. But it is this gnawing fear of debt, takes away or nullifies the best of one's ability to serve.

So far, I have been able to keep out of debt, but only by scrimping and making others do likewise. But there seems to be no limit to the high that commodities are soaring, and unless financial help increases, we simply cannot honorably carry on.

I wonder if Indian Residential schools are all rocking in the same boat. If so, I feel sure that the matter is before you as an urgency that must receive attention.

Colonel Neary:

Lytton Residential School:
A few comparisons with the Mohawk Institute which is administered similarly may be interesting.

PHYSICAL EDUCATION is, at Lytton, on an organized basis. Exercises and games are a part of the class time-table. In bad weather there is available a gymnasium (unheated) equipped with a good variety of apparatus. More use might be made of the auditorium. Equipment for outdoor games is plentiful and its use is supervised and encouraged.

LIBRARY There is no separate room at either school. Here at Lytton most books are concentrated in the senior grades' room where the high school students do their homework. But Mohawk now has none. For evening study the lighting could stand improvement. Books and equipment for the study of science are a need.

SEWING INSTRUCTION: The space and equipment at Lytton are both on a more nearly adequate scale, although each school presents a more "cluttered" appearance than is desirable. An examination of objectives seems necessary as on a brief survey it would seem that the "chore" of keeping clothes in repair excludes the study of textiles, values, line and color, care and cleaning, new garment-making, knitting, etc. I notice a number of looms were not in use.

The provision of mending machines would release a lot of pupil-hours that could be given to progressive work. The farms are mechanized, but household activities lag too near the pace of the usual hom...
Neither school washes dishes in the modern institutional way. As in a few schools elsewhere arrangements should be made to have a few students in turn do household tasks on a household scale. The range of education will continue to be very narrow and unattractive as long as the big schools of today are geared to the habits of the small schools that set the pattern. A new pattern is necessary in many cases. Elements of it already exist at some schools.

The heating plant has fuel- and labour-saving devices and a reserve of power which is said to be adequate for a classroom block which is desired so that more pupils may do a full day's work in school. This would entail the use of some of the present classrooms as dormitories. The three excellent classrooms at the Mohawk Institute might well be increased to four while army buildings are available.

Congestion in dormitories is seen at both schools and is too reminiscent of the crowded home conditions that Indians must be taught to improve. At Lytton the personal property of a pupil is more easily available to him, and he gets a better concept of house and town. Behaviour in and maintenance of the washrooms is a subject of instruction to which both schools could profitably give added emphasis.

This large, well-built and easily-serviced piggery was erected with monetary aid of only $800 from the Department. In animal husbandry teaching our schools might use the pig and calf club organizations more freely. Kamloops Residential school does so successfully.

The exploitation of hothouses could become an occupation at which Indians could compete.

Lytton has repaired this large combined root- and fruit-house which is well stocked. The "McIntosh Reds" which I saw heaped up would have found a ready sale in competition. These children get much more than the usual proportion of fruits and vegetables and their taste in such foods has been cultivated to the point where they would scorn the all-too-frequent starchy diet.

The unheralded visitor sees the dining-room set for the next meal with an apple at each place. There is milk, too, in plentiful supply. Tableware and cutlery are better than some I have seen.

What I saw in this school confirms my belief that other schools could be doing better than they are doing.

Dear Mr. Reid:

I am taking the liberty of writing you in reference to our work. Sometime ago you visited us, and I really enjoyed that short visit, for you appeared to be extremely interested in our work, and you gave me much encouragement in what you had to say about things you saw. Our work has grown, and we now have over two hundred pupils in residence, with many more waiting their turn to come in as we have room for them. Those whom we have we are trying in every way to care for; and during these days of advanced cost of living, I find it extremely difficult.

We are receiving a per capita grant of $257.00 per annum. If you take off 75 days for Summer and Christmas vacation, you have 260 days that pupils are in residence. We are, therefore, receiving nearly 89 cents per day per pupil. Out of this amount pupils have to be fed and clothed; light and fuel provided; and salaries, accommodation and food for twenty of a staff. You know whether or not this amount is adequate to meet all these obligations. When one considers the cost of keeping a patient in hospital, the amount we are expected to carry on with is out of all proportion.

This is a Dominion Government institution. It is not a Church institution in the same way as many residential schools are. That is, we receive no support in money or in kind from the Church. We do receive a small amount from the New England Company, the founders of St. George's School, but it amounted to two thousand dollars last year.

Great things are expected of these schools, and great criticisms are made of them; both by the general public and by the Indian parents; both of whom are quite ignorant of the amount of support we receive. Increasing demands are made continually by the Department and the parents, and often forgetting to supply the extra support that should accompany each demand. I mean, for instance, we try to give full time education in the classroom or in the Manual Training shop. This means employing extra labour in order to carry on the work. Every once in awhile we
receive literature relating to food and diet for the pupils. It is all good literature, and I suppose it has cost a small fortune to compile it, but never a word is said about extra financial help to meet the cost of providing these foods.

Believe me, sir, I am probably more anxious than most people to see the standard of living raised for these native people. I have given a full lifetime to this work, and have received little else in return than worry and hard work. Not that that matters so long as we are receiving a square deal from the Dominion Government; or that we are not getting an unfair deal.

I am writing this to you, partly because, from what I read of your interest in the Joint Committee sessions on the Indian Act; and partly because I think you would want to have some information on conditions that have to do with the native work, and which may at anytime be brought up in the House. I also feel sure that if the opportunity came your way, you would do your part in easing the burden and strain caused by our having insufficient financial help to do and accomplish this unavoidable task.

With kindest regards and every good wish.

I am, Yours faithfully

(sgd) Chas. F. Hives

Principal.

Dear Parents:

This is my Christmas letter to you, and is written partly for the purpose of making sure that you know our plans for the Christmas holidays; and also to send to you my Christmas message and greetings.

In a former letter, I told you that Christmas holidays will commence on Friday, Dec. 16th, when you must come for your children, or have some reliable person to see that they get home safely, and return them to school on Jan. 2nd. You must also send or bring warm holiday clothing for them. This clothing should be sent before-hand, so that your children may be ready when you come for them. These are rules which must be kept, if the children are to be allowed home for the Christmas holidays.

I do not know you as well as I would like; for my work here with my large family of 200 does not allow me to go out amongst you very much. But I do know you through your children, for they reveal to us the kind of a home and parents they come from. The wonderful thing about a home is that the child receives its early training and first lessons of life there. Taught to them by Mother and Father. For that reason, the home or family life is the most important part of the child's life. So important is the home or family life in the sight of God, that He allowed us our first glimpse of Jesus, the Divine Son of God, in simple family life. We love the Christmas story, because we understand it so plainly. Even the poorest of us can go to the Stable of Bethlehem, and see and understand the human love that surrounds the new born Baby.

So Christmas comes to us, chiefly for the purpose of telling us how very important and sacred is the home, because God made it holy by using it to reveal Himself to all mankind. We do exactly the same thing when we make our family life in the home, a sacred and happy unity.

My message to you, dear parents, is that you will allow nothing into your home and family life that would ruin it of its beauty and holiness. And my wish is that you may all be very happy together this Christmas-time.

God bless you and keep you.

Yours faithfully,

Principal.

My Dear Major McKay:

It has occurred to me that you might like to have an unofficial report of a visit I paid recently to St. George's I.R. School, Lytton.

Ever since I became Bishop of this Diocese nearly seven years ago I have been closely in touch with the school going in to visit them two or three times each year. My first visit this year was just after Easter, when I went along on Saturday afternoon and stayed over until Monday afternoon. During this time I had ample opportunities of looking over the farm and the school and of mixing with the staff and the children. I very much enjoyed this visit and was much impressed by what I saw going on both within and outside the school.

The farm appeared to be in a flourishing condition. The cows (34 with numerous calves) pigs (5 for 6 good sows with litters of various numbers and sizes) sheep (54 with lots of lambs) turkeys (160 youngsters) hens (400) and the bees all appeared to be doing well. The fields are either planted or in the process of being prepared for the various cereals and vegetables needed. There were wheat, oats, barley, potatoes, carrots, beets, rhubarb etc. Of fruits there are apples, pears, cherries, peaches and apricots; the Principal was somewhat concerned with these and was replacing some which had been killed by the record cold of the past winter. Some new land was being cleared of trees and bush and prepared for future use. To make for more convenient access to the school a stretch of new road was being made, largely by the labour of the school, helped out by a bulldozer which was necessary for the heaviest of the work.

The School buildings appeared to me to be in very good order. All were very clean and tidy and well kept. When going through the sewing work room I was much impressed by a great pile of 100 new blankets which had been made from the wool shorn from the school's sheep and other material supplied. Another item of
interest was the fact that Canon Hives had been able, by judicious re-arrangement of rooms and storage space, to provide for the accommodation for the High School pupils of the neighbouring town of Lytton to continue their studies. Their own school had burned down a few weeks ago. This was much appreciated by the town's school authorities and also allowed the education of those high school pupils of St George's who had been going into Lytton daily to continue their education without interruption.

That impressed me most of all was the condition of the children. They knew me well enough by now to be quite natural when I am around and I was able to observe them freely in the school, in the chapel and round about the place. Not only are they well clothed and well fed, but they appeared to be to be contented and happy, quite like a large family living happily together. The staff and children were getting along very well.

Altogether, my visit was a very happy one for me. I was much impressed by the quality of the life lived at the school and of the education imparted therein. I was particularly pleased with the behaviour of the children in the Chapel services. By the way they took their parts in the worship they were obviously enjoying the religious exercises in which they were engaged.

Much of the success of the school must be attributed to the excellent leadership and devotion of the Principal, Rev. Canon C.J. Hives and his inestimable wife. He is indeed the "key" man of the school and gives himself without limit to the task of leading the life of the school and of being a great father to the staff and the children. He has my greatest admiration and respect.

I am somewhat concerned about Canon Hives. It seemed to me that he is in danger of breaking down under the strain of the burden he is carrying and I suggested to him that he should try to get a real and extended holiday this year to re-new his strength.

Hoping that you may be interested in the above.

With all good wishes,

Sincerely yours,

[Fredric Cariboo.]
