REPORT FROM ST. GEORGE'S SCHOOL, Lytton, B.C.

to Synod, Kamloops, May 31st 1950.

My Lord and Gentlemen:

This report will be confined to the activities of St. George's School during the year 1949, when there was an average attendance of 200-25 pupils. The largest attendance in the history of the school. There were no deaths and very little sickness of any kind. No cases of truancy and no corporal punishments. The last two items may not appear of importance, but really they register the moral tone of this school, and to those who are at all intimate with institutional life and routine, realize the importance of a healthy and proper moral standing. Unless such an institution is run at a normal moral level, complications of a very serious nature, both with the pupils as well as the staff, are the inevitable result, and in consequence, progress is slow. I am happy to be able to honestly report good steady progress has been made in all departments of the school; that a fair standard of efficiency has been maintained; and from reports here and there, St. George's School is held in high esteem by the native people and local white people, as well as by the Indian Affairs of the Dominion Government.

Having more or less blown a trumpet, which would seem like self praise, I would ask your indulgence as I point out to you some of the happenings that have, to some extent, made up the life of the school during the year ending December 31st 1949; the most important of which was the sacred rite of Confirmation, when forty Indian girls and boys were presented to the Lord Bishop of the Diocese. We try, in every possible way to make this event an important one in the life of these children. The service itself is an impressive one; but doubly so when proper preparations have been made in preparing the candidates carefully, and the entire school eagerly taking an active part in the services. The Bishop, as usual, gave a very helpful and inspiring talk to the candidates. While these young communicants are at school, they are very regular in making their communion. I would, however, hope you know that they attend of their own free will. Some set themselves a rule to attend, perhaps every two weeks, or perhaps once a month. They are encouraged in this matter, and are urged to, if at all possible, to hold fast to this rule.

Last fall we had a very delightful visit from the Primate of All Canada, and Mrs. Kingston. I feel sure they enjoyed their visit, and they appeared to be very interested in the life of the institution, and definitely appreciative of the work that is being done for our Indian children.

At this time, last year, I received word, through the Bishop of the Diocese, from New England Company, asking us to join them in celebrating their three hundredth Anniversary, by giving a break in the routine, and other expenses. I asked that we might invite all the ex-pupils of St. George's School to a lunch, so that we might have a re-union, and an opportunity of reminding them of their old school days, and the obligations they owe to life from the help they received from St. George's. New England Company asked their approval of this plan, and we prepared a luncheon for 350 guests. Four hundred and fifty arrived, and it seemed as though we had a repetition of the feeding of the five thousand; for all sat down and all were well fed.

I cannot pass over this matter without paying a very sincere tribute to New England Company for the financial help they have given to the work at St. George's School, and which they are still giving year by year, as my financial statement will show. Many people have never heard of this venerable mission society, which has its headquarters or court in London, England. It is the oldest missionary society in England, and was founded by Oliver Cromwell, and afterward given its charter by King Charles II. For about one hundred years, the work of this society was carried on by missionaries near Boston, Mass. Afterward, when their arose political differences between England and America, they moved from Boston into Canada, where their work was...
carried on amongst the Six Nations Indians in Ontario. Two schools were founded by New England Company; one at Brantford, called the Mohawk Institute, and the other amongst the Thompson Indians at Lytton, called St. George's.

It is, therefore, with a deep sense of gratitude to this most venerable of all English missionary societies, and to Almighty God, for the wonderful contribution which they have made on behalf of the native children of Canada. Believers, however, will I say that I do not know how we could have carried on without their splendid help during the very difficult and trying years of advanced prices in everything bought with the dollar. Often I have been tempted to appeal for assistance from our own Missionary Society and the W.A., but so far, we have not in any way received a cent or a garment from "M.S.C." or the W.A. Our per capita grant allowance, which we receive from Indian Affairs, amounts to about ninety cents per day. With that we feed and clothe the child, pay all salaries and meet all other maintenance expenses.

During the year, twelve of our pupils have attended the High School in Lytton. These are taken every morning by our own vehicle, and brought back after school in the afternoon in like manner. We receive an extra grant of eighty dollars per capita for High School pupils. Last Autumn we sent three girls to the Alberta Provincial School of Nursing (Iides) in Calgary to take a training. I am not only very pleased with the reports I have received from the Superintendent of their progress, but I am hopeful of many more following them year by year.

During the Fall of last year we received a very delightful visit from Dr. Perkins, Resident Canon of Westminster Abbey. The lantern slides which he showed, and the address which he gave were very interesting and helpful to all of us at St. George's and to the many visitors who came to hear him.

About two months ago, the Lytton High School was completely destroyed by fire. The School Inspector and the Principal came to us seeking help and classroom accommodation for forty-two pupils. This we gave to them, so that practically no school time was lost, or disorganization caused. This following is a letter received from the Public School Inspector, and speaks for itself.

Office of Inspector of Schools,
515 Columbia Street,
Kamloops, B.C.

May 8, 1950.

Canon Hives, Principal,
St. George's School,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Canon Hives:

I wish to convey to you and your Department my sincere thanks and appreciation for the splendid co-operation and assistance we have received from you in providing the accommodation for our students when we lost our High School recently by fire. As a result of your splendid effort, almost no time has been lost by our students. The morale and interest of the students have thus been easily maintained.

In closing, may I congratulate you for your success in operating an excellent type of Indian School.

Yours truly,

(sgd) F. A. McLellan
Inspector of Schools.

There are, no doubt, many other items of interest which might be added to this report, which is becoming a little drawn out, but I would like to say a word about the future of St. George's.
Next month, the Engineering branch of Indian Affairs are planning to revise our domestic water system, by renewing all the main pipe line and extending it about half a mile further up the mountain to the source of supply. There, at the source, will be made a fifty thousand gallon reservoir. This will serve to give us a more adequate supply of water, and also protect the water from contamination. Also, this year our electric light system will be modernized and be more convenient and safe. These two projects will cost a great deal of money. Next year we have a building program which, if carried out, will give us a six classroom block, thereby taking all the classrooms out of the main building, which space will then be used for dormitories, and so increase our pupilage by, at least, fifty.

So, my lord, and brethren, I would have you know that St. George's School, which, if not a Diocesan school, is a Church school in your midst, and is a going and a growing concern, of which, I feel sure, should you visit it, you would be justly proud, and find it to be worthy of your prayerful and sympathetic support.

Dear Mr Arneil:

I am writing you to ask your permission to take two months holiday commencing Sept. 22nd. This is the first time that I have done such a thing during the thirty four years that I have been Principal of an Indian Residential School. My doctor advises me to do this for the sake of my health, and I really think it would not do the staff any harm for me to be away from them for awhile.

By the time I would start my holiday the pupils would all be in and settled down. I feel confident that I shall have a good strong staff. My wife would not accompany me on my trip to England. My wife is Canadian, and therefore has no ties of relationship in England. New England Company has very kindly offered to contribute toward my expenses by paying for my ticket returning from England. I appreciate this very much indeed, as I really should not spend so much on a holiday. And yet, I feel assured that the rest and change will be of great benefit to me in many ways.

While I am absent, I would like to leave Mr. Ronald Purvis in charge. I feel he is quite capable of looking after things for two months, for he has been with me for sometime, and knows the work pretty well.

On my way to England, I would like to call at Ottawa, and if there is anything that requires attention in relation to the school, I could give it while there.

Yours faithfully,
